cs_en: Petr Čech: Last-minute transfer?
Anything is possible
Today is the last day when you can still jump through the transfer window and make a big transfer.
The next chance won't come in winter.
Petr Bohemia, currently Chelsea's replacement goaltender, now does not sit over a new professional contract in Madrid, Monaco or Paris.

He sits in the Smíchov NH Hotel, talks with Czech journalists and is preparing for a Czech rehearsal with Americans and then also for a sharp start qualification about Euro 2016 against the Netherlands.
In the goal of Chelsea in the new season Premier League takes priority Thibaut Courtois, the Czech first time in ten years in the London club became an alternate.
Some time ago it was speculated that Real Madrid might be interested in the Czech Republic.
He lost the Spanish Super Cup at the beginning of the season in duels with Atlétice and couldn't even make it to the league season when he lost 2:4 in San Sebastian.
There was also speculation about the interest of Paris SG.
He pulled two wins into the French league season and two draw, shot up St. Etienne 5:0 on Sunday.
Relatively the most pressing boot club AS Monaco.
He's got 1-1-2 in the league so far, and he broke up with Lille at 1-1 this weekend.
News popped up on the tabloid English website today that the Czechs might want to go to Queens Park Rangers.
According to English bookmakers, however, the Czech departure from Chelsea at the last minute is not very likely.
Skybet set a course of four to one on him.
Peter, is it possible that you'll still change your jersey in the last few hours?
I don't count on it, but there's never anything 100% in football.
Maybe there'll be an offer during the day that can't be rejected.
What would such an offer have to look like?
(CHUCKLES) "Well, I don't know yet what such an offer, which can't be rejected, actually looks like.
It would have to be a consensus of all parties First of all, it would depend on Chelsea's position whether or not the club would have dealt with the offer.
Is it technically feasible to make such a transfer now that you're in Prague?
Wouldn't it be necessary for you to sign a new contract somewhere in the new assignment?
That's not what I was thinking.
But there's a lot of players in this situation today, they're all at some representation meetings somewhere, and I'm sure a lot of transfers are gonna close today.
So somehow it would be feasible.
How many clubs are there on the planet that could afford you?
Well, I really don't know.
And you don't pressure yourself to leave?
The situation where I didn't catch a new season in the first three games is new to me after 15 years of career.
However, there's no reason to panic, pack and go anywhere.
I want to continue this fight for goalie Chelsea's position, and it's up to the coach who he chooses, what decisions he's gonna make over the next few weeks.
What role does family play in your decision-making?
I'm taking all the factors into account.
Of course, it is a sporting aspect that matters to me, but I also look at it from a personal aspect, which of course the needs of the family belong to.
Is it possible that you would catch another club in England?
That's the question I thought would never concern me.
But anything is possible in football.
I don't want to rule anything out.
I don't know the answer.
Presidents of the Government of India and Japan at a meeting in Tokyo

The new Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is in Tokyo to meet his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe. On his first major visit since May's election victory, he is to discuss economic and security commitments.
Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to consolidate economic ties with the third largest economy in the world.
First of all, there are plans for greater cooperation in the field of nuclear energy.
According to the rapporteurs, India also hopes that both nations will agree on cooperation on defence issues.
Police in Karrata arrested a 20 - year - old young man after a motorcycle chase
They stopped the bike after a zone with a maximum speed of 70 km/h drove 125 km/h and went to the bush to escape the cops.

The patrolling traffic police in Karrata tried to stop the blue bike at the side of the road this morning when they noticed that they were driving 125 km/h on the exit from the gas station on Bathgate Road.
According to the police, the driver didn't stop and went down Burgess Road and then turned into a bush, so the cops lost sight of him.
The bike and the person who matched the driver's description were then spotted in a house in Walcott Way, Bulgara.
Karrath Police accused a 20-year-old man of disobeying a call for a halt and careless trial.
There will be September 23rd before the Karrata trial.
Motorcycle's been impounded for three months.
George Webster accused of rape at hotels in Nairn and Pitlochry
A man will be brought to trial on charges of rape of women in two hotels.
George Webster, 28, was briefed during the Glasgow Supreme Court hearing.
Supposedly, on June 7, 2013, he was supposed to rape a woman at the Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire County.
According to Webster, she was attacked while she was unconscious, sleeping and not in a state to give her consent.
Furthermore, Webster is prosecuted for rape of another woman at the Golf View Hotel in Nairn at the Scottish Highlands of 4 May 2014.
Judge Lady Rae set the trial date at the Edinburgh Supreme Court on November 17th.
Restoring the very American ideal that labour rights are also human rights
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have proposed a law designed to protect the organisation of trade unions as civil law.
©According to how unions work, jobs for the middle class work, says Ellison, a democratic senator for Minnesota, co-chaired by the Congress Committee.
That is why I am so proud to present, along with the example of occasional rights, John Lewis, a law that strengthens the position of employees.

This groundbreaking legislation will give workers the same legal opportunities to prevent discrimination in the organisation of trade unions as in other forms of discrimination - and will stop anti-union forces

To amend the Labour Relations Act to allow all workers who face discrimination if they want to join the trade unions, to sue a civil court - and to sue compensation or compensation - is a proper and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not according to American standards.
The best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other plaintiffs put in the law is to reestablish America's ideal.

Despite the trade union struggles that have taken place in recent years - Wisconsin, Michigan, and other states - Americans have once supported countries around the world to adopt, extend and respect labour rights.
There were times, and millions of Americans still remember them, when the country was one breather of democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, and the right to gather.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas MacArthur and his advisors supported the country to adopt a constitution designed to ensure that Hideki Toja's military autocracy would be replaced by democracy.

They were convinced that employees and their unions played a role in shaping the new Japan, including the language and openly acknowledged that the right of employees to gather, negotiate collectively and act is guaranteed.

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his advisors urged the Germans to create a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism would be replaced by a strong democracy.

The Germans realized that employees would need to organize and promote themselves in the new nation, and therefore they included a clause that openly says: "The law is to create associations that will ensure and improve working and economic conditions for each individual and every profession or profession will be guaranteed.
Arrangements that will restrict or seek to damage this right will be abolished. Measures leading to the fulfilment of such a purpose are illegal.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Commission for Human Rights, which proposed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted by the United Nations as a global treaty in 1948, the plaintiffs and Roosevelt guaranteed that everyone has the right to create and enter trade unions in order to protect their interests.
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labour rights are human rights.

When the country advised other countries how to create a civil and democratic society, Americans explained that the right to create labor unions - and their participation in collective bargaining with companies and government agencies as an equal partner - must be protected.

Now that these rights are being challenged in America, it is certainly necessary to return to the American ideal that working people must have the right to organise and enforce themselves in a free and open society.
As Reverend Martin Luther King Jr. said 50 years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Today, everyone knows that the unions have not diminished the nation's strength, but have expanded it.
They have increased the standard of living of millions of people, created a market for industry and raised production to an unsuspected level.
Those who attack the union forget these simple truths, but history remembers them.
History is not forgotten, and neither should we.
The formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of the protection of civil rights to prevent discrimination in the organisation of trade unions - is very late.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis are restoring ideals that raised America and made it the true promise of democracy.
The judge temporarily blocked the law that could have shut down all the abortion clinics in Louisiana.
The federal judge temporarily blocked the Louisian law on Sunday, which, according to lawyers, would probably close all five abortion clinics in the state.

A regulation enacted by the signature of Louisian Governor Bobby Jindal in June, which is due to enter into force on 1 September, would require doctors performing abortions to have the right to receive a patient in a hospital within 30 miles of their practice.
The judge's order means that doctors may temporarily continue to carry out legal abortions and, in the meantime, they must obtain this authorisation.
© The proposing party will be able to legally operate and, in the meantime, obtain a permit, standing in the order of federal judge John deGravelles.
The hearing will be scheduled within one month so that the judge can issue a more permanent resolution concerning the law.
Activists for the right to abortion welcomed the resolution, which is the last in a series of similar measures, and said that it would give doctors more time to obtain permission.

Tonight's decision ensures that women in Louisiana are safe from a sneaky law to deprive them of their health and their rights, announced by Nancy Northup, President and Executive Director of the Reproductive Rights Centre, which, on behalf of three out of five clinics, has sought to block the law.
It was not clear whether the decision also concerns doctors from two clinics that were not among the plaintiffs, and they also apply for this authorisation.
Louisiana is among the eleven states that have passed similar laws, and the courts in Alabama and Mississippi have declared such provisions unconstitutional.
The key parts of the Texas law that would close most of the remaining clinics in the state would be blocked by a federal judge on Friday.

Fighters for women's rights to abortion, along with the Association of American Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and the American Medical Association, claim that the need to have such permission places requirements on doctors that are not medically necessary.
Opponents opposed the fact that measures aimed at protecting women's health, and some also welcomed the fact that clinics would be closed due to measures.
The reproductive rights centre indicated that only one abortion doctor is authorised in Louisiana.
If all doctors in the state were forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would also stop performing the procedure out of fear of his safety, said the group.
In response, the Louisiana authorities stated that they would not punish the abortion doctors while waiting to process the application for rights.
Due to late diagnosis and poor availability of treatment kills ovarian cancer more often in rural areas
Angelina Jolie and her brother James released a video of their deceased mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in Australian countryside are at greater risk of dying from ovarian cancer than their counterparts in the city.
Researchers analysed medical records of more than 1100 Australians diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found that only 35 percent of five years after diagnosis lived.

The head of research, Susan Jordan, of the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute, reported that women in rural and remote areas of the state were about twenty percent more likely to die during the study than women in urban areas.
SMALL STUDIES: New medicines can slow down lung and ovarian cancer
Researchers followed women during seven years of treatment.
Dr. Jordan said that the chances of survival affected the age of women at the time of diagnosis, type of ovarian cancer, other existing diseases and socio-economic status.
The lowest survival rate occurred in older women who were diagnosed with cancer at an advanced stage.
Women in rural and remote areas of the state were about twenty percent more likely to die during the study than in women in urban areas.

Although the study was not designed to determine why women living outside the city were more likely to die of ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan claims that factors may be late diagnosis and poor availability of treatment.
© The disease is best treated by gynecooncologists who usually reside in larger cities, she said.

Despite improving remote medical services to overcome the barrier in the form of distance, the doctor suggested that it would help strengthen the transport service that allows specialists to treat women closer to their homes, and programs to support people who are treated far from their family and friends.

Dr. Jordan stated that the study revealed that the long-term survival of women with ovarian cancer is low regardless of the geographical location, which emphasizes the need for better treatment and prevention programs.
Research funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer cancer will be published by the Medical Journal of Australia today.
In March 2012, young mother Elisha Neave of Gold Coast was diagnosed with aggressive ovarian cancer at her age of 33.
Garden centers regret a reduction in the number of homeowners

According to the HTA study published by the Financial Times, the decline associated with the extraordinary decline in homeowners under the age of 35 could lead to the fact that when today's young generation of consumers reaches the main age group of gardeners, garden centres will lose up to £10 million a year.
According to the report, on average 55 percent of the amount that people living in their own homes spend on their gardens.

As other factors threatening the sector, which earns an estimated £5 billion a year, the increase in the number of people living in very urbanized areas where there are no gardens, the liking of pavement instead of front gardens used as a parking area and the shrinking size of gardens.
In the area of Great London, where the share of homeowners has fallen from 61 percent to 43 percent over six years, the lowest expenditure on gardening products in Britain is due to one household.
HTA and the Royal Gardening Society have stated that housing in a sublease or lack of space does not mean that humans cannot grow plants.
Guy Barter, the main garden advisor for RHS, said: ©The tenants are very popular in growing plants in pots - when they move, they can take the plants with them.

The HTA report revealed that the golden age of the garden retail sector was between 1997 and 2005 and was the result of a higher share of homeowners and economic prosperity lasting from the 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted higher sales this year due to better weather, which came after adverse conditions in March and April.
When the Eastern dictator preaches democracy.

After Putin at his youth organization's convention, which reminds me most of all of it Hitlerjugend, was ravaged by atomic weapons and basically made it clear to everyone that he didn't care about their views, he gave us a lecture today on democracy.
However, I have a feeling that the current regime in Russia shows many features of the fascist state.
The great nations have one thing in common, and that is that they can be mastered both by the tense nationalism and by the fact that the inferiority complex can transform into imperialist appetites.
Time seems to pass in the east differently than in the west.
While the Western world thought that the war over Europe was long gone, in the East, it thinks that they have been overlooked for a long time and must regain their international position.
Such a mood and frustration ruled Germany in the 1930s, just before the Nazis took power and then followed an explosion of nationalism unlike today's situation in Russia.

And then the very same cult of a strong leader, the beating of journalists, the destruction of uncomfortable political opponents, discrimination against minorities and homosexuals, that is indeed quite similar.
Vladimír Putin and certainly a large part of the Russians miss the time when Russia ruled half the world and the second part shook before them.

Probably Western politicians caused it themselves, maybe little was patting Vladimir on the shoulders, maybe not inviting him where he wanted to go and maybe underestimating him, and he just acted like a typical Russian man.
He made a house call, pretended that he didn't really want to go anywhere and sharpened knives at home.
Now he's decided to take back the lost positions.
He's gonna start slow, he's got time.
He's probably in charge of life, so where would he rush to?
He trampled the Caucasus, now he trampled the Ukrainians, then the Dwarves of the Baltics are next.
They've been biting a Russian bear in a fur coat long enough.
I'm sure China will notice that, too, who's jumping a little too much, and she's definitely looking for the far east.
And those Germans are pissed off about Vladimir, too, how well they're doing, and that's what we gave them when they were 45.
How about a new Novorosiji in Karlovy Vary?
That would be a base and there's plenty of ours, and how they're being squeezed in and they're already trying to tear down any of them.
I mean, our veterans are gonna remember how they were in Czechoslovakia.
I mean, their Prime Minister Gospodin Sobotka, he's so soft, he can be peeled like onions, and I can eat their whole EU.
It would be so much fun to get them to jump on the big Russia.
They need to be reminded of where their place is.
And as detonators, we'll use our comrades who live in their territory.
There's enough Russians everywhere, and when they say they're being oppressed, they're just being oppressed, and we don't leave it that way, we protect them.
And the Russian will rule again, for what else is he born to do.
After all, Europe is good as a preposition for which proud Ivan can dance Cossack.
Turkey subpoenaed an American diplomat for a spy report
The Turkish Foreign Minister has called the highest-ranking American diplomat in the country to explain the report on American and British spy activities in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bulent said that the US charge d'affaires and Turkish civil servants discussed the report on Monday.

German magazine Der Spiegel and Internet magazine The Intercept stated that Turkey was a priority target of the US and British intelligence services, according to documents provided by a former US National Security Agency analyst.
According to the Turkish media, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan countered the importance of the report and stated that all major states were watching each other.
The earlier report, according to which the German intelligence service also focused on Ankara, provoked a more bitter reaction in the Turkish government.

The creators of Game of Thrones are currently filming episodes of the fifth order of the iconic series.
At the same time, they boasted about how the fourth row tricks were created.
The most visible are computer modifications of the series environment and mass scene, when the troop becomes a giant army of the famous Daenerys.
Director of Magaluf Police Charged with Corruption
On Friday, the complainants submitted evidence of blackmail by police officers and city hall officials in Calvia's Autonomous Region to the Office of the Mallor State Prosecutor.
The head of police in Calvia on the holiday island of Mallorca was arrested after charges brought against businessmen and bar owners in the infamous party district of Magaluf.

Chief Inspector José Antonio Navarro was taken into custody after he was accused of corruption by several entrepreneurs from Punta Ballen, a street where most of the bars and nightclubs in Magaluf are located.

According to the Internet daily Mallorca Diario, on Friday, the complainants submitted evidence of blackmail to the prosecutor of the Mallorca Corruption Office on the part of police officers and civil servants of the City Hall in the Calvia municipality.
Two other local police officers were arrested by the Spanish state police for connection to corruption charges, and together with Navarro, the judge will question them.
The Spanish national daily ABC quoted disgruntled night business owners, according to which preferential treatment by public officials has a serious impact on their business.
© It is no longer about making money, but about surviving, said one of the entrepreneurs in court.
Don't mess with our livelihood.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf made it to the main pages of magazines around the world after a video of 18-year-old British tourists appeared on YouTube who gave oral sex to 24 men during a bar tour.
Since then, island authorities have been trying to oversee drunkards and rioters in the ranks of holiday parties in Magaful by reducing the number of infamous alcohol tours in bars.
In addition, the Playhouse Club, where there was an oral sex event, was forced to close for a year and together with Carnage's tour operators to pay a fine of 55,000 euros (73,000 dollars).

The Magalauf tourist resort, which is popular mainly with the British, was also witnessed by many alcohol accidents including the fashion wave known as the balconing, where people jump from one balcony to the other or from the balcony to the hotel pool.
The first spring day marked by rain and storms that had an impact on the flight at Adelaide airport
JARO brought South South Australia an ice surprise, came with a heavy rain and a violent wind, which seriously hit the airport in Adelaide.
Another 5 mm of precipitation is due in the city until nine o'clock in the evening and another 6.6 mm will fall during the night on Sunday.

The last rain was introduced together with a few short showers connected with the storm and wind gusts, which began eight o'clock in the evening and brought almost 4 mm of precipitation within about ten minutes.
After a few early doses of spring came after the winter last week, on Monday the temperature in the city fell again to just 15,8 °C.
Storm weather is believed to have contributed to the delayed arrival of Virgin Airlines from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The plane was supposed to land shortly after 19:30, but it was hit by a change in the speed or direction of the wind and was forced to delay the landing.
Wind gusts at Adelaide Airport at that time reached the ground speed of about 50 km/h.
Flight data showed that the plane had to drop the second landing and finally landed at about 8:40 p.m.
The delay of the aircraft subsequently led to delays in other flights, including Emirates flight from Dubai and Qantas flight from Sydney.
According to the forecast, the temperature in Adelaide will reach a maximum of 16 °C on Tuesday and one or two showers may appear.
Israel's Children Return to School After the Gaza War

Thousands of Israeli children from areas near the Gaza Strip returned to school on Monday after spending the summer in bomb shelters, while during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, rockets and mortars attacked their homes.
The beginning of the school brought a sense of joy and excitement to communities in southern Israel, but signs of struggle are still evident.
In Ashdod, a city in the south of the country, the workers of the preschool, hit by a rocket, removed the remains of shrapnel from the wall and slowly expect the children to return.
© We are a little scared, but otherwise we look forward to it, said Ronit Bart, resident of Kibucu Saad and English teacher at local school.
A lot of kids in this area really need to get back to the routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart revealed that it's a little strange to go back to school at once.
© We've had some hard times and we haven't left the house at all, she said.
Kibuc, located near the Gaza border, visited President Reuben Rivlin to offer his support to the residents.

Until the ceasefire last week ended the war, thousands of residents of border settlements such as Saad remained inside their homes or left their homes and set off to safer areas away from Gaza to escape rockets and mortars.
Many Nachal Oz residents, a village near the Gaza border, in which a missile from a Palestinian mortar killed a four-year-old boy, hesitate to return.
The Minister of Education said that about 12 families still haven't returned.
Their children were temporarily placed in alternative schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a city on the border with Gaza, which was heavily hit by Palestinian fire.
He encouraged the children to study diligently and added: "We will provide you with education and security. ©
Israel and Hamas agreed last Tuesday on an unlimited amount of time.

The cease-fire led to the immediate end of the fighting, but it did not solve key problems such as Hamas's demand to end the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of airports and ports in Gaza.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the return of the bodies of two soldiers killed in the war.
A new round of indirect negotiations is expected to start later this month in Egypt.
According to estimates by Palestinians and the UN, more than 2,100 Palestinians died in the war, three quarters of which were civilians and at least 494 children.
Israel is questioning these figures and estimates that at least half of the killed were radicals, even though there is no clear evidence for these claims.
66 soldiers and six civilians died on the Israeli side, including a Thai worker.
Hamas and other radicals from Gaza fired during battles on Israeli cities mainly in the south of the country 4 591 missiles and missiles from mortars.
The Israeli army, in turn, made more than 5,000 air raids and other attacks.
Israel's attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in Gaza, and an estimated 250,000 people hid in a hundred UN schools that turned into a provisional shelter.
Because of tens of thousands of people who are still in hiding, school officials postponed the beginning of the school year due to the ongoing struggles last week.

I hope that they will soon open the school so that we can complete our education as well as Jewish children and other children in the world, said Mohammad Amara, a 13 - year - old boy from school in Gaza's largest city.
I stand by your willow.

David isn't here yet, but Sparta had some problems last week, there were more players, and David probably still has a little bit of problems.
But we want him to be here and be okay as soon as possible," said Pavel Vrba to the journalists.

The other players are fine.

On Sunday night Vrba called as the last player of Spartan backup Lukáš Váhu.
He admitted that this was not an easy decision, other midfielders were also considered.
I made a decision based on the fact that Luke is a prospective player who is 25 years old.
The decision-making was very difficult, but I stand by it," Vrba said to Vách.
What about Shural?
Let's see what happens to Latatoo.
It is not possible that the nomination could still change in case of health problems.
On the weekend, for example, Liberec's Josef Šural, who gave a hat trick, flashed with great performance.
Of course there are players who have recently shown form.
Let's see how David Lafata's doing.
In the event that it cannot be available on Wednesday, I do not claim that I cannot dominate any of the players who have taken an interest in the Czech league," Vrba said.

This afternoon there will be a representation of training in Strahov, on Tuesday there will be classic pre-game training before duel with the USA on Letná, which will be open to fans and followed by a signing.
The game with Americans is played on Wednesday at 20:15 and the national team in it will seek premier victory under the Willow.
In the previous three preparatory games, he played two draws and once lost.
The qualifying match with the Netherlands is then on the agenda on 9 September at 20:45.
Pesice is going to Italy on the Netherlands
The willow is glad to have more time for training than previous meetings.
It is an advantage when you have players eight days and you can rehearse with them certain things that maybe we didn't have so much time before.
We will now be able to concentrate only on preparing ourselves for the Netherlands as best we can," Vrba praised.
The Dutch will present themselves in Italy before the match in Prague on Thursday and the duel will be personally watched by former temporary coach Josef Pešice.
He'll give us the information from the game.
But it's not just about him, we're gonna have a game and we're gonna have a video game and we're gonna talk about him.
A new coach is coming to the Netherlands, we will see what changes will be there," Vrba said to the bronze medalists from the recent World Championship.
According to the very monitored statistics, the prices of flats in the winter period have increased most in the last seven years.
According to the index of the value of flats in the Australian capital RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic increased housing prices by 1.1 % in August, the agency reported on Monday.
The increase led to an overall increase in June, July and August to 4,2%, the highest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase has risen to 10.9 percent, more than twice as much per year until August 2013, but the profit has not been evenly distributed in the country.
RP Research Director Data Tim Lawless stated that Sydney and Melbourne are leading the market.
RP figures Data show that housing prices in Sydney increased by 16.1 percent last year, while prices in Melbourne increased by 11.7 percent.
Among the other strongest markets were Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, with prices rising between five and six percent on average.
On the other side of the scale, Canberra was placed, which was damaged by a government-ordered reduction in expenditure and where prices increased by only 1.4 per cent during the year.
Lawless said that now that spring has begun, the number of properties will increase for sale in the coming months, which will be a real test for the market.

In view of the continuing high level of auction sales, generally high sales speed and low interest rates, it is likely that the housing value will increase even further over the next three months, he said.
My father never hugged me.
He never told me I love you
Henry was born in 1958 as one of the seven children of Jamaican immigrants in Dudley, the Midlands.
With his father, who died when Henry was 19, who worked at the factory, they had a colder relationship.
Henry is trying comedy, Rudy's Rare Records, which is partly based on an imaginary conversation with his father and which is part of the Radio 4 series.
Soundtrack is a mixture of reggae and rap and melody is optimistic.
But Henry had to deal with some unpleasant childhood memories.
After his mother's death, Henry went through some serious therapy, and now he's thinking about his relationship with his father.
He knew so little about him.
You've never seen his face, you've only heard his voice: stop with the racket.
Leave your sister alone.
Move!
I want to watch cricket.
My older brothers Seymour and Hilton - when I was a kid, they were adults - went to a bar with him and discussed things like the shape of a glass of beer or the beauty of a cricket strike.
I've never talked to him like that.
Most of my life, he was a serious guy in a corner reading newspapers.
Henry recently visited Dudley's foundry, and although the conditions were better than in his father's day, he looked into what life must have been like for him.
There's a little bit more light in there today, but it's still dark, smoky, grim labyrinth, where the flames explode, and there's a lot of smoke and soot.
My dad always got in the tub and just lay there, and then I could hear him slowly starting to sing for himself because he was washing the foundry off.
When I was passing by, I realized he'd been doing this for years to support his family, and I started to appreciate him more.
Even so, Henry had a childhood without parental love.
Daddy didn't hug anyone, he didn't say I love you.
When my mom was sick and dying, we started thinking, "I love you, I love you, I love you."
His daughter Billie, who she has with Dawn French, allowed him to experience the love he lacked as a child.
Can you stop with the "I love you" thing now?
Don't hug me all the time!
Dad, I'm 22!
Dawn French.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She's a great mom.
French, who he's been married to for 25 years, is still good friends.
Dawn's nice.
Why shouldn't Dawn and I be friends?
She's a great mom.
Henry's own mother had diabetes.
It was one of the things that killed her.
So when I was very, very overweight and there were signs of diabetes, the doctor said to me, "You have to make a radical change."
So I started going to the big fitness center, and I also had to go on a drastic diet to get rid of the symptoms.
It's very hard.
And tiring.
Nobody wants to eat carrots.
A change in the direction of Henry's career may be reflected in his elegant, short-cut beard.
After receiving recognition from critics for his Othell, he plunged into the theatre.
A comedy full of mistakes and August Wilson's fences followed.
It's a different experience than sitcoms and comedies that filled his hectic work life.
He started when he was 16 and worked at the factory.
DJ noticed him on stage parody someone and wrote about him in the New Faces talent show.
His TV career began in the mid-70's: I was the only black impersonator/comic on television for a long time.
He learned as he marched.
Besides having to be noticed by the public, I also had to learn how to make up working jokes, be a star and perform on television, and that was really hard.
Lenny in New Faces in 1975

Kenya registers civil servants to shine a light on non-existent employees
Kenya began with a biometric registration of all its civil servants to try to remove non-existent employees from the government's payroll.
According to the government's statement, employees who do not register in the next two weeks will cease to receive a salary.
The government thinks thousands of people get paid even after they left the state service.
After taking office in 2013, President Uhuru Kenyatta promised to prevent corruption in the state administration.
The audit carried out this year showed that the state was losing at least one million dollars a month (£700,000) on the salaries of non-existent employees and further abuse of official authority.

The government suspects that the salaries are still being placed on bank accounts after the death of the employee or after the employee leaves the state administration, the BBC reporter from Nairobi, Wanyama Chebusiri, reported.
All civil servants must attend identification centres in the next two weeks, where their data will be recorded biometrically, as stated in the Government's statement.
He also says that anyone who does not arrive without sufficient apology will be removed from the payroll.

This measure will contribute significantly to the financing of the real public service staff and will also be used to clear the payroll at both levels of the government, thus solving the problem of non-existent employees, told Anne Waiguru, Secretary of the Ministry of Development and Planning.

Some of them were involved in the December investigation into corruption, which focused on government officials, including four ministers.
In July, several Turkish police officers were arrested for alleged organizing a criminal gang and phone eavesdropping.

According to Berkeley, the housing market is returning to normal.
One of London's most prominent developers warned that the housing market in southeastern England had returned to normal levels of activity.
Living in the capital was subject to high demand and rising prices, and widespread concern about the credit bubble caused the Bank of England to introduce mortgage limits in June.

Tony Pidgley, the founder and chairman of the developer's company for demanding Berkeley clients, said on Monday: "Since the beginning of the current financial year, the market has returned from the top in 2013 to the normal level of transactions.' It adds that it provides a stable environment for operation.
The London housing market was doing well during the fall because buyers from abroad flooded into the capital.
According to the cadastral office data, prices in the city jumped by 18.5% last year alone, far ahead of an average of 6.5% in England and Wales.
The average sales prices of private, affordable and student housing from Berkeley increased by about a fifth last year and climbed to £423,000 at the end of April.

However, because of the strengthening pound, it has not been so attractive for foreign buyers of London's property in recent months - some of them have also been intimidated by the introduction of new real estate taxes and talk about possible social taxes, with which politicians came before the parliamentary elections of next May.

Last week, Foxtons, a London real estate agency, warned that the April revision of the mortgage market, which introduced stricter rules on loans, would slow the pace of market growth in real estate sales and prices during the second half of the year.
The new Bank of England data on Monday showed a decline in the amount of approved mortgages in July, suggesting that the housing market is calming down.

Hamptons International, another real estate agency, has reduced home prices already to 3% on the basis that home prices have already started to decline, forecasting the increase in London property prices for 2015.
According to WA Ellis, the volume of transactions in London's most expensive neighborhoods, such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington, fell by a quarter each year.

Production in the euro area is at a 13-month minimum
The growth in production in the euro area slowed to 13 months, according to a closely monitored survey in August.
The final index of purchasing managers in the euro area (PMI) from June 51.8 fell to 50.7 in August.
A number higher than 50 indicates expansion.
New orders have decreased and the factories have damaged the growing tensions between the EU and Russia due to Ukraine.
The figures come from the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday.
Markets will want a clear plan from the bank on how to deal with delayed eurozone recovery and the threat of deflation with inflation stagnating to 0.3 percent.

There has been speculation that Mario Draghi's director may have indicated this week that he is considering quantitative eurozone easing, similar to what the United Kingdom and the US joined during the financial crisis.

Although at least some growth is better than no growth, the braking effect that the growing economy and geopolitical uncertainty on producers are becoming increasingly visible, said Rob Dobson, the chief economist of Markit.
Germany's production PMI, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to 11 months minimum 51.4.
In the second largest economy of the zone, France, the PMI fell to 46.9.
There is concern about France, and Italy has gone from expansion to stagnation.
Signs that the driving force of growth in the most important industrial areas in Germany, Spain and also the Netherlands has disappeared are also not very reassuring, said Dobson.
Industrial slowdown is likely to add fuel to the fire to analysts expecting the implementation of other monetary or tax incentives.
One positive report came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI has risen to 57.3, the highest level since the end of 1999.
Howard Archer, the chief economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The best you can say about the August production overview of shopping managers is that it shows that the sector is still growing.'

He added: Eurozone producers currently have a very difficult life because increasing geopolitical tensions - especially between Russia and Ukraine - add even more uncertainty to the increasingly difficult conditions in many countries.
This increasing uncertainty has proven to have affected trade - particularly consumer confidence, which is likely to cause some orders to be postponed or even cancelled, especially expensive ones.
He stated that it seems even more likely that the ECB will eventually have to implement some form of quantitative easing, although we expect it to be limited.

If the camera has a bracketing mode that makes a series of images with slightly different exposure variances, take advantage of it.
Stay close to the surface.
With a deeper dive of light, it decreases significantly.

China's leaders presented Sunday's decision as a democratic breakthrough because it allows Hong Kong to vote directly, but the decision also makes it clear that China's leaders are firmly in control of the nomination process of a committee that is strictly controlled by Beijing.

The decision came after the summer months, which recorded one of Hong Kong's largest and most watched protests in several years.

The authorities in Hong Kong have been preparing for Beijing's announcement for days and have strengthened the protection of the government's headquarters on Sunday and have deployed policemen and barricades.

Oral agreement with an employer can be a problem
Unfortunately, you didn't get a doctor's certificate of incapacity to work, which serves as evidence for the organization that you can't perform work duties for health reasons.
Moreover, you did not immediately notify your employer.
The agreement subsequently took place that the given days would be registered as a vacation, but the agreement only took place orally.
Although the Labour Code does not impose an obligation to have the employer's consent to receive leave confirmed in writing, in practice this procedure has proved to be successful.
If there is only an oral agreement, you do not have confirmation of the agreement.

Later, the alleged consent to the taking of leave, as in your case, may be denied and absent from work assessed as a long-term unforgivable absence, thus a reason for immediate termination of employment under Section 53 of the Labour Code.
In the event of a legal dispute over the agreement with your employer, you are so lacking evidence.
However, the employment relationship with you has not been cancelled in accordance with § 53, only you have given the given days in the credit sheet as an unforgivable absence.

Unforgivable absence in the credit sheet does not have the same consequences as § 53 (e.g. the impossibility of taking material security in unemployment), yet the possibility of finding a new job is difficult.

We recommend that you visit the doctor again and have it confirmed in writing that there was an accident, as a result of which you were unable to work (this is not a so-called "incapacity"; it is only a medical certificate).
When looking for a new job, you can present this document and explain the situation.

In practice, it is appropriate not to underestimate both the issuing of a written medical certificate of incapacity for work or the early notification of the employer or the request of written consent to the taking of leave.
This will avoid any complications.

The fired employee took revenge, bought laptops and sold them to the company.
A disheartened employee after his release bought computers on the company and then sold them.
He spent the money he received before the police were apprehended.
Within a short period of time, a man bought a total of 16 computers in twelve cases for more than 200 thousand crowns.

Prison guards in Bulgaria are organizing protests
Hundreds of prison officials throughout Bulgaria attended a national protest meeting before the Ministry of Justice in Sofia's capital.
At a peaceful demonstration, they reiterated their request to re-establish the original working conditions that have recently changed.
The list of requirements to be discussed with the interim Minister of Justice, Hristo Ivanov, includes higher salaries.
The overseers symbolically protested the new working hours of the month and demanded a return to the original twenty - four - hour shifts.
Although the prison guards' unions and representatives of the Ministry of Justice met, they did not agree, the Bulgarian State Radio (BNR) informed.
©The negotiations are still ongoing, said BNR Head of the General Directorate of Prison Service Rosen Zhelyazkov.
Members of the Federation of Workers' Trade Organisations at the Ministry of the Interior are also expected to join the protests of the prison service staff.
Why the universe can have more dimensions and we can't see them
Physicists don't usually write bestsellers, but Brian Green of Columbia University hit a black one in 1999.

His book The Elegant Universe has become the most accessible way for laymen to break into the thicket of problems that many theoretical physicists are dealing with today - an attempt to unite two perfectly functioning but mutually incompatible discoveries of the 20th century: quantum theory and general relativity theory.
One reason for the success of the Elegant Universe is undoubtedly that it is not a boring story in the case of searching for a unified physical theory.

The physics fundamental problem between two key theories (for at the moment our universe is de facto divided into two worlds with different laws) was solved and solved so imaginatively that it was worth telling even laymen.
In addition, Greene coped with the complex material so freshly and captivatingly that he cannot be blamed for how much interesting he did not include in his book.
Moreover, he corrected his "mistake " mostly in the next two books: The Structure of the Universe and the Hidden Reality.

Apparently, even the author wouldn't object if his book became obsolete faster, but the fact is that even after 15 years, the elegant universe still provides almost everything essential that an informed layman with ambition should understand the world's importance to this important part of theoretical physics.

It is quite likely that in the coming years it will still be a little more lively in this area (need to say that the LHC accelerator will finally go to "full gas"), and so it is a good time to enter Greene without violence the doors of the world of modern physics.
How many dimensions can our universe have?
Surely the idea that our universe may have more than three spatial dimensions may sound foolish, fantastic, strange, or mystic.
Yet it is concrete and completely acceptable.
To understand this, let us turn our eyes away from the universe as a whole to something more groundless, namely a long and thin garden hose for watering.
Imagine stretching a hundred-meter garden hose from one side of the canyon to the other and watching the whole scenery from a half-mile distance (as in the picture and on the following page).
From such a distance, you can easily notice a long hose stretched in a horizontal direction, but if you don't have a sharp vision, you hardly recognize the thickness of the hose.
Given its great distance from the hose, you would think that an ant forced to live on the hose has only one dimension in which it can walk: the left-right dimension along the hose.
When someone asks you where the ant was at the moment, you answer it only with one indication: the distance of the ant from the left (or right) end of the hose.
All we're saying is that from a half-mile distance, a long piece of hose looks like a one-dimensional object.
In the real world, the hose is thick.
If we expand everything, we will suddenly see a second dimension - in the shape of a circle waving a hose.

In such an enlarged view it is clear that the ant can actually move in two independent dimensions: in the already well-known left-right dimension after the length of the hose, but also in the "dimension in/against the direction of clockwise movement" around the circular section of the hose.
You begin to understand that to determine the position of a small ant you have to enter two numbers: how far away it is from the end of the hose and where it is on the circle waving the hose.
This reflects the fact that the surface of the hose is two-dimensional (note. Experts will note that this chapter focuses purely on the fault theory of strings.
He discusses non-disturbing aspects in chapters 12 and 13.).

The surface of the hose is two-dimensional: one long longitudinal dimension is represented by a straight arrow, the dimension in the direction of the circuit, marked with a circular arrow, is short and rolled.
However, there is a clear difference between these two dimensions.
The dimension along the hose is long and easily visible.
The dimensions of the hose wrapping circuit are short, "spooled" and worse noticeable.
In order to realize the existence of a circular dimension, we had to examine the hose with a significantly better resolution.
The example illustrates an important feature of spatial dimensions.
That they divide into two groups.
They can either be large, large, and therefore directly visible, or, on the contrary, small, rolled up and much worse observable.
Of course, in this case, we did not just beat ourselves up to uncover the "wrapped" dimension of the hose thickness.
All you had to do was get a telescope to help.
But if the hose were thinner - like a hair or a capillary - we would only reveal the coiled dimension with great effort.
In 1919, Kaluza sent Einstein his article in which he came up with the amazing idea that space geometry of the universe could have more than three known dimensions for all of us.

Kaluza justified his radical claim by providing an elegant and convincing framework in which Einstein's general relativity and Maxwell's electromagnetic theory can be woven into a single, unified conceptual structure.
The question immediately arises as to how this observation of Kaluz goes together with the obvious fact that we see just three dimensions of space.

The answer, which Kaluza quietly assumed between the lines and which was clearly stated and clarified by Swedish mathematician Oskar Klein in 1926, stands and falls with the claim that spatial geometry of our universe can have both large and rolled dimensions.
This means that, like the dimensions in the direction of the length of the hose, our universe has a large, vast and easily visible three dimensions, the existence of which we realize at any moment.

But by analogy with the circular circuit of the garden hose, the universe can have additional dimensions, firmly rolled into space so tiny that they have remained hidden even from our most perfect experimental apparatus.
To get a clearer idea of the nature of Kaluz's remarkable design, let's stay with the hose for a little while longer.
Imagine drawing a relatively dense series of circles on the circumference of the hose in black color.
The hose still looks like a thin one-dimensional line.
With a telescope, the drawing will reveal the coiled dimension even easier, because we will see the motif from Figure 2.
We can clearly see that the surface of the hose is two-dimensional, with one dimension large and almost unlimited and with the other short and circular.

Kaluza and Klein came up with the idea that our universe has a similar structure, but apart from one small circular dimension, it has three large spatial dimensions, which combined four space dimensions.
It is difficult to draw an object with too many dimensions.
To help our imagination a little bit, let us note the illustration in Figure 3; it shows two large dimensions and one small circular dimension.
In the picture, we enlarge the view of the geometry of the space similar to that of the hose surface.
Each following level represents a huge increase in the geometry of space from the previous level.
Our universe may have an additional dimension (seeing them on the fourth level of magnification) if the rolls are small enough space; this explains that we have not yet directly observed them.
The square network represents the commonly known "big" dimension, while the circle represents a new, tiny and rolled dimension.

Just like strings of threads in a densely woven carpet, even these circles exist in every place of the usual dimensions - we only drew them into intersections in a square network because of their graphics.

The background of Figure 4 shows the commonly known structure of the space - the ordinary world around us - in such common measures as meters, illustrated by the side of a small square in a square network.
In each picture below, focus on a small area of the picture before; enlarge it to become visible.
At first, nothing special happens, as we see at the first few levels of enlargement.

However, if we go beyond the microscopic properties of the geometry of space further - to the fourth level of magnification in Figure 3 - we will suddenly see a new circle of a coiled dimension similar to a looped thread in a densely woven piece of carpet.

Kaluza and Klein came up with the idea that an additional circular dimension exists at every point in the direction of large dimensions similar to the hose of the circular circumference at each point of its length.
For the sake of clarity, we have only drawn the circular dimension in some, regularly distributed points.
Figure 4 of Kaluz and Klein's idea of the microscopic structure of space geometry summarizes.
Similarity with the hose is obvious, although we also record important differences.
First, the universe has three large, far-reaching spatial dimensions (of which we have drawn only two), while the hose has only one large dimension.
The more important difference is that we're talking about the spatial geometry of the universe itself, not just some object inside the universe, like our hose.
But the basic idea is the same.
If the additional round dimension is extremely miniature, recognize it - as well as the circular circumference of the hose - is much harder than to see the apparent, large and large dimensions.
If the size of the additional dimension is small enough, it will actually be beyond the power of our most modern enlargement tools.
But most importantly, the additional dimension is not just a round bump inside the normal dimensions, as the two-dimensional illustration falsely suggests.
The circular dimension is a new dimension that exists at each point of three common large dimensions.
It is the dimension of the remaining three dimensions independent as are the dimensions of the top-down, left-right and front-back independent (and perpendicular) each other.

A sufficiently small ant could move in all four dimensions and to determine its position we would need four figures, apart from the three usual positions in the circular dimension; if we count the time, then data five, in any case one more than we would normally expect.
Are you intrigued?
Brian Greeen's elegant universe can be purchased here on books.idnes.cz.
Price for e-book is 149,- CZK.

To our surprise, then, we find that even though we are aware of the existence of only three dimensions of space, Kaluz and Klein's reasoning shows that this does not exclude the existence of additional crappy dimensions if they are small enough.
The universe may have more dimensions than we can see with the naked eye.
How small should they be?
The state-of-the-art technical equipment can detect the structures of a billionth of a billionth of a meter.
We can barely observe smaller rolled-up dimensions.
In 1926, Klein combined Kaluz's original idea with a few ideas from the just-born quantum mechanics.
His calculations indicated that an additional circular dimension could be about one Planck length, which is far beyond the discernment of today's instruments.
Since then, physicists have called the possibility of additional small spatial dimensions of Kaluz-Klein theory.

Genetic disorders are often misdiagnosed
A woman from Britain describes how she thought she was going to die after a bad diagnosis for many years.
After being diagnosed with another disease, Karin Rodgers spent most of her teens believing that she had only a few years to live.
In fact, it was Charcot-Marie-Tooth syndrome (CMT) - a group of hereditary disorders that damage nerves outside the brain and spine.
CMT UK's charity said that bad diagnosis is a common problem among people with CMT, because very little is known about diseases.
In the United Kingdom, approximately 23,000 people suffer from CMT, which may manifest symptoms in the area of motor skills such as muscle weakness, clumsy walking and twisted toes.
In the affected patients, numbness or pain may also occur, this condition is incurable and progressive, which means that symptoms get worse over time.
When Rodgers was 13, she thought she was suffering from Freidreich's Fa - a disease that had a very bad prognosis.

Entrepreneurs in Maryland and Virginia together for the fiscal year 2013 made $27.6 billion into government and local treasury, which is 3.8 percent higher than the $26.6 billion collected in 2012.

Virginia, with 28 percent, has the smallest tax revenue from business in proportion.

A recent increase in business tax revenue cannot be attributed only to the healing real estate market.

The trade tax paid by small businessmen as a personal income tax - the cost increase compensation structure by increasing prices, according to which most companies are organized - in D.C., Maryland and Virginia increased by 20 percent to 2.4 billion dollars last year, much faster than other taxes.

However, it is certain that potential attackers had plenty of time to gain access to different accounts before publishing this tool.
iCloud users should therefore change their password associated with Apple ID for preventive reasons.
The length of the password, not its complexity, is important.

If you want to back up explicit photos or any other sensitive content online, first encrypt files before uploading.

That's it.

I'm afraid so.

There are no indications that the Ukrainian army is committing anything like this.
We have an idea of the number of executions, but I can't give the numbers, and I don't want to.

Every time I cross the line of the war front, I am without a gun and show soldiers or armed men loose arms.

In his opinion, such a state should not even exist.

A.cz: Speaking of characters - on the Ukrainian TV talk show, you called your Prime Minister Arsenius Jaceňuk a weak, clueless and tired "leader" who would do best if he left quickly.
For those three hundred meters of walking, I'm always at least five times scared.

The Norwegian Cruise is approaching the three-billion-dollar purchase of Prestige Cruise

According to sources familiar with the whole matter, Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings s.r.o. (NCHL.O.), the world's third largest cruise operator in the world, has advanced the negotiation of the purchase of Prestige Cruises International Inc. for approximately $3 billion.

The business by Norwegian Cruise, a company with a market value of $ 6.8 billion, which competes with the greater competition of Royal Carrebian Cruises s.r.o. (RCL.N) and Carnival Corp (CCL.N), has allowed access to luxury cruise ships Prestige Cruises and rich clients.
The agreement can already be published this week, revealed the source on Sunday, but pointed out that negotiations still need not end successfully.
Owner of Prestige Cruises, a private investment company Apollo Global Management LLC (APO.N), also owns a 20% stake in the Norwegian Cruise.
Sources did not wish to be appointed because the negotiations were not public.
Representatives of Norwegian Cruise and Prestige Cruises did not reply to the comments, spokesperson Apollo refused to comment on the situation.
The Norwegian Cruise, based in Miami, operates 13 cruise ships in North America, the Mediterranean and the Baltic Sea, Central America and the Caribbean.
The company's income in 2013 was $2.57 billion, 13 percent more than in 2012.
Prestige Cruises operates under Oceania and Regent brands, which together own eight cruise ships sailing to Scandinavia, Russia, Mediterranean, North America, Asia, Africa and South America.
In 2013, the company announced sales of $1.2 billion, 6 percent more than in the previous year.
It is expected that the 29 billion segment of cruises will benefit in the coming year from the rise of the middle class in growing economies such as China and India.
Companies compete to become a preferred option for these customers when choosing cruises.
Prestige Cruises registered the first public offer with US regulatory authorities in January 2014.
Apollo has had a majority stake in the company since 2007 since the sale of $850 million.

Norwegian Cruise has existed in its current form since 2000, when it was merged with a cruise operator owned by Genting Bhd (GENT.KL), a consortium of leisure and casino businesses controlled by Malaysian billionaire Lim Kok Thay.
In 2008, Apollo invested one billion dollars in Norwegian Cruise.
Norwegian Cruise launched shares on the stock exchange in January 2013.
According to the registration of regulatory authorities at the end of June, Genting held a share of 28 %, Apollo 20 % and a private investment company TPG Capital LP 8 %.
According to the registration documentation of the first public offer, Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and Norwegian Cruise include a total of 82 percent of the volume of North American passengers.

Putin asks Kiev to open negotiations with Eastern Ukraine on national sovereignty

According to a description of events by Russian newspapers, Russian President Vladimir Putin asked on Sunday for the Ukrainian government to stop the fight against separatists in the east of the country and to immediately open negotiations on the national sovereignty of the isolated areas.

His spokesperson Dmitry Peskov later explained that Putin had no intention of implying that the regions of eastern Ukraine under the control of separatists would become part of Russia, but that their status within Ukraine should be re-evaluated so that the Russian-speaking region would be empowered to protect its rights and interests.

Putin's call to the Kiev government to treat pro-Russian insurgents as equals corresponds to a clear strategy that follows from the outbreak of unrest five months ago: Help the separatists occupy the territory and force the Ukrainian government to grant the newly announced Novoruska effective independence so that instead of the West can join Russia.

In an interview for the first channel of state television Putin condemned Ukrainian military actions to reclaim the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, which in March and April were dominated by separatists after Moscow's annexation of the Crimean Peninsula belonging to Ukraine on 18 March.
The Kremlin and Separatists have recently designated the territory as a "New Russia" or a "New Russia," a term that refers to the famous pre-revolutionary days of the Russian empire.

The Russian press agency Itar-Tass has published Putin's words saying that the prison is an illusion about anyone who believes peace negotiations are on the horizon because Ukrainian politicians launched campaigns before the parliamentary elections on 26 October, while government troops attack civilian populations in areas controlled by separatists.

In the interests of the people living in these areas, we must immediately start meaningful negotiations, not only on legal matters, but also on the political organisation of society and on the status of the state sovereignty of the south-east of Ukraine.

Peskov said that Putin's reference to state sovereignty was meant in the context of broader autonomy, which has been discussed with Kiev's leadership for several months and which is intended to alleviate the concerns of Russian-speaking areas from the threat of cultural and linguistic rights.
Peskov said that only the Ukrainian government can grant the necessary autonomy to the eastern regions.
This is not a matter for discussion between Ukraine and Russia, Peskov said, because it is not a conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but an internal Ukrainian conflict.

The intervention of the spokesman of the Kremlin, who was to correct the incorrect interpretation of Putin's remarks, highlighted Russia's leadership's approach to addressing the uprising of the separatists in the east, which is different from the open cast of Crimea, where most of the two-million-dollar population of origin belongs to ethnic Russians.

Moscow would have much more difficulty anecting Donetsk and Luhansk in the east of Ukraine, since most of the 6.5 million people are not Russians, and public opinion polls that have taken place before the conflict have shown broad support for remaining in Ukraine.

The autonomy discussed by Russian diplomats in international fora would give regional governments in Ukraine the power to determine their own trade agreements and international relations, and thus essentially give the Kremlin effective control over the territory that would link the Russian mainland with Crimea.
The Black Sea Peninsula, annexed five months ago, is the headquarters of the main Russian naval fleet, maritime business facilities and historical coastal resorts.
The areas between Russia's Rostov and Crimea are also a centre of mines, factories and foundries that produce important components for the Russian army.

During his inauguration speech of June 7, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko suggested that Ukrainian legislators - after the new elections - consider changes in the constitution that would give different regions more control over their finances and language status.
But this vision of autonomy differs greatly from that of the Kremlin and separatists, and Moscow is accused of arming and inciting violence.

Putin's last call for Kiev to treat separatists as equals was followed by further insurgents last week after Russian troops and tanks from a previously quiet area along the Azov Sea penetrated eastern Ukraine.

The separatists reinforced by the Russians took control of Novoazovsk so forcefully that the Ukrainian security authorities fear that this is a campaign to occupy strategic coastal territory up to Crimea.

This has accelerated the enormous civilian and military efforts to harden Mariupol, a port with metallurgical jumpsuits of 500,000 inhabitants, between Novoazovsk and the narrow entrance gate to the Crimean Peninsula.

Poroshenko spoke on Saturday at the meeting of the European Union's leaders in Brussels and urged action to prevent further Russian aggression against Ukraine, the former Soviet Republic, which has been independent for the last 23 years.
© We are approaching the point from which there is no return, warned Poroshenko.
There are now thousands of foreign military units and hundreds of foreign tanks in Ukraine.
The EU Summit has not taken any definitive action - leaders are calling for further sanctions against Russia in the event of an unspecified escalation of the Ukrainian crisis.

On Saturday, Colonel Andrij Lysenko, spokesperson for the Ukrainian National Security and Defence Council, told reporters in Kiev that Ukrainian soldiers had to withdraw from their positions in Ilowa after two colonies of Russian armored vehicles and 1 000 military troops broke into the Donetsk region last week to support the besieged separatists.

On Sunday, the first of the 63 reported Ukrainian soldiers who were captured in Ilowa during the Russian invasion were replaced by 10 Russian paratroopers captured a week ago in the interior of Ukraine, reported Lysenko on Sunday.
