de_en: The Prime Ministers of India and Japan met in Tokyo.

India's new Prime Minister Narendra Modi meets his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe in Toko on his first important foreign visit since his election victory in May to discuss economic and security relations.
Mr Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to strengthen economic relations with the world's third largest economic nation.
Plans for stronger nuclear cooperation are at the top of the agenda.
India is also reported to be hoping for a defence cooperation treaty between the two nations.
Police of Karratha arrested 20-year-olds after fast motorcycle hunting
A motorcycle was confiscated after the driver drove it at 125 km/h in a 70 km/h zone and through bushland to escape the police in Bilbara.
Traffic police in Karratha tried to stop a blue motorcycle this morning after watching it leave a gas station on Bathdate Road at 125 km/h.
The police reported that the driver then ignored the stop signals and continued driving on Burgess Road before bouncing into the bushland where the officers lost sight of it.
The motorcycle and a person who corresponded to the driver's description were later seen at a house in the Walcott Way in Bulgarra.
The police of Karratha accuse a 20-year-old man of disregarding a stop signal and ruthless driving.
It is scheduled to appear before the Karratha District Court on 23 September.
The motorcycle was seized and confiscated for three months.
George Webster accused of hotel rapes in Naim and Pitlochry
A man is on trial for the rape of women in two hotels.
George Webster, 28, was read at a hearing by the Glasgow Supreme Court.
He is accused of raping a woman at the Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire, on 7 June 2013.
The charge is that Webster attacked her while she "was unconscious, asleep, and could not signal consent."
Webster is also accused of raping a second woman at the Golf View Hotel in Naim in the Scottish Highlands on May 4, 2014.
Judge Lady Rae set the trial date for 17 November at the Edinburgh Supreme Court.
Returning to the very American ideal of labour rights as human rights
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have proposed a bill to establish the organisation of trade unions as civil rights.
"Just as unions die, middle-class jobs die," said Ellison, a Democrat from Minnesota and deputy chairman of the Progressive Caucus in Congress.
Therefore, I proudly present the employee empowerment law together with the civil rights icon John Lewis.

This groundbreaking law gives workers the same legal possibilities for discrimination on the basis of trade union organisation as in other forms of discrimination - and thus stops anti-unionist forces.

Complementing the National Labour Law to create a possibility for workers exposed to discrimination to organise a trade union representation in order to bring justice before a civil court - and to obtain compensation or fines - is a useful and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not according to American standards.
In fact, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other sponsors of their bill propose is to link back to a very American idea.

Despite the setbacks the trade unions have suffered in recent years - in Wisconsin, Michigan and other countries around the country - Americans have once encouraged countries around the world to recognise, expand and comply with labour laws.
There was a time when millions of Americans remember when this country called democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the right of association in one breath.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas Mac Arthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution to ensure that Hedki Tojo's militarized autocracy was replaced by democracy.

Conscious that the workers and their trade unions took a role in the creation of a new Japan, they used a language that explicitly acknowledged that "the rights of workers to union and collective bargaining and action are guaranteed."

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight urged David Eisenhower and his staff to write a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism was replaced by a strong democracy.

Recognizing the fact that the workers would have to organize themselves and raise their voice in the new nation, the Germans added a clause that explicitly stated: "The right to establish associations in order to secure and improve the working and economic conditions is guaranteed to every individual and every profession or trade.
Agreements which restrict this right or aim to reduce it are null and void; measures aimed at this are illegal.

When the former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt presided over the International Commission on Human Rights, which drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as adopted by the United Nations as a worldwide agreement in 1948, Roosevelt and the other authors added a guarantee that "everyone has the right to form or join trade unions to protect his interests."
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labour rights are human rights.

When this country advised other countries on how to shape civil and democratic societies, Americans said that the right to establish a union - and that this union should then be allowed to participate in collective bargaining as an equal partner with companies and government agencies - had to be protected.

After these rights have been attacked in America, it is indeed very wise to recall the American ideal, which requires the working population to have the right to unite and to be heard in a free and open society.
As Pastor Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago,
The story is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the workers' movement did not restrict the strength of the nation, but enlarged it.
By raising the standard of living of millions of people, labor miraculously created a market for industry and raised the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack the work forget these simple truths, but history keeps them.
History remembers, and that's what we should do.

The formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of the protection of civil rights as protection against discrimination in the creation of workers' representatives - is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis are renewing the ideals that have made America great in the past and that have redeemed the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily stops law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close
A U.S. federal judge provisionally stopped the implementation of a law in Louisiana on Sunday, which lawyers say would have led to the closure of all five abortion clinics in the state.

This measure, which was introduced by Bobby Jindal, Governor of Louisiana, in June to enter into force on 1 Sept., would force doctors who perform abortions to acquire a patient's admission right at a hospital within a radius of 30 miles of their practice.
However, the judge's decision means that doctors can continue to carry out legal abortions for the time being while applying for such a right.
"The plaintiffs can continue to work in accordance with the law while trying to obtain these rights," wrote Federal Judge John deGravelles in his judgment.
Within one month, a hearing will be held for the judge in order to obtain a more lasting decision for the law.
Abortion advocates welcomed the decision, the youngest in a series of judgments against similar measures, saying that doctors would have more time to obtain hospital admission rights.

"Today's decision means that the women in Louisiana escape a devious law that wants to deprive them of their health and rights," said Nancy Northup, President and Chairman of the Center for Reproduction Rights, who had sued on behalf of three of the state's five hospitals to stop the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the judgment also covered doctors from the two clinics who had not joined the action and had also applied for admission rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have passed similar laws, with courts recently declaring such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key points of a bill in Texas that would have forced most of the remaining hospitals to close down were stopped by a federal judge on Friday.
Abortion advocates and the American College of Ostretricians and Gynecologists, as well as the American Medical Association, agree that admission rights require unnecessary restrictions on doctors.
Opponents of abortion oppose the fact that the measures serve to protect women's health, although some also welcomed the effects of closure of clinics.
Only one doctor who carries out abortions in Louisiana has a patient's right to be instructed, informed the Centre for Reproduction Rights.
If all other doctors in the state were forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would no longer perform the surgery for fear of his safety, the group said.

In their argument against the verdict, representatives of the state of Louisiana said that they would not punish doctors for carrying out abortions, while their requests for patient representation rights were still pending.
Delayed diagnoses and lack of access to the best treatment options lead to higher death rates due to ovarian cancer in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James have released a video hommage for their mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in Australia's rural areas have a higher risk of dying of ovarian cancer than women in cities.
Researchers analysed the medical data of more than 1100 Australian women who were diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found that only 25 percent were still alive five years after diagnosis.

Research leader Susan Jordan of the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said that for those living in rural and remote regions of the state, the mortality risk was 20 percent higher during the study than for those living in urban areas.
SMALL STUDY: New medicines could slow down lung and ovarian cancer
The researchers investigated the medical care of women over seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that the age of a woman in diagnosis, the type of ovarian cancer, existing pre-diseases and social and economic status also affected the chances of survival.
For older women and those whose cancer was already more advanced at the time of diagnosis, the survival rate was lowest.
For those living in rural and remote regions of the state, the risk of mortality was 20 percent higher during the study than for those living in urban areas.

Although the study did not investigate why women living outside the city were more likely to die of ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suspects a late diagnosis and a lack of access to the best treatment centers as potential factors.
"This disease is best treated by gynecological oncologists, and these are mostly found in larger cities," she said.

Despite the improvement of telemedical services to counter the distances, she proposed, as a possible remedy, strengthening the service of doctors flown in to give specialists the opportunity to provide more densely for women at their home, as well as treatment programs for people outside their region.

Dr Jordan said that, regardless of geographical status, the study showed a poor long-term survival rate in women in ovarian cancer and underlined the need for better treatment and prevention strategies.
The study, funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer, is now published in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a young mother of 33, learned from the Gold Coast that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
Garden centres regret declining homeowner numbers

The decline, along with an increased drop in the number of homeowners under 35 years of age, could lead to gardening centres losing tens of thousands of pounds a year when, according to a study by HTA, today's young consumers reach the "core age group for garden products", as reported in the Financial Times.
The report says that tenants spend an average of 55 percent of the amount that people spend on their own homes for their garden.

The rise of people living in highly urbanised areas without gardens, the popular process of asphalting pre-garden for park purposes, and the decline in garden size are other factors that threaten the industry, where an estimated £5 billion per year is being sold.
In the Greater London area, where the share of homeowners has fallen from 61 to 43 percent over a period of 6 years, the lowest expenditure on garden products per household is reported.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that housing for rent or small gardens does not mean that people cannot grow plants.
Guy Barter, head garden consultant for the RHS, said: "Container gardeners, for example, are very popular with tenants because they can take their plants with them during a move."
The HTA report identified the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retailing due to rising household ownership and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
It also forecasted an improved market situation for this year due to better weather after unfriendly weather conditions in March and April last year.

The police used tear gas.

The first spring day with wet and stormy weather conditions affects flights from Adelaide airport
The FRUHLING has provided South Australia with a winter surprise, with heavy showers and strong wind, which affected flights from Adelaide airport.

The bad weather conditions have probably led to the delayed landing of a flight from Virgin Airlines from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The plane should have landed shortly after 7.30 p.m., but was hit by a shearwind - a sudden change in wind speed or direction over a short distance - and had to take off.
At this time, winds reached about 50 km/h on the ground at Adelaide Airport.
The flight data showed that the aircraft had to take off on a second approach and finally set up at about 8.40 p.m.
The delay resulted in the delay of some other flights, including an Emirates flight from Dubai and a Quantas flight from Sydney.
For Adelaide, a maximum temperature of 16°C is predicted on Tuesday, with possible showers.

Israeli children return to their schools after the war in Gaza

Thousands of Israeli children from the areas near the Gaza Strip returned to the schools on Monday after spending the summer in air raid shelters, while rocket and mortar shelling went down on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas and the schools in Gaza remained closed while the area recovered from the fighting.
The start of school brought a feeling of joy and expectation to the communities in southern Israel, drawn by rocket bullet holes, but the signs of the fighting are still fresh.
In the southern city of Ashdod, employees of the "Pashosh" kindergarten, which was hit by a rocket, removed from the walls and sliding walls prior to the arrival of the students.
"We're a little scared, but excited," said Ronit Bart, a resident of Kibbutz Saad and an English teacher there.
Many children from our area urgently need to return to a routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart said it feels "a bit weird" to suddenly go back to school.
"These were difficult times, and we didn't leave the house at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the kibbutz near the border with Gaza to offer his support.

Until a ceasefire interrupted the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities such as Saad stayed in their homes or left their homes to move to safer areas further away from Gaza and escape the rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the Gaza border, where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian mortar shell, are still reluctant to return.
The Ministry of Education said that about a dozen families had not yet returned.
Their children were temporarily housed in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu attended a school in Sderot, a border town to Gaza, which is heavily marked by Palestinian fire.
He appealed to the children to learn a lot and said, "We will make sure that you acquire knowledge and offer you security."
Israel and Hamas agreed on an indefinite ceasefire last Tuesday.

The ceasefire brought an immediate end to the fighting, but important problems remain unresolved, such as Hamas' call for the lifting of the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of the air and sea ports in Gaza.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the handing over of the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to begin in Egypt this month.
In the war, more than 2,100 Palestinians were killed, three quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children, according to estimates by the Palestinians and the UN.
Israel denies this information and estimates that at least half of those killed are fighters, but did not provide any concrete evidence for this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other fighters in Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortar shells during the fighting on Israeli cities, most of them in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.
The Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of houses in the Gaza area and about 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools, which were converted into temporary shelters.
While tens of thousands of people continue to live in the shelters and fights, the education authorities postponed the beginning of the school year last week.

"I hope the school will soon be open again so that we can continue to learn, like the children in the world and the Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who currently lives in a school in Gaza City.

House prices have experienced the strongest winter increase in seven years, showing a widely observed index.
The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for Homes in the Australian capital rose by 1.1 percent in August, according to the RP data of Monday.
As a result of this increase, the overall increase in June, July and August is 4.2 percent, the largest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase was 10.9 percent, more than twice the increase in the 12 months to August 2013, but the increases were not evenly spread across the country.
RP Data's research manager, Tim Lawless, announced that Sydney and Melbourne are driving a split market.
RP Data figures show that home prices in Sydney increased by 16.1 percent last year, while Melbourne increased by 11.7 percent.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, where prices rose by an average of five and six percent.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which was hit hard by cuts in government spending and where prices only rose by 1.4 percent over the year.
Mr Lawless also said that with the beginning of spring, there would now be an increase in the real estate available for sale, which would be "a real test" of the market.

"Looking at the constantly high rate of auction prices, a generally fast sales rate and the constantly low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will rise even further in the next three months," he said.

Konstantin Weckers ruthlessly honest memoirs
It's actually more philosophical testimony than biography, which Konstantin Wecker, songwriter, pacifist, political activist, ex-prisoner, put on paper in "Monk and Warrior" on 287 pages.
The Munich-born on 1 June 1947 wrote down his memoirs, each chapter initiated by a suitable song text, rather than chronologically, but more thought scraps for thought scraps.
And he is ruthlessly honest: from the Onanie as a gymnasium to shoplifting and drug use, he does not leave out any human weakness.
Also to show how he himself has learned tolerance in dealing with his fellow human beings.

Broad space also includes abstract, but all the more important concepts: love, soul, ego, being in the now, spirituality - all of which he tries to get to the bottom of, in a very philosophical but also very personal way.

And he also explains his pacifism, his social criticism, his political commitment - and how not only the music influenced him (the opera lover became a soul and rock musician), but also his stay in prison.
The latter has also brought the Lebemann Konstantin Wecker closer to the ascetic monk, who is "by subtraction", as he says, "by leaving away all unnecessary things".
Between all the high-spirited views there are also short anecdotes to the earth: for example about fights in a local frequented by GIs or a crazy car ride, during which he targeted a tree frontally.
Even there, he's ruthlessly honest.

with Dawn French.

HR4-RADTOUR 700 cyclists stop in the spa park of Bad Salzhausen and Schotten
When cyclists stop on their tour in Bad Salzhausen or Schotten, this is nothing special in itself.

Berkeley declares housing market "normal" again
One of London's most prominent contractors pointed out that the housing market in the south-east of England had "returned" to normal levels.

Homes in the capital were highly sought after and the subject of enormous price increases, which prompted the Bank of England to set mortgage credit ceilings in June due to the widespread fear of a credit bubble.

Tony Pidgley, founder and CEO of the high-class construction company Berkeley, said on Monday: "Since the start of the current financial year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels since the peak in 2013" and added that this offers a "stable environment of action".
The real estate market in London was well positioned during the downturn, as foreign buyers rushed into the capital.
According to the cadastral office, prices in the urban area alone rose by 18.5 percent last year, much more than the average increase in England and Wales as a whole.
The average selling prices of Berkeley's private, inexpensive and student offerings increased by about a fifth last year and were around £423,000 at the end of April.

However, a stronger pound has made property ownership in London less attractive to foreign buyers in recent months - some of them have also been deterred by the introduction of new real estate taxes and political rhetoric for a possible "illegal tax" before the general elections next May.

London real estate agent Foxtons warned last week that the April mortgage market report, which presented tougher lending arrangements, would also lead to lower market growth in both real estate sales and prices in the second half of the year.
New data from the Bank of England on Monday show a decline in mortgage approval in July, which also indicates that the real estate market is cooling down.
Hamptions International, another real estate agency, revised its forecast for the rise in real estate prices in London for 2015 down to 3 percent, based on a already weakening house price awareness.
The transaction volume in the most expensive areas of London, such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington, has now fallen by a quarter year after year, says real estate agent WA Ellis.
Nevertheless, the desire for a home in the capital city is a blessing for Berkeley, as the amounts due for future sales amount to more than £2.2 billion.
Mr. Pidgley added: "The demand for the right, well-planned product at the best locations remained stable and as a result, future sales remained stable."
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new homes by the end of April – almost a third more than the peak in 2007 before the crisis.
The annual pre-tax result rose by 40 percent to £ 280 million each year, while sales increased by 18 percent to £ 1.6 billion.
In a statement on Monday before the Company's annual meeting, Mr. Pidgley said that the revenues for Berkeley in the current year are expected to be in line with current market expectations.
Analysts consistently estimate the annual pre-tax result at £450 million.
Berkeley shares were fixed in London retail in the afternoon at £23.96.

Lesotho military member says that no coup d'état is planned; Prime Minister remains in South Africa

Official military officials in Lesotho argued that they had planned a coup d'état to overthrow the government and said that they were acting against police officers accused of arming political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Thabane fled the country and said that the country's army had surrounded its headquarters and occupied government buildings in the capital Maseru.
The Prime Minister took his family to neighboring South Africa after reporting on threats of assassination.

Military spokesman Major Ntlele Ntoi said that there was no coup d'état in fact, but that the military was responding to the threat of "political fanatics" whose armed forces were imminent by the police.

"What happened this morning was that the Lesotho Defence Forces staff acted after receiving several intelligence reports that inside the police some elements actually wanted to arm some of the political, party-political young fanatics who were about to do devastating damage," he said to Voice of America.
South African government spokesman Clayson Monyela said that the military action had made the impression of a overthrow.
"Even though no one has claimed to have seized the government by force, all reports agree that the activities of Lesotho's defense forces have so far shown signs of a coup," he said.
Spokesmen of the Lesotho military announced on Sunday that the soldiers would retreat to their barracks and that the situation in the capital would be calm.
Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Mothetjoya Metsing takes over the government during Thabane's absence.
Thabane said that he believed that he had become a target because of his attempt to fight corruption in the country.

Production in the euro-zone on a 13 month low
The increase in output in the eurozone slowed down in August to the lowest point in the last 13 months, according to a closely observed study.
The final Markit purchasing manager index of the manufacturing industry (PMI) fell to 50.7 in August, after a level of 51.8 in July.
An indication over 50 indicates an expansion.
New orders went down and factories experienced break-ins at a time of increasing tensions between the EU and Russia over Ukraine.
The figures arrive before the meeting of the European Central Bank (ECB) on Thursday.
Markets expect the Bank to have a clear plan to deal with a hesitant recovery in the euro area, as well as the threat of deflation at a inflation rate of only 0.3%.

There are speculations that the ECB's head Mario Draghi could provide further information later this week on whether he is considering a quantitative easing for the eurozone, according to those made by the UK and the US during the financial crisis.

"Although small growth is better than no growth at all, the slowing effects of increasing economic and geopolitical uncertainties have become clearer for manufacturers," said Rob Dobson, leading economist at Markit.
The factory PMI for Germany, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to the lowest level in 11 months at 51,4.
Meanwhile, in the second largest economic nation of the bloc, France, the PMI fell to 46,9.
France remains a child of concern, as well as the decline of Italy from a solid expansion to stagnation.
Evidence that growth incentives in the key industrial mechanism are no longer effective in Germany as well as in Spain and the Netherlands is also not reassuring," said Mr Dobson.
The decline in industry is likely to fuel the fire of analysts who expect further monetary or fiscal incentives.
A positive message came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI rose to 57.3, the highest level since the end of 1999.

Howard Archer, Chief Business Expert at IHS Global Insight, said, "The best thing you can say for the August purchasing manager's index of manufacturing in the eurozone is that the sector continues to grow after that."

He added: "Currently, producers in the eurozone seem to find life quite difficult, as current increased geopolitical tensions - especially in relation to Russia and Ukraine - increase uncertainties in the still difficult conditions in many countries.

These increased uncertainties have clearly affected the economy - in particular, and consumer confidence, and are likely to lead to delays or even cancellations of some orders, especially large orders.
He said that it would be "more and more likely" that the ECB would eventually have to initiate a kind of QE, "although we suspect that this will be limited."

4 tips for better underwater photos and videos
If you want to take photos or videos underwater, there is a selection of devices.
The cheapest option is a watertight point-and-shoot, like the Nikon Coolpix AW120 or an action cam like the GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, both available for about $300.
I took these photos at a family party with several cameras, all available at a price of less than $350.
Regardless of the equipment, there are a few rules for the best results.
Check your equipment twice.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure that the battery compartment and other compartments are tightly closed.
Also set your camera to the photos or videos you want to record.
Some cameras and camcorders have scene and recording modes that optimize exposure time for the subdued underwater conditions.
And before you jump in, check to what depth your equipment is working.
Some cameras are only approved for up to 5 feet, others up to 50 or 60 feet.
In our shopping guide and reviews, search for digital cameras for conventional and waterproof models.
Take multiple shots - because many won't work.
Point-and-shoot cameras have an LCD that allows you to compose images, action cams usually do not.
Even if you have an LCD, it is difficult to look under water, and the right image setting is a lucky thing.
So take a lot of pictures.
If your camera has a row mode that takes a series of shots with slightly modified exposure settings, use it.
Stay close to the surface.
The light gets dramatically worse as you move away from the surface.
If possible, you will stay close to the surface if you take photos in a pool, lake or sea.
This also allows you to bring more color into your photos; the deeper you go, the less color you will see.
Get close to the objects.
This is also good advice on land, but it is even more important under water because of the poor light conditions.

It is especially important when you are working with an action cam: these devices often have a fixed wide-angle lens, which means that you need to get closer to your objects if they are to fill in the entire picture frame.
Andrew Lawson was a man of the sort whose character changed things, even in such a gigantic organization as the NHS.
As a consulting anaesthesiologist, he devoted his career to saving the sick both the agony of the disease and the agony of the treatment.
Among his patients, his wife recalls, was a MI6 employee who had to live with the devastating effects of torture.
Lawson knew that the doctors were concerned with the diagnosis and diseases, while the patients were mostly concerned with something else: pain.
One day in 2007, however, he was the one whose path of suffering began.
"I didn't feel," he wrote in May of this year.
I've had trouble catching up.
As he struggled with the flu-like symptoms, he noticed that he was impatiently accusing his wife Juliet.
"I'd rather do everything immediately than later," he noted.
When Juliet was on a business trip for a week, Lawson felt quite unusually and without reason worried.
Something was in the air.
He asked a colleague to take an X-ray of his chest.
Only two weeks ago he had been skiing in the French Alps.
The result of the X-ray was available.
He suffered from mesothelioma, an incurable cancer that attacks the pectoral membrane, i.e. the skin covering the lungs.
As with most cancers, the exact trigger is usually difficult to determine.
For example, while some smokers suffer from lung cancer, not all lung cancer sufferers have been former smokers.
But mesothelioma is different.
In almost all cases, the trigger is an asbestos load - contact with the fibre building material, which was once considered a "miracle" but has now been recognized as fatal.
For most of us, mesothelioma is a disease that can easily be ignored.
Asbestos is, after all, a product of the past.
The most dangerous type of asbestos has not been used in Britain since the 1960s, when the industry voluntarily committed itself not to use it.
Even where it was still used, only people in certain industries worked directly with the cloth plumber, construction workers, carpenters and shipyard workers, for example.
As an industrial hazardous substance from another time, it seems to be hardly worrying today.
But this complacency is inappropriate.
Britain, it seems, is experiencing the culmination of a mesoltheliom epidemic today.
There are more deaths from mesothelioma here than in any other country in the world.
With a total of 2,500 deaths per year, twice as many people die from this disease as in road accidents.
Annual figures of mesothelioma deaths since 1980 and expected future deaths in Great Britain

The reason why we are experiencing the deadly effects now, although asbestos has been illegal for years (all types of asbestos were banned in 1999), is that a mesothelioma develops only after decades.
And the scourge of mesothelioma is not limited to former workers in the construction industry.
Asbestos was, and is often still, present in the houses where we live, the offices where we work, the schools where we learn and the shops where we shop.
And therefore Mesothelioma knows no class barriers, financial limits, professions or age.
The privileged bastions, from the elegant department stores in London to private schools, are no shelter.
The Parliament buildings are asbestos-infested.
Even in the hospitals where we are supposed to be healthy, this lethal carcinogen has already been identified as the source.
Andrew Lawson wasn't old.
He wasn't a plumber either.
In fact, he found it difficult to imagine where he might have come into contact with asbestos.
Then he found out.
"It looks like there was a lot of asbestos in the tunnels at Guy's Hospital, where I was trained for six years," he wrote.
All - students, nurses, doctors and porters - use the tunnels.
One wonders how many of my peers will suffer from the same disease?
Unfortunately, he was able to answer this question at least in part.
"Of the four doctors trained at Guy's Hospital and who have been ill with mesothelioma for the past five years," he wrote in a letter in 2010, "I am the last one who is still alive."
How many more of us are going to get sick?
Andrew Lawson was diagnosed with mesothelioma at the age of 48.
When he died on 17 February this year, he was 55.
That was an unusually long survival period.
Fifty percent of all mesotheliomers die within 8 months of diagnosis.
The disease always ends fatally.
So we can only repeat Lawson's question, "How many of us are going to get sick?"

The UK's leading expert on mesothelioma, Professor Julian Peto, assumes that between 1870 and 2050, if the asbestos epidemic in the UK is expected to come to a halt, a total of 90,000 of the disease will have fallen victim to the disease.
Most of them have no idea at the moment that they will die like this.
A asbestos mine in Quebec, Canada Alamy
A brief look at the files of the courts, to which the parties often turn for damages, shows how far the scourge of mesothelioma is already widespread.
In June this year, for example, Marks & Spencer admitted that Janice Allen had been negligently exposed to asbestos.
She worked for nine years for the chain, from 1978 to 1987, and was responsible for the clothing department at two locations - one of which was the flagship store on Oxford Street.
Mrs. Allen was only 18 years old when she started working at M&S.
Now she has two children in her twenties.
"Before this thing," she says, "I've never heard of mesothelioma, I didn't even really know anything about asbestos.
I never thought this would affect me.
There are few people who know a lot about asbestos.
The fact is that the term asbestos does not refer to a substance but to a group of six minerals.
The name comes from the word "asbestiform", a description of the fiber structure that makes the fabric resistant and flexible.
Three of the six were used in construction.
Chrysotil, also known as white asbestos, is by far the most frequently found asbestos in buildings.
It was used for roof panels, floor panels, pipe insulations, boiler insulations, even brake linings in cars.
It is less lethal than other forms of asbestos, but it is still regarded by the EU and the WHO as a "great health risk" with possible death.
However, brown asbestos (amosite) and blue asbestos (crocydolite) are more dangerous.
Britain was once the world's largest importer of brown asbestos, and experts suspect that "there is clear but indirect evidence that this was a major reason for the uniquely high mesothelioma rates."
An employee of Marks & Spencer was exposed to asbestos at the flagship store on Oxford Street, London
Janice Allen may not have seen himself as a typical mesothelioma victim, but Julian Peto's work suggests that her story is by no means unusual.

He has presented a study of those affected, which shows that "a significant proportion of mesothelioma without known exposure was probably caused by asbestos contact in the environment or in the home."
According to him, a large part of these contacts are based on the "normal use and ageing" of our buildings.
It looks like no one can assume to be safe.
A report by Goddard Consulting, which examined the palace of Westminster, shows how people in the heart of the government could have been unknowingly exposed to the material.

In 2009, Goddard reported that the service shafts and pipelines behind the parliamentary committee rooms were contaminated with asbestos, whose deadly fibers could be swirled up by something as harmless as "strong air movements".
Members of Parliament are often accused of caring for their own interests, but here it seems that the opposite is true.

While the directorate of the Parliamentary Labour Service insisted that the Westminster Palace had received a "clean health certificate", it is now undisputed that £1 billion of work has to be spent over several years to renovate Parliament, modernise electrical installations and remove asbestos, and that, after the general elections in 2015, MEPs will probably meet at the nearby QE2 conference centre rather than at the green benches in Westminster.
The Goddard report also pointed out that "the presence of asbestos has not been handled in accordance with the respective provisions."
No one can know if this mismanagement will cost lives.
All you can do now is wait.
One person who has never been able to determine the exact contact with asbestos is Graham Abbott, a general practitioner.
According to Andrew Lawson, 50-year-old Abbott suspects that he was exposed to asbestos during his work in hospitals.
"I worked in a hospital where asbestos complaints were decided positively," he says, "but I can't prove it in my case.
It's so difficult to remember all the places you've worked on, and the data.
What he remembers is the day in early December 2009, when he got a kind of fever.
He was 45, and he did surgery just late in the evening.
Suddenly, I had chills.
It came all of a sudden.
I felt terrible.
I didn't think I'd make the trip home anymore.
As a doctor, Abbott knew that the pain was caused by the chest skin, the skin around his lungs.
But like Janice Allen, he had no reason to suspect a mesothelioma.
He didn't go to work for a month.
Astonished doctors took X-rays of his chest and put in pleura catheters to remove fluid from the lungs and test it in the laboratory.
His complaints, however, remained undiagnosed.
His health improved slowly, and he returned to his workplace.
From time to time, however, the symptoms returned, often after exercise and heavy breathing.
In 2011, a patient with similar symptoms came to his practice and was later diagnosed with mesothelioma.
But even now Abbott did not associate this with his own case.
After all, his patient was a few decades older and had worked directly with asbestos.
The connection in that case was clear.
In September 2011, Abbott's condition deteriorated again and his family doctor brought his CT scans and X-rays to an expert group.
In December 2011, exactly two years after Abbott had felt sick for the first time, a probe equipped with a camera was inserted into the cave between the rib and the chest skin.
I'm an optimist.
I usually just keep going," he says.
Honestly, I wasn't so worried.
But Rachel, my wife, was worried.
The result of the biopsy was the week between Christmas and New Year: "I was told that it was mesothelioma."
Graham Abbott: Diagnosis of Mesothelioma
Suddenly Abbott had appointments with Macmillan nurses, one of which recommended him to take a lawyer.
Only now did he understand the extent of the epidemic.
"It turned out that asbestos was very widespread, especially in large public buildings where pipes were often insulated with asbestos," he says.
The people who were exposed to asbestos in these buildings are now ill.
And so Mesothelioma now meets younger people who have not worked in the typical professions.
The most dangerous tubes with asbestos insulation in hospitals were underground, so patients were probably not exposed to the substance.

But many employees who changed from one building to another in pedestrian tunnels (like Andrew Lawson) or ate in underground canteens (as Graham Abbott often did), were most likely in contact with the toxic substances.
It turns out that over several decades after the war, hospitals may have been lifesaving for patients, but life-threatening for the treating doctors.
He's still being removed today.
Pupils put their Bunsen burners on asbestos mats.
And it's not just about hospitals.
Asbestos has been widely used in offices, shops, libraries and city halls due to its fabulous insulating and flame retardant properties.
Schools, too.
In fact, many people probably had the first asbestos contact in the classroom.
Everywhere in the country, in thousands of chemistry lessons, students have put their buns burners on asbestos mats.
The issue of asbestos in schools is now frequently addressed on websites.
And meanwhile, such innocent objects in our houses as floorboards or shed roofs have, by default, contained asbestos.
"It is an industrial poison that is contained in large parts of our property," notes Andrew Morgan, the lawyer who represented Andrew Lawson in his trial against Guy's Hospital.
In one case, the only contact that occurred to an affected woman was the demolition of a garden shed in the 1970s.
So watch how you tear down your garden shed.
The effects of diagnosis, and the knowledge that the disease is incurable, is immense.
"It takes a while to process this," says Graham Abbott.
I went back to work and tried to keep going, but I realized that I couldn't concentrate on what I was doing.
I've been in practice for two weeks.
Then I knew I had to go and take care of myself.
Well, I'm not going to see another Christmas.
With the greatest difficulty was the change of perspective from the position of a doctor to that of a patient.
Like countless patients before him, he remembers how overwhelmed he was by all the information he had to deal with.
"It was very hard to record all this," he says.
"I asked my doctor, "How long do I have?"
And I was given about 12 months.
I remember thinking, "Well, I'm not going to have another Christmas.
That's it.""
Mesothelioma is particularly insidious because it is our life support mechanism - the breathing itself - that causes deadly cancer.
Most cases of mesothelioma are caused by asbestos contact.
Asbestos is made of the smallest fibres.
When the asbestos is swirled up and the fibers are inhaled, they can get stuck in the chest skin, the skin around the lungs.
Asbestos fibers irritate the chest skin and can trigger cell mutations.
"The problem arises with the inhaled needle-shaped asbestos fibers," says Professor Tom Treasure, a heart-thorax doctor who switched to Guy's Hospital in 2001.
Exactly the hospital that Andrew Lawson suspects has exposed him to asbestos is now ironically a leading center in the treatment of mesothelioma.
Treasure knew Lawson and treated some others who were probably also exposed to asbestos during their hospital training.
As soon as the asbestos needles reach the lung tissue, Treasure says, "they are pushed from the breathing process to the edge where the skin is.
By nature, it's invasive right from the start.
The usual options for other cancers do not work so well with mesothelioma.
The effectiveness of an operation, for example, is highly controversial.
Some think it's worth a try.
Treasure denies that.
"You can't cut out the chest skin," he says.
They don't get around with the knife.
Meanwhile, the cancer "does not respond very well to chemotherapy," which "shows effect," but does not heal.
"Sometimes there are long-term survivors," says Treasure.
But in the end, they all die.
Fortunately, some patients actually live long, much longer than expected.
The author Stephen Jay Gould died 20 years after the diagnosis.
Two and a half years after his own diagnosis, Graham Abbott still struggles.
After contacting Mesothelioma, Abbott came into contact with Andrew Lawson, who had become a one-man support and counselling office for fellow workers four years after his diagnosis.
"Hello, Cancer Center," he said happily when he called.
"He was very positive," says Abbott.
He had received his diagnosis four years earlier and was still very active.
Initially, Abbott had been offered six chemotherapy cycles that would last four months and would probably only prolong his life by one month.
"I was desperate," he says.
I wanted to give up.
However, Lawson managed to "make things appear in a slightly more positive light."
After consulting several doctors, Abbott decided to continue his treatment with Prof. Loic Lang-Lazdunski, heart-thorax specialist at Guy's.
"We had an advantage because I didn't have to be remitted, I just called and got an appointment," Graham admits.
A normal patient would have to receive a referral and wait for approval of the treatment.
Money is crucial for mesothelioma sufferers to be able to perceive the best available therapies.
But if these treatments eventually fail, many sufferers are of another financial concern - about the future of the families they leave behind.
And so they turn to the courts in the hope of compensation.
Andrew Lawson contacted Andrew Morgan from Field Fisher Waterhouse LLP.
"It has been known since 1898 that asbestos is extremely dangerous to health," Morgan says.
But what changed in the 1960s was that it was recognized that even a very low burden posed a health risk.
And here the negligence of the companies began to play a role.

Andrew Lawson and Guy's Hospital eventually settled their case, but it wasn't what Morgan calls "full compensation" because Lawson couldn't prove with absolute certainty that his mesothelioma was due to asbestos contact at Guy's.
After the investigation of his death, however, a Guy's spokesman confirmed that "the asbestos fibres in the affected basement area were removed in the 1990s."
That was too late for Andrew Lawson.
How asbestos can be removed
In fact, for mesothelioma sufferers who seek compensation, it is an enormous problem to assign the deadly asbestos contact to a company or a workplace - usually decades after the incidents.
Many of their former employers have been sold or closed.
Insurance records may be lost.
And those who defend themselves against claims know that the time is for them, but certainly not with the plaintiffs.
In response to this, there have been significant new legislation this year, which makes it easier for mesothelioma sufferers to claim compensation even if their former employers are no longer found.
The law has set up a £350 million insurance industry-funded fund for all who were diagnosed after July 2012 to prove contact, but cannot sue anyone.
In these cases, the plaintiffs receive 80 percent of what a court could have granted them in a normal compensation process - about £120,000.
About 300 successful applications for the programme are expected per year.
Andrew Morgan, like so many mesothelioma sufferers, thinks that £350 million was a "very good job" in the insurance industry.

"This is a deal from insurers for insurers," he says, suggesting that this sum is a quarter of what insurers would have had to pay if time hadn't gone by and mesothelioma patients could find the companies and sue them normally.
Also Mike Penning, then Minister of Labour and Pensions, admitted that the law was "not perfect".
But both Penning and Morgan admitted that in the face of seven fatalities, rapid action was necessary every day.
"People suffer so much and need help today," Penning said during the second hearing of the Mesothelioma Law in December of last year.
At that time, Graham Abbott had been in the hands of Prof. Loic Lang-Lazdunski for 19 months.
After their first discussions, Lang-Lazdunski recommended an operation, which he expects to have a positive effect in contrast to Tom Treasure.
This was accompanied by radiotherapy and chemotherapy - a triple therapy with which Lang-Lazdunski can present a survival rate of up to 40 percent over five years.
Abbott felt strengthened.
"Of course, that's the most important thing," says Abbott.
You see that again and again in patients.
There's something that keeps you going.
If you give up, you'll get worse very quickly.
Graham Abbott underwent the operation in March 2012.
At the end of August, he had the last of the six chemotherapy cycles.
Aftercare scans showed no signs of the disease.
Then I had a scan in March 2014.
There were several cancer patches around my chest.
I just turned 50.
It's not life-threatening.
It's life ending.
Abbott again underwent six chemotherapy cycles.
Now no trace of the tumors is visible.
But the process is physically and psychologically very strenuous.
You have to think about practical things - about the money when I'm no longer, for example, or show my wife how the boiler time setting works.
If you get bad news, you get negative.
You have to look forward.
As the father of Ellie, 16, and Tamsin, 14, this is not always easy.
"It's hard for parents," he says.
It's hard to know what to say and how much.
When I got my first diagnosis, I told my girls that I had a disease that wouldn't make me old.
They reacted differently.
Tamsin is very sociable and impetuous.
She told her friends and we soon got a lot of calls.
Ellie was more reserved.
She didn't say much.
Such conversations are something that all cancer patients have to go through.
But for mesotheliomers, such conversations are not pervaded by hope, not by a trace of hope for survival.
The disease (like Stephen Jay Gould in the end) brings a grim security.
As Andrew Morgan says, "Mesothelioma is not life-threatening.
Body embalmed pharaohs wrapped in asbestos clothing
Asbestos fibres used for strengthening cooking pots and for greater heat resistance.
Pliny the Elder describes asbestos.
A tissue has been developed that is not combustible.
I saw napkins scorching in the fireplaces at feasts.
The use of modern commercial asbestos begins in Italy, where it is used to produce paper (including banknotes) and fabric.
Important asbestos mines are opened in Canada and South Africa and shortly thereafter in America, Italy and Russia.
It is the ideal insulation material for the steam engines and turbines of the industrial revolution.
Global asbestos production is increasing to more than 30,000 tonnes per year.
Statisticians of Prudential identify a premature death rate for those working with asbestos, who will no longer receive life insurance.
Nellie Kershaw dies in Rochdale.
Dr. William Cooke states that asbestos particles in the lungs are "without any reasonable doubt the main cause of death".
This is the first case of this kind.
Kershaw's employer, Turner Bros Asbestos, accepts no liability.
No compensation will be paid.
During the Second World War, ships are intensively built, one of the most deadly operations with asbestos contact.

An appeal court confirms the first successful personal injury claim in the UK for contact with asbestos.

Great Britain imports 139,000 tons.
A health and safety executive in the UK commits all companies working with asbestos to obtain a license.
The import and use of blue and brown asbestos are prohibited by law in the UK.
Any use of asbestos is prohibited in the UK.

China denies Hong Kong right to vote in government, demonstrators swear retaliation
On Sunday, despite the growing calls for democratic reforms, the Chinese parliament decided against the nomination of candidates for the 2017 elections by the Hong Kong electorate.
This action probably fuels the long-announced protests in Hong Kong's business district, while activists initiated planning and mobilization within a few hours of the announcement.
The decision of the Chinese People's Congress allows the communist leaders in principle to reject all non-peking-faithful candidates.
"This is not unexpected, but it makes us angry," said legal expert Emily Lau, chairman of the Democratic Party.
This is not what Beijing had promised.
The people of Hong Kong were lied to.
And it is clear that we are dealing with an authoritarian regime.

In his defense of the Chinese decision, Li Fei, Deputy Secretary General of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said that the admission of public nominations to the Hong Kong government elections would be too "chaotic."
Since 1997, when the UK returned control of Hong Kong to the Chinese, Beijing has promised to have the residents elected to the government presidency from 2017.

The Chinese leadership presented Sunday's decision as a democratic breakthrough because Hong Kong's citizens have a direct right to vote, but the decision also makes it clear that the Chinese leadership remains firmly in control of the process through a nomination committee closely controlled by Beijing.
According to a new clause, only candidates "with love for the country and love for Hong Kong" should be admitted.
The decision follows a summer in which some of the largest and most popular protests have taken place in Hong Kong for several years.

Behind the pro-democratic campaign in Hong Kong is the Occupy Central With Love and Peace movement, whose organizers have threatened to shut down the financial district if Beijing does not allow genuine universal suffrage.
On Sunday evening, hundreds of Occupy Central supporters gathered in the rain in front of Hong Kong's government headquarters within a few hours of the announcement.
At the demonstration, the organizers said that their movement had reached a new level of civil disobedience and that they were planning waves of protest in the coming weeks.
However, they did not provide any details, apparently in order to avoid problems with the authorities.

In an online message, the organisers stated that the movement "considered the occupation of the central district only as a last resort, an action that should take place only when all the opportunities for dialogue are exhausted and there is no other choice.
We are sorry to say that today all the opportunities for dialogue have been exhausted and the occupation of the central district will definitely take place.

Hong Kong authorities have been preparing for the announcement of Beijing for days, and security measures, including police forces and barricades, were tightened on Sunday in front of the government building.
The unrest is exacerbated by the feeling of many in Hong Kong that they are slowly losing control of their city.
The arrival of people from the mainland increases competition for products and services.
In addition, there is growing fear that Hong Kong's values such as democracy and freedom of speech will begin to crumble under the growing pressure of Beijing.
Some criticized the demonstrations of the Occupy Central movement, as it endangers business operations - the lifeline of Hong Kong.

"The protests they speak of could cause great economic damage, depending on how many are involved and how long they last," said legal expert Regine Ip, who has been criticizing the movement for a long time.
We do not want to stir up fears that Hong Kong will get out of control.
This impression is bad for investment.
China's state-controlled media also recently reported on democracy activists in Hong Kong as subversive agents controlled by Western powers.
This summer, activists organised an unofficial referendum on the electoral rights in which 780,000 people participated - more than a fifth of Hong Kong voters.
In July, tens of thousands participated in one of the largest democracy demonstrations in the region's history.

We look forward to responding to this demand and to offering Britain's first luxury travel service for students today.

Together with our new VIF options, we look forward to ensuring that students reach the university with minimum effort and maximum luxury this year.

Students today are very different in their expectations and demands from the students 10, 20, 30 or 40 years ago - it is more important than ever to make a great first impression, and with VIF you can do exactly that.
The National Student Union, however, criticized the service as being withdrawn.

Feminists criticise racial and police behavior after Ferguson
The unarmed teenager was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo. earlier this month.
The participants lifted their hands in the air and sang, "Hands up, don't shoot," while they waited before the funeral.
After two weeks of protests in Ferguson, Mo, about the shooting of the unarmed teenager Michael Brown, blogger Miriam Zoila Perez noticed a change in the online discussions of white feminists.
In their experience, white feminist commentators put gender before race when it comes to addressing reproductive rights and income inequalities.
However, while tensions in the Midwest increased and received attention throughout the country, Perez saw that white women's responses were 100% about the race.

Compared to the answers of black women shortly after the shots of August 9th, the personal essays entitled "Thoughts about Ferguson from a White Woman" and "Feminism is not only about the oppression of women" came relatively late.
But for Perez, that meant an important change.
"I don't think there are many people in feminism who talk about being white and privileges in such a high-class way," she said.
People felt compelled to express something about the incidents.
It is characteristic of the crisis that we are in and because the situation in Ferguson is so ethnic that they have to express it.

For English professor Koritha Mitchell from Ohio State University, Ferguson exposed problems that black American women are exposed to every day, but which are not regarded as "women's issues" in cultural space.
"I can publish something funny on Facebook about myself and my partner and get 150 likes from anywhere," Mitchell said.
When I post something about how colored people are under siege in their own country, the silence is deafening.
"How can it be safe for women to talk publicly about a relationship, but not about security in public space?" she asked.
For black women like Mitchell, who have studied race, gender and sexuality in the history of the US, there is no dichotomy between racial and gender problems.
For them, black women have not had the luxury of separating the themes cleanly; they live every day in the combined reality.

While white women now combine race and gender in feminist mainstream circles, Angela Hattry, Professor of Women and Gender Research at George Mason University, says that her predecessors did the opposite.
"Between 1865 and 1890, at least 10,000 black men were lynched and the reason was almost always the rape of a white woman," said Hatery.
White women had to be involved in the story to justify the lynching.

For Hatery, the division between white and black women came at the point where white women fighters for women's suffrage like Susan B. Anthony analyzed the country in the late 19th century and found that the struggle for the suffrage could only be successful for one group: women or blacks.
"They made the decision to campaign for women's suffrage, and blacks' s suffrage should come later," said Hatery.
When you remember such things, you realize with power why colored women don't trust white women.
We didn't do our job well.
We never helped black women protect their husbands and sons.
Even after women were given voting rights in 1920, it took a decade for white women to organize themselves against lynching in the Association of Southern Woman for the Prevention of Lynching.
The group was formed almost 40 years after the original request for help from black women, says Mitchell.

For Mitchell, the flood of white feminist reactions to the issues raised by Ferguson - police behavior, racial discrimination - is a mirror of the time when white feminists played "catch" with the problems that black women have been dealing with for generations.
"Wouldn't it be great if the activists who have such traditional feminist platforms take the right to raise a child as seriously as they do with the right to receive control?" Mitchell asked.
Second-generation feminists, who built their careers on the struggle for reproductive rights and access to contraceptive means, are now trying to understand what that means.

The well-known white feminist activist Gloria Steinem went two weeks after Michael Brown was shot on Facebook and published a pointed article by Rebecca Carroll, columnist of the Guardian, in which she demanded more protests from white Americans on the subject of racism.

"I hope that women who have a different but parallel reason to understand a danger inherent in the body - and opinions on the race that are significantly different in public polls - will lead to change," wrote Steinem.
Although Steinem stands for a rather intersectional feminism in which racial as well as gender issues are addressed, some of her comments on the racial theme in America are astounded.

Christina Sommers, researcher at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Who Stole Feminism?" told She The People that young men in the United States, especially young coloured men, "are far more vulnerable than their sisters," but Steinem's comments on Ferguson contrast with her earlier criticism.
There are now hundreds of special programs for girls and young women, but almost nothing for boys.

But when the White House recently launched a small program, My Brother's Keeper, to help vulnerable young black and Hispanic men, there were annoying reactions from many feminists, including Gloria Steinem.
The relationship of the police with the black community is not the only problem that pushes into the foreground of mainstream feminism.

After the U.S. border police picked up nearly 63,000 unaccompanied minors at the southwestern border of the country this year, the issue of immigration reform is again on the surface - this time as a women's issue.

Andrea Mercado, co-chair of We Belong Together, an organisation that mobilises women for immigration reform, said that for a revisit of the topic as an essential theme for women, she only had to publish the stories of immigrant women.
"These speak for themselves," Mercado said.
When the vast majority of work visas go to male immigrants, the women accompanying them are in a position in which they are vulnerable to domestic violence and exploitation.
"These stories resonate with women's organizations," she said.

Leonidas asked in the Gladiator Arena
Not only the gladiators stood knee-deep in the mud at the first Rheinbach Roman Day in the amusement park.

But the attraction of the event was strong enough to attract well over 1000 visitors yesterday, who defied the rain showers and the autumnal cold and were completely inspired by the historical spectacle.
There was a colorful dance of representations, performances, games, exhibits and information about the time of the Romans and their significance for the Rhineland.

The main attraction of the day was undoubtedly the martial combat force from the gladiator school "Amor Mortis", which used every rain break to demonstrate their robust fighting skills in the arena prepared with soft sand.
Gladiator owner "Leonidas" proved to be a humorous and knowledgeable presenter and sent his men one after the other into the ring for a heroic duel in various gladiator genres.
First, the "provocators" were on the row with a rectangular shield and shortsword as well as leg rail on the left leg and arm rail on the right arm.
The "Essedarii" with breast shield, short sword and throw lance as well as iron gladiator helmet, leg and arm protection followed.
Especially impressive was the appearance of the "Retiarius", who fought against the "Secutor" with litter net, Dreizack and dagger and after a short fight hit the boy to the ground.

Then the swords crept metallically against each other, the shields scraped and the throwing lances flew surreptitiously through the arena that could be a fear and fear for the health of the gladiators.
But the impressive "Summa Rudis", the muscular referee, had an always attentive eye on them.

"We wanted to revive Roman everyday life and make the culture of the Roman era experienceable," said Lorenz Euskirchen, chairman of the organizer "Friends of the Roman Canal", explaining the intention behind the spectacle.
After two years of preparation, the theme park became an "Oppidum Romanum", a Roman city, as Vice Mayor Claus Wehage stated in his greeting.
After all, the Romans not only brought war and conquest in our region, but also the Roman culture and numerous buildings that we still admire today.
Remains of this were also to be admired during Roman Day, such as "Aqueduct marble" from the eleven-meter-high and 1400-meter-long Roman canal bridge, which was once at Lüftelberg.
The Frontinus Society faced the supply of water and energy once and now, and managing director Petra Fricke knew: "Today we still benefit from the knowledge of the past".

This is also confirmed by the graduate surveying engineer Ralph Heiliger of the "IngenieurteamZwei" from Rheinbach, who presented surveying instruments of the Romans such as Chorobat, Groma or Dioptra.
The Roman villa in Blankenheim presented sketches and models from the excavations anno 1894 as well as bricks from the original hypocaust, the warm air heating that once warmed the Roman villa.
Impressive also the footprints left by Wolf and Fuchs two millennia ago in the steps of clay before they were burned.
In 2011, the Office for Conservation of Land Monuments at the Landesverband Rheinland had excavated the remains of a Roman villa in the Gewerbepark Nord in Rheinbach.
They had found the surrounding walls of an economic building with a dart for drying grain and malting.
The building probably belonged to a Villa Rustica, an agricultural estate, explained archaeologist Dr. Jennifer Morscheiser.
She presented a series of finds from these excavations in a glass cabinet, including a large plate, several fine glass vessels and parts of a delicate necklace.
The villa probably existed from the first to the fourth century AD, until the invasion of the Germanic people in the then Roman Rhineland, Morscheiser suspects.
In addition, the children dealt with the Roman windmill game, similar to today's mill game, or they wrote their names with metal grips on wax tablets, as they once did.

At the stand of the Römerthermen Zülpich, the children were allowed to lay mosaics themselves, make glass mosaics at the stand of the glass museum Rheinbach and serve a heavy stone wheat mill at the stand of the Naturzentrum Eifel Nettersheim to grind the flour for a flat bread or a cereal.

With the Roman touring car drawn by two cold-blooded people, the visitors drove through the amusement park and passed the impressive stand of the Städtisches Gymnasium, which presented the results of their "Römer project weeks".

With a Roman week from 13 to 21 September, the municipality of Wachtberg will also contribute to the Roman year 2014, proclaimed throughout the Rhine, which is supposed to commemorate the death of Emperor Augustus 2000 years ago.

Together with the Heimat- und Geschichtsvereinen as well as the Wachtberger Wander-Verein, the partnership association and the amateur play district Oberbachem, thematic hikes, a lecture, cooking evenings as well as guided tours for school classes are offered and remind of the Roman past of Wachtberg.

For example, a Roman legionary will tell of his work on the hilly Wachtberg, present plants as living monuments from the Roman era, and present a funny lesson on the understanding of nations between a group of Wachtberger "Germans" and drawn Romans.
The Adendorf primary school is dedicated to the Roman theme within the framework of a project week.
With the Roman Week, the numerous, often but no longer visible traces of the Romans in Wachtberg are to be made tangible again.
In the Wachtberger Rathaus, a small presentation will commemorate the discovery of the Berkum Matron shrine in 1879.
Ebola: The epidemic is affecting West Africa's economy
The Ebola epidemic in West Africa is also a serious blow to the economy.
Markets are orphaned - and international companies are moving away.
The devastating Ebola epidemic is a major blow to West Africa's economy.
The crop rots in the fields, the mines are abandoned and the markets are orphaned - the virus has caused serious damage to the region.
Some international companies are already taking a distance.
"The Ebola epidemic is not only a medical crisis, but also an economic one," says Donald Kaberuka, head of the African Development Bank.
Liberia is hardest hit
"It's a total disaster, we're losing a lot of money," says Alhaji Bamogo, who sells clothes on the second largest market in Liberia's capital Monrovia.
Only those who want to buy food or something for disinfection against Ebola will be on the market.
Liberia is hardest hit by the virus, and here alone more than 600 people fell victim to the fever.
The health authorities recently stated that the disease had penetrated into every corner of the country.
The virus has also spread in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Nigeria.
A total of more than 1500 people died, and thousands more were infected.
Foreign companies withdraw employees
Companies are suspending their operations throughout the resource-rich countries.
Foreign companies such as the steel group Arcelor Mittal are withdrawing their employees, and several international airlines are no longer flying to the affected regions.
The local traders and farmers also react: Few merchants still leave their homes to get supplies.
In some areas of Sierra Leone and Liberia, which are quarantined, the cocoa and coffee beans that are important for export rot in the fields.
The farmers dare not leave their homes for the harvest.
Food is becoming scarce
"People will travel less and less," says Phillipe De Vreyer, Parisian expert on the economy of West Africa.
The man, for example, who normally goes to the market and sells his vegetables, prefers to stay at home.
The population therefore feels the consequences of the epidemic directly and urgently: food shortages.
In the markets, stocks of staple foods such as rice are dwindling.
At the same time, the region, which is heavily dependent on international companies, is threatened with image damage - with far-reaching consequences.
According to Philippe Hugon of the French think tank Iris, the biggest danger is that international companies should basically avoid the area for a long time.
It was crucial to see how far and how long the virus would continue to spread.
Investors may feel that "it is dangerous to live and invest in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia," warns Hugon.
The disease also affects the strained state budgets of the states
The disease also affects the already strained state budgets of the affected states.
The rating agency Moody's fears that their budgets will be heavily strained by the high expenditure on the health care system and, in addition, by the deteriorating economy.
The African Development Bank already promised to help the health systems of the affected countries with 60 million dollars (45 million euros).
The effects are already noticeable in Nigeria, where so far only a few Ebola cases have been diagnosed.
Although the oil-rich region in the southern Niger delta is not yet affected.
But elsewhere, many people already stay at home for fear of contagion.
Reservations in hotels also go down significantly.
Protectors celebrate their 50th anniversary
The Schützenverein "Tannenwald" Berngau celebrates its 50th anniversary from 12 to 14 September.
The preparations for the 50-year foundation festival from 12 to 14 September run at the Schützenverein Tannenwald at full speed.
On Friday, September 12th, a big entertainment evening with the group "Dorfrocker".
On Saturday, there's the big gunshot at 6:00.
Afterwards the mood evening with the "Stoapfälzer Spitzbuam" is in the big marquee.
brass band provides the music
Highlights on Sunday are the celebration service and 9.30 a.m. in the parish church and the big parade at 2 p.m.
In the afternoon is also the price distribution of federal and Gaushooting.
A particularly beautiful sight will be the 25 festive ladies with their dirndln.
Festkapelle is the brass band Berngau.
Mayor Wolfgang Wild and Secretary of State Albert Füracker took over the patronage.

The original name "Schützengesellschaft Tannenwald Berngau" dates back to 1907, when on 21 March the association for "social entertainment by means of practice in room and small caliber shooting" was founded.
The Nazi regime had caused the dissolution of the association in 1937.
It was not until 1964 that 19 young men found themselves again, who on 30 April at the Gasthaus Lukas raised the "new" Schützenverein "Tannenwald" Berngau.
Karl März and Adolf Ried led the club as shooter champions through a difficult initial period, in which it was primarily about finding a club club and installing the shooting operation.
In the autumn of 1965, the Schützenverein started in the restaurant "Leininger" with two teams in the lap competitions.
In the following years, the sports shooters, who were now organized in seven teams, established themselves in all classes up to the 1st Gauliga.
The club records pelted every year and the magical limit of 380 rings was reached for the first time in 1980 by Rudi Meier.
Just as the performance of the active shooters has increased, the membership numbers have also developed positively.

After the club club "Leininger" no longer met the demands of a modern shooting club, the then board under the leadership of Johann Rinn decided to create a future domicile in the cellars of the new "Landgasthof Härtis".
After a work performance of 2700 hours, on 8 May 1988, Father Strasser gave the church blessing for the new trenches.
One of the great highlights in the club's history was certainly the 44th Gauschießen, combined with the ceremonial consecration of the new Sagittarius flag in July 1991.
On 23 and 24 April 1994, the Schützenverein celebrated its 30th anniversary.
A Böller group was founded in 1995.
Josef Schmalzl became Böllerreferent.
A major challenge for the "Böllerer" and for the association as a whole was the organisation of the Bavarian Böller Meeting 2005.
In many hours of voluntary work, the members of the association modernised the rooms and the shooting area in the Berngauer Hof last year and thus brought them up to date with the latest technology.
Eleven teams in lap competitions
The sporting achievements of the Schützenverein can also be seen.
A total of eleven teams currently participate in the round competitions: six air rifle teams, an air pistol team, a sports pistol KK1, a youth and two AH teams.
The 1st team with Lars Ellrich, Katharina Ellrich, Steffi Grad and Kerstin Kellermann joined the district league 1 in the round 2013/14 from the Gauoberliga (highest league in Schützengau ANB).
The 2nd team with Verena Moosburger Alexandra Meier, Eva Schuhmann and Tobias Graml has climbed from Gauliga Nord into the Gauoberliga.
In addition to shooting sports, events such as jockeys, carnival and king's ball, club trip and Christmas party have tradition.
The shooters are also present at the festivals in parish and parish.
Tony Stewart suffers accident on return to the race track
Tony Stewart's return to the race track ended halfway through his race on the Atlanta Motor Speedway.
Stewart drove against the wall for the second time after his right front tyre burst in lap 172 and ended his evening.
Stewart drove his damaged car into the garage and left it without talking to journalists.
His team leader Chad Johnston said his 14-member team was disappointed, but now focused on the race next weekend in Richmond, Virginia.
"I wish we had a better bet and a better result for him," said Johnston.
We're going to Richmond and hope we can do better there.
Stewart had already driven into a wall earlier in the race on Sunday evening after a collision with Kyle Busch and had to have the right side of his car repaired.
"I went in today with quite good hopes for a good result," Johnston said, adding, "It just didn't work."
Not long after the second accident, Stewart's car was loaded into the tug and the team packed and was ready for departure.
Stewart dropped three NASCAR Sprint Cup races after his car hit and killed another driver in an ash race in the north of New York State.
He decided to return this week and win either in Atlanta or at the next race in Richmond to win a spot in the pursuit.
He returned to his workplace during an investigation into the tragic incident leading to the death of 20-year-old Kevin Ward Jr., who had stepped on the road during a race to confront Stewart.
The authorities announced on Friday that the investigations into the cause of the accident will continue for at least two weeks.
No decision has yet been made as to whether Stewart has to reckon with an indictment.
The three-time champion was greeted with great applause when he was introduced before the race.
After a start at 12th position, Stewart had already entered the first 10 shortly afterwards and was temporarily in fourth place.
After a reboot in lap 122, Buschs
Car with No. 18 out of control after the exit from curve 2 and colliding with Stewart, with both cars driving against the wall.
Stewart drove on, but fell back to 21st place.
Dance-joyed offspring wanted
Just try it out: Laura, Lena, Lisa, Marie, Bettina, Emma and head Lisa Neitzel (from the left) are looking forward to joining.

Children and teenagers can always enjoy lessons in children's dance/jazz dance, bambini ballet, video clip dancing and hip hop on Wednesdays.
