I'm twisted in that way.
This didn't help.
He wanted it to sound like fun.
Often, when he wanted to have fun, the effect was quite different, because he, like his father, lacked the convincing charm to control the cruelty of jokes.
Maybe his father meant to be cruel.
Maybe he, Kevern, wanted the same thing.
In spite of his gentle eyes.
Ailin Solomons blushed and got out of his terrace chair and at the same time knocked down the receiver and spilled the wine they had just had.
Even the wine was made of selyan flowers, so he could not use it as a reason for colliding.
In his nervousness, he seemed to shake, like palm leaves in a storm.
“And your fat head is what I’m pervertedly attracted to you,” he said...
Except I don't feel like it.
Kevern felt sorry for Ailinn, both for his own unwarranted cruel words and for the fear that appeared in his eyes at the moment that Ailinn decided to stand against him.
Did Ailinn think he was gonna hit you?
He had never told Kevern about life in the cold northern archipelago where he had grown up, but Kevern was sure that it was basically like life here.
The same vast, cold sea that waved against them.

The same confused men, even more paleer and diabolical after what happened than their smugglers and breaker grandparents, walked from pub to pub, ready to beat any woman who dared to resist or tease them.
Thick head?
If he wasn't careful, he'd see a fat fist!
Suck first — kissing had become the most common word for erotic encounter between man and woman; the antidote for the meaningless loveballads pumping out the receiver — first suck and then attack.
Kevern thought it was too much, too, for the sucking itself was hostile.
Ailin Solomons' body language told him to leave.
He pulled himself out of the terrace chair like an old man.
Ailinn also felt weary, but the depth of Kevern’s grief surprised him.
It wasn't the end of the world.
They barely knew each other.
Ailinn followed him — just as his traveling companion watched Kevern go out the window upstairs — to a man who was himself responsible for his heavy life.
Adam leaving the garden, he wondered.
He felt pity for Kevern and the men in general, even though some of them had raised their hands against him to strike.

The man who turned his back, bowed down, ashamed, beaten, who had lost all will to fight — why did he feel that he was so familiar with that vision, even though he did not remember that he had seen it once before this moment?
When Ailin Solomons was alone again, he looked at his feet.

A few years before the event just described, an intelligent and enthusiastic 32-year-old researcher, Esme Nussbaum, who worked at the General Opinion-measured Private Institute in Ofnow, conducted a short study of the continuation of minor and medium-hard violence in those areas of the country where the reduction or even the end of violence was most likely, taking into account the money and energy used to eradicate it.

“Many things have already been accomplished and much remains to be done,” he wrote, “in order to compensate for the natural aggression of the people who have fought for thousands of years and have often won, especially in the abandoned and remote corners where, despite the towers of the church that cross the hedges, human mildness has rarely been known over time.
However, some things should not be completely removed.
The higher the tower, the lower the appetites it produces.

The people weep among sentimental ballads, devour stories of overcome adversities and swear in the name of the virtues of marriage and family life, but at the same time the old-fashioned cruelty persists in its grip on both rural communities and urban cohabiting areas, and there is also evidence of a new, more vicious fight in homes, workplaces, our streets and even playgrounds.
“You have an unfortunate tendency to dramatise,” his director commented after reading the full report.
I suggest you read less novels.
Esme Nussbaum put her eyes on the ground.
And I have to ask, are you an atheist?
“I don’t think I have to answer that,” Esme Nussbaum said.
Are you gay?
Esme still appealed to her right not to answer personal questions.
Feminist?
Once again, silence.
“I don’t ask,” said Luther Rabinowitz, “because I am opposed to atheism, lesbian sexuality and feminism.
There is no prejudice in this workplace.
We are servants of an open-minded society.
Although a certain type of hypersensitivity in itself is perfectly acceptable and respectful, it can sometimes lead to distorted outcomes, things that you have just presented to me.
Clearly, you have something against the church — and what you call cruelty or evil soul, others usually call natural energy and physical strength.
SINGING WHAT HAPPENED IF IT HAPPENED, as if it had happened yesterday, if it ever happened, will destroy the fundamental vitality of the country.
Esme Nussbaum looked around when Rabinowitz spoke.
Behind Rabinowitz's head, the flashon-pink LED light proclaimed a guide that Ofnow had already distributed to the country for a quarter or longer of the previous century.
Smile to your neighbor, appreciate your partner, listen to the ballads, go to musicals, use your phone, talk, explain, listen, agree, apologize.
Speaking is better than silence and the sung word is better than written, but nothing prevails over love.

“I well understand what you want to say,” Esme Nussbaum replied in a quiet voice when she was sure that her director had quit, “and I just want to say that we are not as effectively healed as we imagine ourselves to be.
I am concerned that if we are not warned, we will find ourselves repeating the mistakes that led to SIIHEN in the first place, what happened if it happened.
True, this time we do not pour out our hatred and distrust on others.
Luther Rabinowitz used his fingers to form a pyramid.
This gesture meant endless patience.
“You go too far,” he said, “when you describe as ‘mistakes’ the actions that our grandparents may or may not have done.
You also go too far when you say that they poured out their ‘hate and distrust on others’.”
A person like you should not have to remind you that when it comes to understanding the past, or defending the present, we are not talking about ‘we’ or ‘they’.
There was no ‘we’ or ‘other’.
It was a time of chaos, that's all we know about it.
“If we are completely honest, in the chaos,” Esme ventured to continue, “no group of society can say that they have behaved well.
I don't blame anyone.
What was done was done, whether it was good or bad.
It was then.
There is no need to talk about it – we agree on this.
And just as it is unnecessary to make accusations, there is no need to make corrections, whether they are justified or not, and even if there is a way to make them.
But what's the past for if you don't learn from it --
The past exists so we can forget about it.
If I may add one more thing --
Luther Rabinowitz broke his pyramid.
“I’ll go over your report,” he said and indicated that it was time for Esme to leave.
The next day, when he went to work as usual, he was hit by a motorcyclist on the sidewalk, whose driving was described by passersby as “evil and fierce.”
Coincidences happen.

Four tips for better underwater images and videos
If you want to take pictures or video underwater, you have several different device options to choose from.
The preferred option is a waterproof, compact point-and-shoot camera, such as Nikon Coolpix AW120 or action camera, such as GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, which both cost about $300.
I myself took these pictures at a family party using several different cameras, each of which cost less than $350.
Regardless of the device, there are a few rules you should follow.
Always double-check your device.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure that the battery and other parts of the camera are closed waterproofly.
In addition, set the camera description settings to match the images or video to be taken.
Some cameras or combinations of cameras and video cameras have a setting to optimize underwater imaging conditions.
In addition, before you jump into the water, make sure you know how deep your device can be.
Some cameras can only withstand a depth of 5 feet, while others can withstand a depth of 50 to 60 feet.
Take a look at both ordinary and waterproof models in our purchase guide and digital cameras reviews.
Take several pictures — many of them fail in some way.
Compact cameras have an LCD display that allows you to compose the image, while action cameras often do not have this feature.
Even if you have an LCD, it is difficult to see underwater, and the composition of the picture can either succeed or fail.
So take several pictures.
If your camera also allows forks, which means taking several photos at once with different settings, use this feature.
Stay close to the surface.
Light decreases significantly deeper.
If possible, stay close to the surface when shooting in a swimming pool, lake or sea.
This will also give you more colors; the deeper you go, the less colors you can see.
Try to get close to the target you're shooting.
This is important advice when shooting on land, but even more important under water because light conditions are scarce.

It is very important when an action camera is in use: these devices often have a fixed lens with a wide angle of view, which means that the photographer must be close to the target in order to fill the whole picture up to the frames.
China does not allow Hong Kong to choose its leaders — protesters swear revenge
On Sunday, the Chinese Parliament decided that the voters of Hong Kong should not elect candidates despite the growing unrest that called for democratic reform in the 2017 elections.

The decision is likely to give a spark to long-awaited protests on the Hong Kong Business Quarter after activists start planning and implementing demonstrations only hours after the decision has been published.
The decision of the People's Congress in China to give the Communists the power to eradicate all candidates who do not obey Beijing.
“This was to be expected, but it is still infuriating,” says Emily Lau, Chairman of the Democratic Party.
This isn't what Beijing promised.
They've been lying to the Hong Kong people.
It is clear that we are dealing with an autocratic regime.

Li Fei, Deputy Secretary-General of the People's Congress Committee of China, defended the Chinese regime by saying that it would be too 'coatic' to stand as a general candidate for the election of the Hong Kong leader.
Since 1997, when Great Britain handed Hong Kong over to China, Beijing promised the residents of the region that they would be able to choose their own leader from 2017 onwards.

According to the Chinese leaders, the decision on Sunday was a democratic breakthrough because it would allow Hong Kong to vote in direct elections, but it also makes it clear that China wants to exercise strict control over the electoral process through the appointment committee, which is managed from Beijing.
According to the new clause, only candidates who ‘love the country and love Hong Kong’ will be accepted.
The summer before the decision, some of the biggest and most prominent protests in the region took place in Hong Kong for years.

The campaign for democracy was largely backed by the Occupy Central With Love and Peace movement, the organisers of which have threatened to block the business block if Beijing does not grant Hong Kong genuine universal voting rights.
On Sunday night, just hours after the decision was published, hundreds of Occupy Central supporters gathered in front of Hong Kong’s main government buildings.
At the demonstration, the organisers announced that the movement would move into a new era of civil disobedience and would generate protest waves in the coming weeks.
However, they did not give details, evidently in fear that it would lead to problems with the authorities.

In their online newsletter, the organisers said that the movement “considers the Occupy Central act as a last resort, which will only be introduced if there is no hope of dialogue and there is no other way”.
We are very sorry to announce that today's last opportunity for dialogue has been lost and the taking over of the centre will take place.

The Hong Kong authorities have been preparing for the Beijing announcement for days, and on Sunday the security measures were tight near the main government buildings, including police and barricades.
In Hong Kong, unrest is fueled by the feeling that the inhabitants are slowly losing control of their city.
The wave of arrivals from the continent has led to competition for products and services.
Furthermore, there is a fear that Hong Kong's values, such as democracy and freedom of expression, are disappearing under growing pressure from Beijing.
Some have criticised the Occupy Central movement because its demonstrations threaten Hong Kong’s lifeblood — the business world.

“The protest they are talking about can lead to major financial losses, depending on how many people take part in it and how long it lasts,” says Regina Ip, the legislator, who has long criticized the movement.
We do not want to see Hong Kong slipping out of our grip.
Such an image would be bad for investing.
In the media of the Chinese state, there have also been stories that Hong Kong’s democracy activists are the minions of the Western powers that foment revolution.’
This summer, activists held an informal referendum on voting rights involving 780 000 people — more than a fifth of Hong Kong’s voters.
In July, tens of thousands took part in one of the largest demonstrations for democracy in the region.

Genetic anomaly is often misdiagnosed
For years, a British woman feared death because of a misdiagnosis.
Karin Rodgers thought most of her youth had only a few years left to live because she had a diagnosed second disease.
He actually suffered from Charcot-Marie-Tooth’s disease (CMT), which means a number of hereditary diseases that damage nerves outside the brain and spine.
According to Charity CMT UK, false diagnosis is a common problem in CMT cases, as there is so little knowledge of them.
It is estimated that some 23 000 people in the UK suffer from CMT, which causes symptoms in motors, such as muscle weakness, difficult walking and toe curing.
The disease can also cause numbness or pain and is incurable and progressive, which means that the symptoms worsen over time.
When Rodgers was 13 years old, he thought he had Friedreich's ataxia (FA), which has a really bad survival rate.
Rodgers believed he would be in a wheelchair before he turned 18 and die before reaching the age of 30.
Today, a 51-year-old mother of two says that “as a child I knew I could not do the same things as others.
I fell every day, and it took me longer than anyone else.
I was never able to skate or skate with other children, and I was bullied at school because I walked and ran differently from the others.

When Rodgers was 13 years old, he had several cuts in the Achilles tendon to straighten his legs. In connection with the surgery, after the doctor left the room, he quickly glanced at his examination papers, which said he was suffering from FA.
“I felt guilty because I was so curious, so I didn’t tell anyone, but when I came home, I checked the information about the disease in the library and wrote to the FA association,” he says.
When I received information from them, I was shocked and panicking.
I thought I was going to be in a wheelchair by the age of 18 and die before I was 25, and in the meantime I would slowly lose my entire ability to function.
I went through this on my own and planned my own funeral.
Rodgers says that by the age of 17, he found that his walking had not deteriorated as much as he had thought and asked his doctor about this.

A Smart Way to Save in Textbooks
The cost of university books in America exceeds $1,000 for many students, so soon Matt Schroeder, starting his second year of study, found a smart way to save on costs.
He developed a system in which students of later years borrow their books for nominal remuneration instead of selling them straight away.
“My math book would normally have cost $180; I paid $10 for using it for the whole semester and a big sandwich,” says 19-year-old Schroeder, a student at Covenant College in Georgia.
Schroeder says that his last semester's books would normally have cost $430.
Instead, he spent $120 on them.
According to the university's board of directors, the average student spends over $1,200 a year on textbooks and school supplies, but students have many ways of reducing these costs.
Students increasingly end up using online shops and creative approaches such as Schroeder’s idea.
More and more students rent textbooks, allowing them to use the book throughout the semester and pay significantly less for it than students who buy the book.
According to Neebo Inc, which runs over 250 campus bookstores, the rent of textbooks has doubled since 2011.
Statistics on the sector reveal that about a quarter of the books of university bookstores in the past spring were book books," says Trevor Meyer, President of Neebo.
According to the National Association of College Stores, less than half of all books are purchased from campus bookstores.
Here is the simplest way to save money.
Online stores
In online stores, a new book can only be obtained by a third of the price it would cost at the campus bookstore.
The recommended price for the ninth edition of Ron Larson, Bruce Edwards and Robert Hostetler’s book “Calculus” is almost $290, but the book is available at Chegg.com for $239.99.
Buy Used
Books used are a good option if the reader is not disturbed by other notes and worn appearance.
For example, the book “Calculus” can be obtained from the Chegg.com online store for $93.49.

Brigham Young University’s senior year student Matt Casaday, 25 years old, says that he bought a book “Strategic Media Decisions: Understanding The Business End Of The Advertising Business” at Amazon.com for only $0.42.
If it was a new book, it would have cost $48.

Ingrid Bracey, director of Amherst's College Without Walls at the University of Massachusetts, and other academics recommend that students ask their professors if previous editions can be used in the course.
Sometimes the reforms of the new edition are not essential for teaching.
In this case, the old edition can only be found at a fraction of the price that should be paid for a new one.
In addition to Chegg and Amazon bookstores, eBay Inc's Half.com is a popular place to buy used books.
Renting
Renting textbooks should be considered if you take good care of them, remember to return them and do not need them after completing the course.
By renting, you can save more than 80 per cent of the price of the new book.
For example, renting a book called "Calculus" for the entire semester costs about $20.
Find out about the rules of the rental company, such as notes, the charges resulting from the use and wear of the highlight pen.
Renter, watch out: if you forget to return the book, the late payment may be higher than the book purchase price.
E-books
It may also be a question of obtaining e-books instead of ordinary paper.
These books are sometimes rented out to the holder of the e-book, such as Amazon.com, Chegg or Barnes & Noble Inc.
You can buy the book "Calculus" as an e-book for six months for about $61.
According to Bracey, many students in literature save the most because many classics can now be downloaded free of charge, while books in science and technology can be very expensive.
It pays to compare different sellers, whatever option you choose.
Joe Gault, 29, who will soon start in Pepperdine law school, recommends using the book ISBN number to determine the price, because it can be used to ensure that you are looking for the right book.
Before ordering online, make sure the book is in stock, Gault says.
He himself learned this the hard way.
The book he bought was on ice for four weeks, and he finally had to obtain it at the full price of the university bookstore.

Norwegian Cruise near the $3 billion Prestige Cruise contract

Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd NCHL.O, the third largest cruise company in the world, is conducting negotiations to purchase its competitor Prestige Cruises International Inc. for three billion dollars.

As a result of the transaction, Norwegian Cruise, with a market value of 6,8 billion dollars, would have access to the luxury cruisers and wealthy customers of Prestige Cruises as it continued to compete against the larger Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd (RCL.N) and Carnival Corp (CCL.N).
According to the sources, information on a possible agreement may be published already this week, although it is also possible that the negotiations will not be successful.
The owner of Prestige Cruises, the private equity company Apollo Global Management LLC (APO.N), also owns 20 % of Norwegian Cruise.
Sources did not want their names to be made public because negotiations were not held in public.
Norwegian Cruise and Prestige Cruises did not respond to the requests for comments and Apollo’s representative refused to comment.
Norwegian Cruise from Miami has 13 cruise ships with a route map covering North America, the Mediterranean, the Baltic Sea, Central America and the Caribbean.
Its turnover increased by 13 per cent from 2012 to 2013 when it amounted to USD 2.57 billion.

Prestige Cruises, which operates from Miami as well, sails under Oceania and Regent brand names, including a total of eight cruise ships, and the route map covers Scandinavia, Russia, Mediterranean, North America, Asia, Africa and South America.
Its turnover in 2013 was USD 1.2 billion, which is six per cent more than in the year before.
The cruise industry, worth USD 29 billion, is expected to benefit from the rise in the middle classes of emerging economies such as China and India in the coming years.
Companies are competing to become the number one choice for these new customers when choosing a cruise.
In January 2014, Prestige Cruises registered its first issuance of shares on the US stock market.
Apollo has owned most of the company's shares since the 2007 deal, which amounted to $850 million.

Norwegian Cruise was founded in 2000 in its current composition after its merger with Genting Bhd (GENT.KL) cruise company. The latter is the entertainment and casino company of Malaysian billionaire Lim Kok Thay.
Apollo invested a billion dollars in Norwegian Cruise in 2008.
Norwegian Cruise became a public company in January 2013.
According to the published data, Genting accounted for 28 per cent of the company, Apollo 20 per cent and TPG Capital LP 8 per cent of the company from the end of June onwards.

The combined share of North American cruise capacity of Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and Norwegian Cruise is 82 %, as shown in the registration document published by Prestige Cruise in connection with the issuance of shares.

Mr Putin calls on Kiev to open negotiations with East Ukraine on a new state.

On Sunday, Russian President Vladimir Putin demanded that the Ukrainian government stop fighting separatists in the eastern part of the country and immediately begin negotiations on the ‘state’ of the dissociating region, Russia’s news sources report.

His representative, Dmitry Peskov, later clarified that Putin did not mean that the separatist-controlled Eastern Ukraine region would become part of Russia, but that its position within Ukraine should be reconsidered in order to give the Russian-speaking population the power to defend their own rights and interests.

Putin's call for negotiations with Russian-minded rebels as equal negotiating partners is in line with his obvious strategy since the beginning of the violence five years ago: he is trying to help separatists take over the region and thus force the Ukrainian Government to effectively grant the newly declared Novorossian independence which will enable it to go to Russia instead of the West.

In an interview with State Channel 1, Putin condemned the efforts of the Ukrainian army to take back the region of Eastern Donetsk and Luhansk, which was dominated by separatists in March and April, following the annexation of Moscow to the Ukrainian Crimean Peninsula on 18 March.
The Kremlin and the Separatists have recently baptized the region as “Novorossija”, “New Russia” – a term similar to the days of glory that preceded the revolutions of the Russian Great Power.

According to the Russian news agency Itar-Tassi, Putin said that the planned peace talks would be an illusion as long as Ukrainian politicians were campaigning for the parliamentary elections on 26 October and government forces were attacking civilians in separatist-controlled areas.

“We must immediately start extensive negotiations, not only on technical matters, but also on the organisation of society and on the status of the State of South-East Ukraine, taking into account the interests of the people living there,” he says.

According to Peskov, Putin's reference to'stateism' is linked to a wider sense of independence, which has been discussed for months with the leadership of Kiev in its attempt to dispel the fears of Russian-speaking regions that their cultural and linguistic rights are under threat.
Only the Ukrainian Government can grant the eastern regions the independence they need, says Peskov.
This issue cannot be discussed between Ukraine and Russia, Peskov says, ‘because it is not a conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but an internal conflict between Ukraine’.

The interim remark by the Kremlin representative, which was intended to correct the ‘false interpretation’ of Putin’s comments, underlined that the Russian regime is dealing with the separatist rebellion in the eastern regions differently from the one in Crimea, where it practically took over an area where the majority of the population of 2 million people is ethnically Russian.

It would be far more difficult for Moscow to integrate even the Donetsk or Luhansk regions in Eastern Ukraine, because the majority of the 6.5 million people living in the region are not ethnically Russian and, according to pre-conflict polls, the majority of the population was in favour of remaining in Ukraine.

The independence discussed by Russian diplomats in international fora would give Ukrainian local governments the right to agree on their own trade agreements and external relations, which would give the Kremlin practically power in an area that links Russia to the Crimea.
On the Black Sea Peninsula, which was annexed to Russia five months ago, Russia's main fleet is located as well as commercial shipping port areas and historical coastal sites.
There are also mines, factories and metal smelters in the area between Rostov and Crimea, which produce vital products for the Russian army.

In his inauguration speech on 7 June, President Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine proposed that the Ukrainian legislators – after the new elections – consider constitutional changes in order to increase the decision-making power of the regions that are not members of the Ukrainian core region as regards their own economy and the status of languages.
However, his vision of independence seems to differ sharply from the view of the separatists perhaps armed and fomented by the Kremlin and Moscow.

Mr Putinin made his latest demand to the Government of Kiev for negotiations with Russian-minded rebels as equal partners after the rebels made further progress last week following the invasion of Russian tanks and troops in Eastern Ukraine from a previously peaceful area off the coast of the Azov Sea.

The Ukrainian security authorities fear that the takeover of the separatist city of Novoazovski, supported by Russia, will be the beginning of a larger effort to take over the entire strategically important coastal area up to Crimea.

It has led to massive civilian and military reinforcement of Mariupol city. Mariupol, half a million inhabitants, is known as a steel-producing port city between Novoazovski and the narrow land area leading to the Crimean peninsula.

On Saturday, Poroshenko spoke to the leaders of the European Union in Brussels, asking for further action to prevent the future violations of Russia in Ukraine, the former Soviet Republic, which has been independent for 23 years.
“We will soon reach a point from which there will be no return,” Poroshenko warned.
There are now thousands of foreign soldiers and tanks in Ukraine.

The EU Summit did not take decisions on direct action; the leaders suggested that additional sanctions be drawn up to enable them to be introduced if the crisis in Ukraine flares up again in unclear circumstances.

The Ukrainian soldiers had to withdraw from their positions in the Ilovaisk region after two Russian Armoured Divisions and 1 000 soldiers entered the Donetsk area last week to strengthen the separatists in difficulty, General Andriy Lysenko, a representative of the Ukrainian National Security and Defence Council, told journalists in Kiev on Saturday.
According to Lysenko, the first of the 63 Ukrainian soldiers surrounded by Russia in Ilovaisk was replaced by 10 Russian paratroopers who were imprisoned in the territory of Ukraine a week ago.

Scientists have found a way to detect related stars.
Astrophysicists from the University of California in Santa Cruz studied turbulence and its effect on chemical uniformity in star formations.
It is expected that the opening of specialists will allow for the search of the stars for related, i.e. arising from a single cluster.
The results of their research have been published in Nature magazine and are briefly available on the university website.
The cause of the same chemical composition of nearby stars is turbulence in the clouds of gas prior to the formation of the stars.
Even if the birthed star then leaves the star cluster, its chemical composition can determine its birthplace and its region of formation.
Previously, scientists questioned whether the evolution of a star outside the cluster could lead to differences in its chemical content from that of relatives in the cluster.
Astrophysics modelling results show that such differences should not occur.
In their study, supercomputer experts modelled two interstellar gas streams that together formed a cloud.
This object has been transformed into a cluster of protostars for several million years under its own gravity.
Scientists added paint marks to the initial gas streams and found that rapid turbulence in the cloud resulted in a high degree of chemical uniformity.
Astrophysicists believe that their research proves that they can look for chemical stars and identify possible regions where such objects can be formed.

Recalling the very American ideal that labour rights are human rights
Congressmen Keith Allison and John Lewis proposed a bill that protects the organization of trade unions as civil law.
"Where are the trade unions, there are middle-class jobs," says Allison, the Minnesota Democrat, who co-chairs the Congressional Progressive Fracture.
That's why I'm proud to introduce the Workers Empowerment Act, along with the symbol of the civil rights movement, John Lewis.

This innovative bill will give workers the same legal opportunities to discriminate against the organization of trade unions as other forms of discrimination, stopping the forces of the opponents of trade unions

The amendment of the Labour Relations Regulation Act to allow workers facing discrimination in organizing trade unions to seek justice in civil courts - and to receive damages and fines - a reasonable and necessary initiative.
But this is certainly not a radical initiative - at least by American standards.
In fact, the best way to understand what Allison and Lewis and the co-authors of the bill are offering is to remember a very American thought.

Despite attacks by trade unions in recent years, in Wisconsin, Michigan and other states throughout the country, Americans have once supported countries around the world in accepting, expanding and respecting labour rights.
There was a time that millions of Americans still remembered when that country simultaneously defended democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the right to organize.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas McArthur and his associates helped the country to adopt a constitution designed to guarantee that Hideki Tojo's paramilitary autocracies had been replaced by democracy.

Fully aware of the role played by workers and their trade unions in forming the new Japan, they included a text that explicitly recognized that "the right of workers to organize, to negotiate and to act collectively is guaranteed".

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhauer and his associates helped the Germans write a constitution that guaranteed that the fascism of Adolf Hitler had been replaced by a strong democracy.

Recognizing that workers would need to be organized and heard in the new State, the Germans included an article that explicitly stated: "The right to form associations in order to protect and improve labour and economic conditions will be guaranteed to everyone and to every profession or activity.
Agreements that restrict or seek to infringe this right will have no legal effect; measures to that end will be declared illegal.

When the former First Lady, Eleanor Roosevelt, chaired the International Commission on Human Rights, which drafted the World Declaration on Human Rights, to be adopted by the United Nations as a world agreement in 1948, Roosevelt and the drafters included a guarantee that "everybody has the right to organize and join trade unions for the protection of their interests".
For generations, Americans have taken for granted the basic premise that labour rights are human rights.

When that country advised other countries on how to build civil and democratic societies, Americans explained that the right to organize trade unions - and that the trade union should participate as an equal partner in collective negotiations with corporations and government agencies - should be protected.

Now that these rights are being attacked in America, it is indeed wise to return to the American ideal that working people should have the right to organize and to have their voices heard in a free and open society.
As Reverend Martin Luther King Jr. said 50 years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Everyone now knows that the trade union movement did not undermine the power of the nation, but increased it.
By raising the standard of living of millions, trade unions wonderfully created a market for industry and raised a nation to an unimaginable level of production.
Those who attack trade unions forget these simple truths, but history remembers them.
History remembers as well as we should.
The formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of civil rights protection to prevent discrimination against the organization of trade unions - is long overdue.
Keith Allison and John Lewis are restoring ideals that have historically expanded America and made the promise of democracy a reality.
The judge temporarily blocks a law that could close down all abortion clinics in Louisiana.

In the United States, a federal judge on Sunday temporarily blocked the entry into force of the Louisiana Act, about which his supporters say he is likely to close down all five abortion clinics in the state.

Under this measure, which was signed into effect by Governor Louisiana Bobby Gindall in June and was due to enter into force on 1 September, doctors who perform abortions would have to have the authority to receive patients in a hospital within a 30-mile radius of their practice.
However, the judge ' s decision meant that doctors could now continue to perform legal abortions while continuing to seek such powers.
"The plaintiffs will be allowed to work legally, continuing with the exercise of authority," wrote Judge John de Gravelles in his decision.
The hearing will be scheduled within one month, at which the judge will issue a more permanent decision on the law.

The right to abortion advocates were pleased to meet this decision, the last in a series of decisions against similar measures, saying that it would give doctors more time to obtain hospital authority.

"Today's decision guarantees that Louisiana's women will be protected from a sneaky law that seeks to deprive them of their health and rights," said Nancy Northap, president and head of the Center for Reproductive Rights, who filed an action to suspend the law on behalf of three of the five state clinics.
It was not immediately clear whether the decision applied to doctors from two clinics who had not been plaintiffs in the case and had also applied for admission.
Louisiana is a member of 11 states that have enacted such laws, and the courts have recently declared such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key parts of the Texas law, which would have closed most of the remaining clinics in the state, were blocked by a federal judge on Friday.

The right to abortion advocates, together with the American College of Obstetrics and Gynaecologists and the American Medical Association, say that laws on admission powers impose restrictions on doctors that are not necessary from a medical point of view.
Opponents of abortion object that such measures are aimed at protecting women ' s health, although some have also noted their positive effect on the closure of clinics.
Only one doctor who performed abortions in Louisiana had the authority to see a hospital, reported to the Centre for Reproductive Rights.
If all the other doctors in the state were to stop doing this, the team reported that the doctor was afraid for his safety to stop doing it.
Criticizing this decision, Louisiana officials said that they would not punish doctors who performed abortions while their applications for admission were pending.
The effect of quotas on domestic products
At least half of the products for each product in the range of trading networks should be Russian-made, according to the State Duma deputy from Justice Russia Oleg Nealov.
The parliamentarian has drafted a bill aimed at introducing protective measures against domestic producers and is writing the newspaper Izvestia.
The document will still be detailed to avoid possible discomfort to buyers.

This applies to products that are not produced in Russia. <...> For the rest of the product groups that are produced in Russia, the Riteiler will have to provide at least half of its shelves to domestic producers," Nilov reported to the publication.

Together with the amendments to the article "On the basis of State regulation of trade activities in the Russian Federation", the bill provides for the amendment of the Tax Code, setting a reduced VAT rate of 10 per cent for the sale of products produced in Russia.
The idea of introducing a 50% quota in trading networks is part of the stimulus package for Russian producers.
There will be several times more domestic goods on the counters.
However, the initiative can have both positive and negative effects, experts say.

According to the counsel of Taxic, a member of Sergei Litvinenko, the independent expert centre "Public Doum", for the Russian economy, as well as for the domestic agricultural and food industries, the impact will be positive and will lead to growth.
There'll be farmers, farmers, small shops.
They can sell more, which means the profits will grow.
In addition, they will be entitled to dictate their terms and prices to the RTs, since they will be forced to buy their goods.
Russian producers will be able to increase their activities and sales, leading to higher taxes than before.
This will increase fiscal revenues, create new jobs, expand some industries, absorb some faster, contribute to GDP growth.
Russia's dependence on foreign food will be reduced several times, though not immediately," the expert notes.
Previously, Russian enterprises were often unable to break into the counters of local shops because of high competition from foreign counterparts.
Now that the embargo has been imposed, this niche has been freed and can breathe with relief.
But it should not be forgotten that after all the necessary harmonizations and sanitary checks, food products from Latin America, Turkey and Serbia will enter the Russian market.
In other words, it is now a time of calm when the previous players have already left and the new players have not yet arrived.

Nearly a month later, we can talk about the increased demand for domestic raw materials, as well as the rise in the prices of finished products," said Aife.ru, First Vice-President of the Russian public organization Rossian Club of Financial Directors, K.E. Tamara Kasyanova.
Clearly, the idea of selling at least 50 per cent of Russian food products in each category will make it possible to secure the sector to local producers.
In that case, they would compete with each other rather than with goods that were less expensive with subsidies from another State.
In other words, the competition for the buyer will take place between companies operating under the same laws of the industry.
On the other hand, Kasyanova points out that Russian producers are not able to meet 50 per cent of the domestic needs of compatriots in all respects.
And in this situation, trading networks will have to push Russia's share of goods to half the range.
As a result, there is a growing fear that poor goods will reach the counters.
It is possible that foreign products with broken labels will be supplied as produced in Russia," the expert adds.
The negative effects of quotas will be felt by large trading networks, especially those that benefit more from cooperation with importers.
It is logical that foreign suppliers themselves will suffer from this situation, as the demand for their products will decrease.
Litvinenko does not rule out that the law on quotas for domestic goods may affect consumers as well.
The point is that some Russian-made products may be of less quality than imported counterparts, while shops may be able to raise the prices of the second as scarce goods.
The idea of import substitution, forgotten in the early 2000s, was again discussed by economists in February this year because of the continuous devaluation of the ruble.
Now, against the backdrop of a difficult relationship with the West, the question of giving up imported products becomes even more urgent.
The Act is intended to require Riteilers to treat domestic producers when making orders to suppliers.
Then we will go much faster and more confident on the way to import, and the production planning system for the necessary products will be set up in a shorter time frame," says Deputy Oleg Nealov.

A particularly effective quota mechanism would be for those agricultural sectors where the potential was particularly high, for example in the dairy sector, where the share of imports was 25 per cent.
Our farmers are really capable of fully covering the counters of Russian shops.
In addition, meat production can also gain a strong boost.
As is known, the largest share of imports remains for beef, ranging from 30 per cent to 35 per cent.
So 65 to 70 percent is still Russian," Kasyanova says.
Experts were of the view that the introduction of quotas on domestic products would facilitate and could accelerate import substitution.
However, this initiative alone will not lead to import substitution, as it requires a set of measures, I am sure of Litvinenko.

In any case, 50 per cent of the goods sold under the initiative could still be imported from abroad, which meant that full import would not occur, but significant steps would be taken in that direction.
Moreover, there were few quotas, and domestic production had yet to be established in order to meet those quotas.
These quotas will provide such guarantees," the expert notes.
Untimed diagnosis and lack of access to optimal treatment means that ovarian cancer in rural areas kills more
Angelina Jolie and her brother James published a video of the memory of their late mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women living in rural Australia face a higher risk of death from ovarian cancer than those living in urban areas.
Researchers analysed the disease maps of more than 1,100 Australian women diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005, finding that only 35 percent lived five years after the diagnosis.

The lead researcher Susan Jordan of the Institute of Medical Research, QIMR Berghofer, reported that the probability of dying during the study was 20 per cent higher for those living in the regions and remote areas of the state than for those living in urban areas.
STUDY: New drugs can slow down lung and ovarian cancer
The researchers followed the medical path of the women in seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that the age of the woman at the time of diagnosis, the type of ovarian cancer, the presence of current diseases and socio-economic status also affected the likelihood of survival.
Older women and those with cancer at a later stage at the time of diagnosis had the lowest survival rates.
For those living in regions or remote areas of the state, the probability of dying during the study was 20 per cent higher than for those living in urban areas.

Although the study was not intended to determine why women living outside cities were more likely to die from ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suggested that the late diagnosis and lack of access to optimal treatment were possible factors.
"This disease is best treated by surgeons specializing in gynaecological oncology, and they are mostly in big cities," she said.

Despite improvements in the quality of telemedical services to reduce the impact of distance, she suggested that an increase in the number of exit services that would allow specialists to treat women closer to home and support programmes for people receiving treatment far from home could help.

Dr. Jordan said that, regardless of geographical location, the study found that long life expectancy among women with ovarian cancer was rare, stressing the need for more effective treatment and prevention strategies.
The study, funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer cancer, will be published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2012, at the age of 33, a young mother from the Golden Bank of Elise Neev was told that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
A new FAP will open doors in the Kugener district in September
Construction of a medical facility in the village of Toktaibeliak began in April of this year and was carried out according to a model project.
The cost of the work was just over 10 million rubles.

According to the Department of Public Relations and Information of Head Mary Al, funding for the construction of the facility was provided from the national budget in accordance with the targeted investment programme.
The total area of the facility is almost 230 square metres.
Health care will be provided to the inhabitants of eight localities: the village of Toktaibeliak and the villages of Dementjevo, Püncherumal, Tunya, Fomichi, Toraybeliak, Shinur and Cushkaal.
The new midwifery centre will replace the existing FAP, which was built in 1918 and has long exhausted its resources and does not meet the sanitary requirements.
The new institution will be opened shortly.
Killing a four-month-old son in a drunken state, the new booth will be brought to justice.
The woman of Chuwashia will be on trial for the murder of her own child.
In the Cheboksars, an investigation into the criminal case of a 31-year-old citizen of Novoboksarsk accused of causing death by negligence has been completed.
The investigation found that, on 26 July of this year, the accused, along with her four-month-old son, had come to Ceboxara to celebrate the birth of her kid.
After a long dinner, the new boxer decided to stay and put the baby to sleep.
When the baby woke up at night and cried, a drunk woman put him next to her bed to feed her breasts, but soon fell asleep.
During her sleep, a woman fell on her son and died of asphyxiation.
The criminal case, according to the press service of the SCR on Chuwashia, is referred to the court.
Inflation's out of vacation.
Will the Russians feel a sharp rise in prices

As a result of cross-measures by the Russian Federation and the West, inflation in Russia will accelerate and fall short of the government's projections, and the analysts of the BTV Capital are convinced.
According to the experts, the delayed effects of the anti-sanctions would lead to an inflation shock in the first quarter of 2015, written by RBC Daily.
According to the latest MEC forecast, inflation will be 6.5 to 7.5 per cent in 2014 and 6.5 per cent in the following year.
However, according to the newspaper Commersant, this week IER is expected to make "small but fundamental" adjustments to the macroeconomic outlook by 2017.
According to the publication, the agency could reduce the estimate of inflation for 2015, thereby eliminating the expected loss of income growth.
The forecast assumed that the Russian Federation ' s food sanctions were in effect for a year, until August 2015.
In such a situation, how could inflation be expected to be so high?
The current situation implies a one-time shock, but the downward trend in inflation will not change," said the source of the newspaper in Minfin.
BTV Capital economists do not share the Government's economic and financial bloc's expectations of inflation and forecast price increases of 8 per cent in 2014.
The main effect of the food bans will come along with the possible introduction of a sales tax (SNC) in the regions of the Russian Federation in 2015, and experts are convinced.
An inflationary peak of 9% will occur in February, after which the annual rate of price rise will decline, experts believe.
By the way, last week Rosstat came up with the first inflationary outcome after the Russian Federation introduced "creative sanctions."
Aife.ru interviewed the experts and found out their inflationary expectations.
Artem Deev, Head of the Analysis Department of the FC AForex:
Price increases are already observed in major product segments.
Moreover, when socially important products began to be valued, the Government had to initiate systematic monitoring of price stability to prevent the risk of undue price increases in the short term.
Suppliers and RTs already report on a daily basis to the regulatory authorities so that the authorities know exactly who, when and why the price increases are initiated.

The enormous rate of capital outflows, excessive refinancing of the banking sector by the Russian megareguator, internal conversion due to the flight of the population into foreign currency, and the embargo on the import of food products from countries that have joined the sanctions against Russia remain key factors in the growth of the consumer price index.
If inflationary pressures had remained under control, the price of a basket of minimum products would not have jumped 12% per quarter.
The ban on the importation of food products caused a supply shock in the domestic market and led to a perfectly logical increase in the final value.

Since at this stage we are not able to fully implement the mechanism of import recovery, as well as to increase the Russian market ' s self-sufficiency through domestic production, the response sanctions will continue to bear the risks of inflationary growth.

If fiscal reasons for the lack of confidence in the national currency as well as the deteriorating prospects for economic growth are added, inflation may well exceed 8 per cent by the end of this year.
Alexander Razuvaev, Director of Alpari Analysis Department
In the 1990s, inflation sometimes reached 20-30 per cent per month, in zero terms it was also above current levels, another matter, which was then offset by rapid economic growth.
I think inflation will be between 8 and 8.5% at the end of the year.
Plato Maguta, Managing the assets of the Magut Foundation.

The external factor associated with sanctions against Russia has so far been successfully contained, but if there is a further increase in pressure, especially on the financial sector, it may lead to some difficulties and increase the inflationary expectations of the population, which usually manifest themselves in buying cash in order to secure their savings.

It may be assumed that the Government, the CB of the Russian Federation and the Ministry of Finance will try to mitigate the smooth weakening of the ruble, both by market methods and by State regulation.
But price increases have traditionally begun after summer calm, and perhaps this fall will become more tangible.
The target level of consumer inflation in Russia of 7.5 per cent is likely to stand, as the Russian Federation still has financial savings.
The horticultural centres are sad about the decline in the number of homeowners.

This decline, due to the exceptional reduction in the number of homeowners under 35 years of age, may result in gardening centres losing tens of millions of pounds a year when today's young consumers reach the "core age of horticulture", according to a study by HTA, reported by the Financial Times.
According to this report, renters spend on average 55 percent of the amount that homeowners spend on gardening.

It refers to the increase in the number of people living in highly urbanized areas without gardens, the popularity of asphalting in front of the parking house, and the reduction of garden size as other threats to the industry, which is estimated to sell £5 billion annually.
In Greater London, where homeowners fell from 61 per cent to 43 per cent in six years, Britain's lowest expenditure on horticultural products per household.
HTA and the Royal Gardening Society reported that renting housing and lack of garden space did not mean that people could not grow plants.
Guy Bartaire, chief gardener at RHS, said, "Growing plants in containers, for example, is particularly popular with tenants who can carry plants when they move."

The HTA report defined the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "gold age" of horticultural retail trade as a result of an increase in homeowners and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
It also predicts that the market will improve this year due to better weather following unfavourable conditions in March and April last year.
The Bulgarian Ministry of Agriculture carried out a mass clean-up at the Land Development Foundation
Three of the four heads of the Earth Foundation were replaced as early as Friday.
In total, three of the four heads of the Earth Foundation were replaced as early as Friday.
The Bulgarian Ministry of Agriculture officially reported only the removal of the Executive Director, Atanas Dobrev.
Lozana Vasiliev took his place.
It turns out that two of the three Deputy Executive Directors of the Fund were quietly replaced on Friday.
The Deputy Executive Director, Tatiana Angelova, who had been in charge of public assistance and the SAPARD programme until then, reports to BGNES with reference to the newspaper Trud.
I didn't attend the foundation's board because we're not legally members of the board, but I was later informed that I was released.
I can't tell you why my resignation isn't reported on the fund's website.
I'm on vacation.
I hope I know more on Monday," said Angelov's publication.
It will be replaced by Ivanka Bagdatov, who has so far been the head of Investment Credit at the central fund at Earth in Sofia.
The Deputy Executive Director, Nikolai Dachev, was also released.
Until then, he was responsible for direct subsidies to EU fields.
Zivko Zhivkov, who was the head of the Regional Directorate of the Earth Foundation in the city of Grand Tyrnovo until January 2014, will be appointed to his seat.
Only Alija Alieva-Velia, deputy head of the fund, kept her post.
It is currently responsible for the Rural Development Programme.
The official reasons for all changes in the department are not mentioned.
Turkey calls an American diplomat in connection with a report of espionage
The Turkish Ministry of Foreign Affairs has called the highest-ranking American diplomat in the country to explain the report on American and British espionage in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bülent reported that the American attorney of business and Turkish officials had discussed the communication on Monday.

German magazine Der Spiegel and Internet magazine The Intercept reported that documents provided by former U.S. National Security Agency analyst Edward Snowden showed that Turkey was a priority intelligence target for American and British intelligence services.
According to Turkish news agencies, Turkish President Recep Tayip Erdoğan underestimated the importance of this message by saying that all leading countries spy on each other.
Previous reports that the main German intelligence agency had also made Ankara a target of intelligence have provoked a more angry response from the Turkish Government.
The biggest Chinese companies have united against Alibaba.

Chinese companies, among which the largest commercial real estate developer in China, the Dalian Wanda Group, and the Internet giants Tencent Holdings (social media, messenger, etc.) and Baidu (the largest Chinese search engine), are starting a company that will compete in an online trade with Alibaba.
However, it will be difficult to catch up with the miracle of the Chinese Internet, which even left behind its American rivals, eBay and Amazon.com.
Union of the Greatest
Companies plan to invest RMB 5 billion (US$ 814 million) in the joint venture, 70 per cent of which will belong to Wanda and 15 per cent to each of the Internet companies, according to Wanda Group.
It is planned to register a firm in Hong Kong.
SP will combine Baidu search engines with the popular social platform WeChat (the largest social network in China, with about 438 million users), Tencent and Wanda infrastructure.
In addition to a network of 40 fancy hotels, Wanda runs at least 49 commercial properties throughout China and 40 trading centres.
Last year, the company invested 50 billion Yuan (more than $8 billion) in the construction of a film studio and a theme park in Qindao (a city in eastern China on the coast of the Yellow Sea).
The project is expected to attract more than 1 million visitors annually and generate a profit of $960 million.
In addition to this, Wanda owns the American network of AMC Entertainment Holdings cinemas, making the company the largest camera operator in the world.
By 2015, Wanda is planning to equip all its trading centres, hotels, and entertainment places with e-commerce services, which will be developed by an Alibaba competition.
According to Dong Ce, who will lead the new company, Wanda will be able to increase the number of e-commerce users of its services from the current 40 million to 100 million by next year.
The new site should become the world's largest online-to-offline platform, notes Dun Ce.
The essence of online-to-offline (O2O) commerce is to attract buyers on the Internet to enter normal offline shops or buy other traditional services.
A classic example of O2O is the sale of coupons such as Groupon or Vigoda.ru.
"O2O is the largest "pie" in the online business," said Wanda Van Jianlin (Bloomberg quote).
"There is currently no real O2O site in China, and in this situation the odds are roughly the same," he says.
China's Internet market is the largest in the world, and McKinsey & Co. estimates that it will more than triple by 2015 than in 2011, to $395 billion.
The number of Chinese Internet users has risen to 632 million, with Bloomberg reporting official statistics: more people in any country in the world, except India.
This number is projected to rise to 850 million by 2015.
The Union of the Richest
The head of Tencent Ma Huaten was, until recently, the richest man in China, but according to the Bloomberg millionaire Index, Alibaba's founder Jack Ma has already beaten him by $5.5 billion.
Jack Ma's condition is estimated at $21.8 billion, of which $11 billion is his share in Alibaba.
Babu's head, Robin Lee, is now ranked third among China's richest people, while Wang Jianlin of Wanda is number four.

"It is very interesting to observe this battle: the three richest men are joining forces to challenge an even richer man," said Bloomberg, director of China's Electronic Commerce Research Centre in Hangzhou Tsao Lay.
But he doesn't think the new company can really compete with Alibaba as soon as it's created: "Rome cannot be built in one day."

The fact that Alibaba is not easy to compete not only with new companies, but also with well-deserved leaders of the world's Internet trade is evidenced by the previous day's report on Alibaba's financial performance in the last quarter.
Alibaba is often described as an average between eBay and Amazon.com, but from April to June, the Chinese company earned more than both of its American competitors combined.
Alibaba's net profits for the period are almost twice as high as that of competitors, which almost tripled annually to $1.99 billion.
"Alibaba still has enormous potential to generate money, largely because of her mobile applications," commented Bloomberg's report from an analyst from the Hong Kong Arete Research Service.

According to the updated Alibaba on the website of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, the number of active mobile users of the company's services in July was 188 million, well above the March figure of 163 million.
At the same time, 32.8 per cent of all Alibaba transactions in the last quarter were on mobile devices.
Alibaba has to name the value of its shares before IPO.
According to an average of 11 analysts interviewed by Bloomberg, the company can be valued at $187 billion after selling shares.
According to Bloomberg sources, Alibaba's debut on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) could be held on 16 September.
The Road Show company that preceded the event began on September 3rd.
It is expected that Alibaba's release to the IPO will record in the history of NYSE and allow the company to attract about $20 billion.
So far, the Visa payment system has held a record for the amount of funds raised on the US stock market, making $17.9 billion in 2008.
At least half of the food items on the trading networks should be Russian-made, the deputies of the State Duma consider.
They have drafted a bill on the subject.
This includes amendments to article 8 of the FZ "On the basis of State regulation of trade activities in the Russian Federation" and to the Tax Code.
The purpose of the document is to introduce protective measures against Russian food producers.
An important clarification, according to the bill, is that at least 50 per cent of domestic products produced in shops should be for each item.

However, the document will take into account that there are products that are not produced in Russia, such as vegetables and fruits in the winter, so they will have a "cut" to avoid possible discomfort to buyers.

At the same time, the draft law also amends the Tax Code of the Russian Federation, which sets a low VAT rate of 10 per cent for the sale of all food items of which Russia is the country of origin, reports the newspaper Izvesia.

On 27 August, a bill was submitted to the lower house of parliament to amend the Retail Markets FZ, which proposes to revive farmers' markets in Russia in which small producers can market their products.
Chief Malaluf is charged with corruption
The plaintiffs submitted evidence of extortion by police officers and officials of the municipality of Calvia to the office of the public prosecutor of Malorca on Friday.
The chief of the Kalvia police on the spa island of Mallorca was arrested as a result of allegations of corruption by businessmen and bar owners at Magaloufe ' s notorious unbridled drinking centre.

Chief Inspector José Antonio Navarro was detained as a result of allegations of corruption brought against him by several businessmen from Punta Ballen, the street where most of the bars and night clubs of Magalouf are located.

According to the daily online publication Mallorca Diario, the plaintiffs submitted evidence of extortion by police officers and officials of the municipality of Calvia to the office of Mallorca's anti-corruption prosecutor on Friday.
Two other local police officers were arrested by the Guards of the Spanish National Guard on charges of corruption and will be questioned by the judge together with Navarro.
The Spanish daily edition of ABC reported that disgruntled nightclub owners said that protectionism by the authorities had a serious impact on their business.
"It's not about making money anymore, it's about surviving," said one of the businessmen to the court.
Our livelihoods cannot be jeopardized.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf ended up in the headlines of the international press this summer after a popular YouTube video showing an 18-year-old British vacationer blowing 24 men during a bar race.
Since then, the island ' s authorities have been trying to stop drinking hooliganism among Magaluf ' s campers, minimizing the number of scandalous drinking runs at bars.
In addition, the Playhouse club, where the blowjob incident occurred, was forced to close for a year, while the Playhouse and Carnage bar organizers together were fined $55,000 ($73,000).

Magaluf's tourist resort, mainly popular among young British holidayers, was also the scene of numerous alcohol-related accidents associated with a mad fun known as balcony, when people jump from one balcony to another or from a balcony to a hotel pool.
The first day of spring was marked by wet and windy conditions affecting flights to Adelaide Airport
WENSNA prepared a cold surprise in southern Australia, bringing heavy rains and strong winds that affected flights to Adelaide Airport.
Another 5 mm rain fell on the city by 9 p.m., following the 6.6 mm that fell during the night of Sunday.
The last rain was preceded by a couple of short rains, including a storm that began shortly before 8 p.m. and poured almost 4 mm in about 10 minutes.
After winter gave out an early portion of spring last week, the temperature fell again on Monday to a maximum of only 15.8 C in the city.
The squash conditions were allegedly one of the reasons for the delay in landing the Virgin Airlines flight from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The plane was scheduled to land immediately after 7:30 p.m., but was hit by a wind-shift zone - a sudden change in speed or wind direction at a short distance - and was forced to gain altitude.
Wind gusts reached 50 km/h on the ground at Adelaide Airport at that time.
The flight data showed that the aircraft had to climb during the second landing, and the plane finally landed around 8:40 p.m.
The delay caused the subsequent delay of several other flights, including the Emirates from Dubai and the Qantas from Sydney.
A maximum of 16C is projected in Adelaide on Tuesday with a probability of one or two rains.
The calculation of the estimates of the construction facilities in the Russian Federation will take place in a new way.
The issues of pricing, regulation of the construction industry, as well as connection to networks, are being specifically monitored by the Federal Anti-Monopoly Service.
The FAS has set up an expert council to promote competition in the construction sector.
At his meeting, the head of the FAS Control Directorate, Vadim Soloviev, stated that "the calculation of the construction project estimates today is totally incomprehensible".
The regulatory framework makes pricing not transparent and may lead to an unreasonable construction price, is considered by the FAS.

And propose the cost of building public property at the design stage to determine, on the basis of market prices, design solutions instead of current estimates and unit costs for technological operations.
These proposals have been included in the road map and are currently under consideration in a mine.
"The replacement of traditional construction estimates with the calculation of design elements should lead to less corruption in the industry," explained Vadim Soloviev to the BWG.
Because the estimates now count every bolt and nut, and it is not always possible to check everything, so at times bad-faith construction companies can bury whole tractors in the records.
In the minstra, they agree with the FAS.

"The first work on the conversion to cost calculation based on the design elements is already available: methodologies have been developed to calculate the prices of design solutions and to estimate these indicators," told the "BWG" the head of the Department of Urban Development and the Minstrud Architecture, Elena Zhukov.
The area of road construction has been selected as a pilot.
However, experts believe that the problem is far more serious.
According to RGB, the head of the Profi-Invest Construction Company, Anatoly Demyanco, the estimated standards are long overdue, but no other mechanism has yet been proposed to the business.
"As for the proposed calculations of the design elements, this is difficult to implement in practice, since construction of buildings often uses very different technologies," he said.
It's no secret the builders are developing in many ways because of the state order.
In the opinion of the President of the National Assembly, Catherine Lesina, the "Expert Community of Public Order Professionals", today the State is the most solvent customer.

Rosatoma Vladimir Malakhov, Deputy Director of Engineering, Sectoral Capital Construction Centre, drew attention to the fact that today the market is conditionally divided into companies that have access to the portfolio of contracts and companies that have monopoly competence and that do not allow competitors to do so.
He believed that the creation of a transparent market could only be achieved if access to contracts was protected as far as possible from someone ' s managing influence.

At the expert board, it was proposed that a State-order system should be established in such a way that the same performer could not obtain more than one contract worth more than 1 billion roubles or several contracts worth more than 1 billion roubles.
In the mine, it is believed that this approach needs to be assessed in terms of the impact on business as well as the effectiveness of construction management.
As Elena Zhukov explained, it would then be necessary to assign the customer as a general contractor, which would result in an increase in the employer ' s staffing and budgetary costs.
In doing so, the requisitioner ' s specialists will have to have the knowledge to assess the quality and safety of the work performed by the contracting organizations.
Often, such a breakdown would require the identification of who would be responsible for the safety of the facility as a whole.

Thus, employers often abuse their right to establish requirements for the content of an application submitted by a contracting organization.

Israeli children returned to school after the Gaza war

Thousands of Israeli children in the territories near the Gaza Strip returned to school on Monday after spending the summer in bomb shelters, when rockets and mines rained on their settlements during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, while schools in the Gaza Strip remained closed while the territory was recovering from the fighting.
The start of school was a source of joy and excitement for missile-affected settlements in southern Israel, but the signs of fighting remained fresh.
In the southern town of Ashdod, Pashosh kindergarten, which was hit by a rocket, removed shrapnel from the walls and roller coasts before the students arrived.
"We're a little afraid, but we look forward to the future," said Ronite Bart, a resident of Kibbutza Saad and an English teacher at his school.
Many children in our neighborhood really need to get back to their normal lives.
Her 11-year-old daughter, Shani Bart, said she'd suddenly start going back to school "a little weird."
"It's been a difficult time, and we haven't left our homes at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited a kibbutz near the border with Gaza to express his support.

Before the ceasefire ended the war last week, thousands of residents of border settlements, such as Sa'ad, did not go out or left their homes, leaving for safer areas further from the Gaza Strip to escape rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, settlements near the border with Gaza, where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a piece of Palestinian mine, doubt whether they should go back.
The Ministry of Education reported that about a dozen families had not yet returned.
Their children were sent to other schools for that time.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a city on the Gaza border, which had been very hard hit by Palestinian fire.
He advised the children to study hard and said, "We will do everything we can to give you knowledge and to keep you safe."
Israel and Hamas agreed to an indefinite truce last Tuesday.

The ceasefire immediately put an end to hostilities, but key issues remained unresolved, such as Hamas's demand to lift the Egyptian-Israeli blockade of Gaza and to open airports and seaports in the Gaza Strip.
Israel wants Hamas to lay down its weapons and return the bodies of the two Israeli soldiers killed in the war.
A new phase of proximity talks is expected to begin later this month in Egypt.
More than 2,100 Palestinians, three quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children, were killed in the war, according to the Palestinian side and the United Nations.
Israel contests these figures and claims that at least half of those killed were militants; however, it did not provide substantial evidence to substantiate this claim.
Sixty-six soldiers and six civilians were killed on the Israeli side, including one Thai worker.
During the fighting, Hamas and other Gaza fighters fired 4,591 rockets and mines at Israeli cities, mostly in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli army carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.

Israeli attacks have damaged and destroyed thousands of homes in the Gaza Strip and it is estimated that 250,000 people have taken refuge in more than 100 schools, which have been transformed into shelters.
Because tens of thousands of people were still in shelters and fighting continued, education officials postponed the beginning of the school year last week.

"I hope that the school will soon open so that we can complete our education as children of the world and Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who now lives in one of Gaza's schools.
According to a popular criterion, real estate prices showed the highest winter growth in seven years.
The RP Data CoreLogic Housing Price Index for the Australian Capital increased by 1.1 per cent in August, reporting to RP data on Monday.
This increase resulted in a cumulative increase of 4.2 per cent in June, July and August, the largest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase was 10.9 per cent, more than double that of 12 months by August 2013, but the increase was not evenly distributed across the country.
RP Data Director Tim Lawless reported that Sydney and Melbourne run a two-tier market.
RP Data figures show that housing prices in Sydney rose by 16.1 per cent in the last year, compared with 11.7 per cent in Melbourne.
The next largest markets were Adelaide, Brisbane, and Darwin, where prices averaged between 5 and 6 per cent.
At the other end of the scale, Canberra experienced government cost cuts, where prices rose by only 1.4 per cent per year.
Mr. Lowless said that now that spring has begun, there will be an increase in the number of real estates placed on the market over the next few months, which will be a "real test" for the market.

"In view of the current high auction rate of sales, the overall high sales rate and the current low-interest conditions, it is likely that the cost of housing will continue to rise over the next three months," he said.

Kenya registers public servants to identify "invisible workers"
Kenya has started the biometric registration of all public employees in an attempt to remove "invisible workers" from the Government's payroll.
Staff members who are not registered within the next two weeks will no longer be paid will be informed in a government statement.
The Government suspects that thousands of people continue to receive salaries after they have left the public service.
President Uhuru Keniata has promised to reduce corruption in State structures since he took power in 2013.
An audit earlier this year found that at least $1 million ($700,000) per month was lost through payments to "invisible workers" and other financial irregularities.
The Government suspects that salaries continue to flow into bank accounts, even after a person dies or leaves the public service, reports BBC reporter Vanyam Chebushiri from the capital, Nairobi.

All civil servants are required to report within the next two weeks to the identification centres to ensure that their data are collected through a biometric registration procedure and are reported in a government statement.
Anyone who fails to do so for no good reason will be struck off the payroll and reported on it.

"This procedure will significantly contribute to the rationalization of the public service by determining the actual number of public servants and will also be used to clear the payroll at both levels of government - thus putting an end to the problem of "invisible workers", said Ann Weigura, Secretary of the Cabinet of Ministers of Planning and Power Structure.

A total of 33 police officers were detained in Turkey on suspicion of "conspiracy against the Government", reporting to local news agencies.
