Berkeley reports that the real estate market has returned to "normal state"
One of London's most famous developers warned that the real estate market in southeastern England had returned to normal activity.

Homes in the capital have been the subject of strong demand and rapidly rising prices, with widespread fears that the credit bubble will push Bank of England to impose restrictions on mortgage loans in June.

Tony Pajley, founder and chairman of Berkeley's elite construction company, said on Monday: "From the beginning of this fiscal year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels since the peak of 2013, adding that this provided a "stable working environment".
The London real estate market succeeded during the recession, as foreign buyers moved to the capital.
The city's prices jumped by 18.5 per cent in the last year alone, according to the Land Registry, substantially exceeding the average of 6.7 per cent for England and Wales as a whole.
The average market prices for private, affordable and student schemes of Berkeley increased by about one fifth last year, reaching £423000 at the end of April.

However, the consolidation of the pound in recent months has made London's real estate less attractive to foreign buyers, some of which have also stopped the introduction of new real estate taxes and political rhetoric around the potential "mansion tax" before the general election next May.

The London Real Estate Agency Foxtons last week warned that the April mortgage market reform, which introduced more stringent loan conditions, would also reduce market growth in both real estate sales and prices in the second half of the year.
Fresh data from Bank of England on Monday showed a drop in the number of approved mortgage loans in June, suggesting further cooling in the housing market.

Hamptons International, another real estate agency, has reduced its forecast of growth in London real estate prices for 2015 to 3 per cent on the basis that real estate prices have already begun to weaken.
Meanwhile, transactions fell by a quarter over the previous year in the most expensive parts of London, such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington, according to WA Ellis.
However, demand for homes in the capital proved to be very profitable for Berkeley, raising sales above £2.2 billion.
Mr. Pageley added, "The demand for the right product with good design and better location has remained the same and, reflecting this, sales have remained on time."
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new houses this year by the end of April, almost a third more than at the pre-crisis peak in 2007.
The annual pre-tax gains rose by 40 per cent from the previous year to £380 million, and income by 18 per cent to £1.6 billion.
Speaking before the company ' s annual meeting on Monday, Mr. Pajley reported that Berkeley ' s estimated income for that year would meet current market expectations.
According to a consensus among analysts, profits are expected for the entire year before taxes of £450 million are paid.
The value of Berkeley's shares stood at £23.96 in the afternoon at the London Exchange.

Twenty years before or so before the events described above, Esme Nussbaum, a smart and energetic 32-year-old researcher who worked at the Offnau, the unofficial public sentiment control service, prepared a brief report on the persistence of low and moderate levels of violence in the very parts of the country where it was expected to decrease if it did not stop altogether, given the means and forces allocated to its eradication.

Some qualities, however, appear to be inexorable.
The higher the spires seem to be, the lower the passions they generate.

The population sheds tears over sentimental ballads, swallows up stories of overcome obstacles, and declares its passionate belief in the virtue of marriage and family life, but not only does old rudeness keep its strong grip on both rural communities and urban settlements, but there are also indications that new and vicious bullying is emerging in homes, workplaces, roads and even playgrounds.
"You have an unfortunate habit of writing too much," said her research director, reading the report in its entirety.
I think you should read fewer novels.
Esme Nussbaum dropped her head.
I also have to ask you, are you an atheist?
"I don't think I have to answer," said Esme Nussbaum.
Are you gay?

Feminist?
Silence again.

Esme Nussbaum looked around while Rabinovitz spoke.
Behind his head, pink letters like flamingos repeated the advice that "Ofnau" had given the country for the last quarter of a century or more.
Smile for your neighbor, appreciate your wife, listen to ballads, go to musicals, talk on the phone, talk, explain, listen, agree, apologize.
Talk is better than silence, the word is better than the written word, but nothing is better than love.

"I fully understand what you're saying," answered Esme Nussbaum quietly when I made sure that her research manager had finished saying, "and I don't want to say anything except that we haven't been cured as effectively as we convince ourselves.
I'm worried that if we're not ready, we're gonna find that we're repeating the mistakes that originally led to what happened when it happened.
Only this time will we throw our anger and mistrust at others.
Luther Rabinovitz put his fingertips together in a pyramid.
This gesture was meant to mean endless patience.
"You're going too far," he said, "calling "mistakes" in what our grandfathers did or didn't do.
You go too far, and when you talk about them throwing away their "hungry" and "untrust" on "others."

If I can add one word to that--

Lesotho Army states that the coup was not planned; the Prime Minister remains in South Africa
The Lesotho Army denied preparations for a coup to overthrow the Government, claiming that they had acted against the police, who were suspected of attempting to arm political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Tabane left the country, claiming that the army had surrounded his official residence and had taken over government buildings in Maseru, the capital.
The Prime Minister took his family to neighbouring South Africa, claiming that he had been threatened with an attack on his life.
Major Ntlele Ntoi, an army spokesman, stated that there had been no coup, but that the army had responded to the threat from "political fanatics" the police had tried to arm.

"What happened this morning is that the Lesotho Armed Forces Command took action with several intelligence reports that there are some elements among the police forces that are really planning to arm some political, young fanatics of political parties who were prepared to cause chaos," he told the Voice of America.
The South African government spokesman, Clayson Moniel, stated that the army's actions looked like a coup.
"although no one has claimed to have taken power by force, according to all accounts, the actions of Lesotho's armed forces so far have had the main signs of a coup," he said.
The Lesotho Army reported that the soldiers had returned to the barracks on Sunday and that they were calm in the capital.
Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Motetjoa Metsing manages the government in the absence of Tabana.
Tabane stated that he believed that he was being attacked in an attempt to combat corruption in the country.
The situation in Lesotho has been very tense since June, when Tabane suspended parliamentary sessions as a result of differences in its unified Government.
He stated that his actions did not undermine the Government, despite allegations to the contrary.

Eurozone production at the lowest level in 13 months
Production growth in the eurozone slowed to the lowest level in 13 months in August, according to a popular study.
The last value of the eurozone's production sector (PMI) for Markit fell to 50.7 in August, dropping from 51.8 in July.
The value above 50 indicates growth.
New orders have been delayed and businesses have been affected by growing tensions between the EU and Russia in connection with Ukraine.
The figures arrived before the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday.
Markets will expect a clear plan from the bank on how to cope with the eurozone's recovery and the threat of deflation with only 0.3% inflation.

It is suggested that the ECB leader Mario Dragi later this week may give additional signals that he is considering a quantitative easing scheme for the eurozone, similar to those used by the United Kingdom and the United States during the financial crisis.

"Even though some growth is better than no growth at all, the brake effect of growing economic and geopolitical uncertainty on producers becomes more evident," said Rob Dobson, Senior Economist Markit.
The PMI of the German manufacturing sector, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to the lowest point of 51.4 in 11 months.
Meanwhile, in the second largest economic bloc, France, PMI fell to 46.9.
France continues to be a source of concern, as does Italy ' s weakening from stable growth to stagnation.
There are signs that the momentum of growth has disappeared mainly from the industrial engine, Germany, Spain and the Netherlands, as well, does not add confidence," said Mr. Dobson.
The slowdown in industry is likely to further fuel the fire for analysts waiting for additional monetary or fiscal incentives.
One positive news was from Ireland, where PMI grew to 57.3, its highest level since the end of 1999.

Howard Archer, the chief economist of IHS Global Insight, said, "The best thing to say about the August study of the eurozone production sector business index is that it shows that the sector is still growing."

He added: "The eurozone's producers seem to find life very difficult at the moment, because the current increased geopolitical tensions - particularly those related to Russia/Ukraine - add uncertainty to the still difficult conditions in many countries.
This heightened tension has apparently hit the business - and especially consumers' confidence - and is likely to result in some orders being delayed or even cancelled, especially large orders.
He said, "It's more and more like that," that the ECB will eventually have to do some kind of quantitative easing, "although we suspect it will be limited."

4 tips on how to improve the quality of underwater photos and videos
If you want to photograph or film under water, you have a number of options.
The cheapest option is a waterproof soapbox, such as Nikon Coolpix AW120, or an action camera, such as the GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, both sold for about $300.
I took these pictures at the family party with a few cameras, all at a price of about $350.
Whatever equipment you use, a few rules need to be followed in order to achieve the best results.
Recheck your equipment.
Even if you have a waterproof chamber, make sure that the cell battery and other compartments are closed tight.
In addition, adjust your camera to the type of photos or videos you'll be filming.
Some cameras and cameras have filming modes or type of object that optimize exposures for sunken underwater conditions.
And before you jump into the water, figure out how deep your equipment can go down.
Some cells are only 5 feet, while others are 50 or 60 feet.
Look at our buyer's management and digital camera ratings for both traditional and waterproof models.
Take a few shots, because a lot of them aren't gonna make it.
The babysitters have LCDs that will help you compile the photos, whereas the action cameras don't usually have them.
Even if you have an LCD, it's gonna be hard to see underwater, and the frame will be random.
So take a few shots.
Also, if your camera has a serial mode that shoots multiple images with slightly different exposures, use it.
Stay by the surface.
The amount of light drops significantly the deeper you dive under the water.
If possible, stay by the surface when you're filming in a pool, river, or ocean.
It will also allow you to transmit more colors in the photos; the deeper you go, the less color you will see.
Come closer to the target.
It's a great advice to film on land, but it's even more important underwater because of dark light conditions.

It's especially important if you're filming an action camera: It's often equipped with a fixed, wide-angle lens, which means you're gonna have to get close to the target if you want to fill the frame.

Andrew Lawson was a man whose strength could shake everything around, even in a giant organization like the National Health Service.
A consulting anesthesiologist, he dedicated his career to freeing patients from both the suffering of the disease and the pain of treatment.
Among those who approached him was his wife, an MI-6 officer, who had to live with the devastating consequences of torture.
Lawson realized that while doctors are interested in diagnosis and disease, those who receive treatment are mainly concerned about something completely different - pain.
One day in 2007, however, he was the one who began to suffer.
"I didn't feel as usual," he wrote last May.
It was hard for me to find strength in myself.
In dealing with symptoms similar to the flu, he found that he resented his wife, Juliet.
"I want things to happen faster than later," he said.
When Juliet left on business for a week, Lawson found out that he was unusual and unclear why he was upset.
Something was wrong.
He asked a colleague to do a chest X-ray.
Only two weeks earlier, he was skiing in the French Alps.
The X-ray results are back.
It was a mesothelioma, an incurable cancer that affects the pleura, or the pulmonary shell.
For most of the cancers, it's hard to know the exact cause.
Although some smokers are suffering from lung cancer, for example, not all lung cancer patients smoked.
But the mesothelioma is different.
In almost all cases, the cause is exposure to asbestos, to fibrous construction material that was once called a "monster," but which is now known to be deadly.
For most of us, mesothelioma is a disease that you can ignore.
Asbestos, after all, is from the past.
The most dangerous type of asbestos has not been used in the UK since the 1960s, when the recommendatory industrial ban came into force.
Even when it was used, only people from specific industries worked closely with it: pipers, construction workers, carpenters and dock workers, for example.
An industrial toxin from another era, it hardly seems to be a cause for concern today.
But such a calm is wrong.
Britain appears to be at the peak of the mesothelioma epidemic today.
More people die from mesothelioma here than in any other country on the planet.
With an annual death rate of approximately 2,500, more than twice as many people die from the disease as from car accidents.
Annual number of mesothelioma deaths since 1980 and projected number of future deaths in Great Britain

The reason why we are now experiencing its deadly effects is that, although asbestos use has been illegal for many years (all types of asbestos were ultimately prohibited by law in 1999), mesothelioma usually takes decades to develop.
And mesotheliomas are not limited to industrial veterans.
Asbestos was, and in many cases remains, put in the houses where we live, the offices where we work, the schools where we go to school, and the shops where we go shopping.
As a result, mesothelioma ignores class, wealth, profession, or age.
The election bastion, from fashionable London department stores to private schools, turns out not to be a rescue.
The House of Parliament is full of asbestos.
Even the hospitals that are meant to treat us are the tanks of this deadly carcinogen.
Andrew Lawson wasn't old.
He wasn't a Tube Isolator.
In fact, he had to think about where he might have come into contact with asbestos.
Then he figured it out.
"It seems that there may have been a lot of asbestos in the tunnels at Guy Hospital, where I spent six years on internships," he wrote.
All -- students, nurses, doctors and loaders -- used these tunnels.
I wonder how many of my peers will get the same disease?
That was a question that, unfortunately, he could give a partial answer to.
"Of the four doctors who were interned at Gaia Hospital and who subsequently developed a mesothelioma in the last five years," he noted in a letter in 2010, "I am the only survivor."
How many of us are going to be sick with this disease?
Andrew Lawson was diagnosed with mesothelioma when he was 48.
When he died, on February 17, this year, he was 55.
It's so weird to live this long.
Fifty percent of mesothelioma patients die eight months after diagnosis.
She's always deadly.
So now we can just repeat Lawson's question, "How many of us are gonna get the same disease?"

According to a leading expert on mesothelioma in the United Kingdom, Professor Julian Pito, it is most likely that between 1970 and 2050, when an asbestos epidemic in the United Kingdom is expected to be extinct, some 900,000 people will die.
Most people don't know they're gonna die like that right now.
Asbestos Mine in Quebec, Canada
A quick review of the reports from the courtrooms, where victims often seek compensation, shows how far the mesotheliomas have spread.
This June, for example, Marks & Spencer admitted that Janice Ellen had been mistreated with asbestos.
She worked online for nine years, from 1978 to 1987, running clothing departments at two sites, one of which was the main store on Oxford Street.
Mrs. Ellen was only 18 years old when she started working at M&S.
She now has two children over the age of 20.
"Before it happened," she says, "I've never heard of mesothelioma, I barely knew about asbestos.
It never occurred to me that it would affect me.
Few people really know a lot about asbestos.
As a matter of fact, asbestos is not one substance, but a group of six minerals.
They've got their name from the word "asbestism", which means a fibrous structure that tells them strength and flexibility.
Of these six, three were often used in construction.
Chrysotile, commonly known as white asbestos, is much more common in buildings today.
It was used in roof panels, floor tiles, thermal insulation of pipes, boiler seams, even in car brake pads.
It is less lethal than other forms of asbestos, but it is still recognized by the European Union and the World Health Organization as a "serious source of health damage" that could lead to death.
Brown asbestos (amosite) and blue asbestos (accidental) are, however, more dangerous.

Britain was once the world's largest importer of brown asbestos, and experts suggest that "there are strong, albeit indirect, reasons to believe that this is the main cause of the exceptionally high number of mesothelioma patients [in the UK].
A staff member, Marks & Spencer, was exposed to asbestos at the company's main store on Oxford Street, London
Janice Ellen may not have thought of herself as a typical mesothelioma victim, but Julian Pito's work suggests that her story is far from unusual.

He conducted a study of the patients, which suggests that "a significant percentage of mesothelia, when there is no known exposure to work or home, is likely to have been caused by exposure to asbestos from the environment".
Most of this exposure, he says, is due to the "normal use and impact of weather" on our buildings.
No one seems to be sure he's safe.
The Goddard Consulting report, which examined the Westminster Palace, shows how people, even at the heart of the government, could have been exposed unconsciously.

In 2009, Goddard reported that technical mines and pipelines behind parliamentary committee premises had been contaminated with asbestos, whose fatal fibres could have been driven by something as harmless as "strong air flows".
Members of Parliament are often accused of pursuing their own interests, but in this case the opposite seems to be true.

Although the Directorate of Maintenance of Parliament insisted that the Westminster Palace had received a "pure sanitary certificate", it had now recognized that it was necessary to work for £1 billion in the reconstruction of Parliament by improving the electrician and removing asbestos, and that, following the 2015 general elections, members of Parliament might meet at the QE2 conference centre in the vicinity rather than in the green benches of Westminster.
The Goddard report noted that "the asbestos situation was not managed according to different rules".
It is impossible to know if this management error will cost lives.

One of the people who hasn't been able to detect their contact with asbestos is Graham Abbott, a general practitioner.

Suddenly, Abbott went into a meeting with Macmillan's nurses, one of whom asked him to contact a lawyer.

"It appears that asbestos has been widely used, especially in large public buildings, where asbestos thermal insulation on pipes was quite common," he says.
People who have been exposed to asbestos in these buildings are now becoming infected with this disease.
Thus, mesothelioma is now affecting younger people in unusual occupations.
The most dangerous asbestos-insulated pipes in hospitals were in the basements, so it was unlikely that patients would be affected.

But many of the employees who went through pedestrian tunnels to get from one building to another (like Andrew Lawson) or ate in basement dining rooms (as Graham Abbott often did) are almost certainly exposed to toxic substances.
For decades after the war, it turns out that hospitals were a place, theoretically, where life was saved for the patients, but a place that threatened the lives of the doctors who treated them.
It's still being removed today.
Schoolboys put their Bunsen burners on the asbestos stand.
And it's not just hospitals.
Asbestos has often been used in offices, shops, libraries and city halls because of its amazing isolation and fire-resistant characteristics.
Schools, too.
In fact, for the first time many are likely to have been exposed to asbestos in class.
Throughout the country, in countless chemistry classes, schoolchildren installed their Bunzen burners on asbestos standouts.
There were websites that drew attention to the asbestos problem in schools.
Meanwhile, in our homes, harmless things, such as floor tiles or shed roofs, tended to contain asbestos.
"It's an industrial poison embedded in a lot of our buildings," notes Andrew Morgan, a lawyer who represented Andrew Lawson in a case against Gay Hospital.
In one case, the only contact a sick woman could remember was the demolition of the garden shed in the 1970s.
So be careful with the garden sheds.
The effect of a diagnosis when it is known that the disease is incurable is enormous.
"It takes quite a while to realize this," says Graham Abbott.

One of the most difficult things was the transition from being a doctor to being a patient.

Mesothelioma is particularly dangerous because it is the mechanics of how we sustain life - the very act of breathing - that causes cancer that kills.
Most mesothelioma cases are caused by contact with asbestos.
Asbestos consists of tiny fibers.
When asbestos breaks down and the fibers inhale, they can be trapped in a plaster, a pulmonary shell.
Asbestos fibers are annoying to the pleura and can cause cell mutations.
"The problem is caused by the inhalation of needle fibres of asbestos," Professor Tom Treger, a cardiothoracic surgeon who arrived at Gaia Hospital in 2001.
That's the hospital where Andrew Lawson suspected he was exposed to asbestos, now ironically, the lead mesothelioma treatment center.

This is essentially an invasive process from the beginning.
The conventional treatments for other forms of cancer are much less effective at mesothelioma.
The effectiveness of surgical intervention, for example, is highly controversial.
Some people think it's worth a try.
Treger disagrees.
"It's impossible to cut a pleura," he says.
It's impossible to come up around her with a knife.
Meanwhile, this cancer is "not very good at chemotherapy," which "acts," but does not cure.
"Sometimes there are sick people who live long," said Treger.
But eventually, they all die.
Fortunately, some patients live much, much longer than expected.

How to Remove Asbestos
In fact, linking lethal exposure to asbestos to one company or workplace - usually decades later - has proved to be a major problem for mesothelioma patients seeking compensation.
Many of their former employers changed ownership or closed down.
The insurance records could have been lost.
And those who defend themselves against lawsuits know that on their side is a time that the plaintiffs certainly do not have.
This year ' s response is significant new legislation that facilitates the recovery of compensation for mesothelioma patients, even if their former employers cannot be traced.
Under the Act, a £350 million fund funded by the insurance industry was created for those diagnosed after July 2012 and who can prove contact but have no one to sue.
In such cases, the sick will receive 80 per cent of the amount that the court could award in the ordinary compensation case, about £120,000.
About 300 successful claims under this scheme are expected each year.
Andrew Morgan, like many who work with mesothelioma patients, thinks £350 million is a "very good job" for the insurance industry.

"This is a transaction written by insurers for insurers," he says, implying that the sum is one quarter of what insurers would have had to pay if the time interval had not intervened and the mesothelioma patients would have been able to trace the companies and file the lawsuit in the normal way.
Even Mike Penning, formerly the Minister of Labour and Pensions, admitted that the law was "unfect."
However, both Penning and Morgan admit that with seven people dying every day, rapid action was necessary.
"People suffer so much, and they need help today," said Penning during the second reading of the mesothelioma bill last December.

Abbott felt strong.
"This is, of course, one of the most important things," says Abbott.
You see this in patients all the time.
There's some kind of power that supports you.

You can think about practical things -- about finances when I die, for example, or about showing my wife how a timer works on a boiler.

Like Ellie's dad, 16, and Tamsin, 14 years old, it's not always easy.

It's the perfect heater for steam engines and industrial revolution turbines.

China refuses to give Hong Kong the right to choose leaders; protesters swear revenge
The Chinese Parliament decided on Sunday not to allow Hong Kong voters to run for election in 2017, despite growing demands for democratic reform.
This move is likely to mark the beginning of the long-proclaimed protests in the Hong Kong business quarter, as activists began planning and mobilizing within hours of the announcement.
The decision of the National People ' s Congress essentially allows Communist leaders to remove all candidates who are not loyal to Beijing.
"It hasn't deceived our expectations, but it does enrage us," said the legislature Emily Lau, president of the Democratic Party.
That's not what Beijing promised.
They tricked Hong Kong's people.
And obviously we're dealing with an authoritarian regime.

Defending China's decision, Lee Fei, Deputy Secretary-General of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said that allowing the popular nomination of Hong Kong's leader for election would be too "chaotic."
Since 1997, when the UK returned control of Hong Kong to China, Beijing has promised to allow the people of the region to elect by vote the head of Government from 2017 onwards.

The Chinese leaders presented the decision taken on Sunday as a democratic step forward, as it gives Hong Kongers the right to a direct vote; however, the decision also makes it clear that Chinese leaders will continue to hold the process in their hands with the help of a Beijing-controlled nomination commission.
And according to the new article, only candidates who "love the country and love Hong Kong" will be admitted.
The decision came after the summer, when one of the largest and most publicized protests in Hong Kong over many years took place.

A major part of the pro-democratic campaign in Hong Kong is the Occupy Central With Love and Peace, whose organizers threatened to cut off Hong Kong's financial region unless Beijing guarantees genuine universal suffrage.
On Sunday evening, a few hours after the announcement, hundreds of Occupy Central supporters gathered in the rain in front of Hong Kong government headquarters.
During the demonstrations, the organizers stated that their movement was moving into a new phase of civil disobedience and that they would rise at the waves of protest in the coming weeks.
However, they did not provide details, apparently in an effort to avoid problems with public authorities.

In an online statement, the organizers reported that the movement had "considered the possibility of seizing the central area only as an exceptional measure, an action that could be taken only if all possibilities of dialogue had been exhausted and no other choice had been made.
It is with great regret that we report that, to date, every opportunity for dialogue has been exhausted and that the seizure of the central area will undoubtedly take place.

Government authorities in Hong Kong had been preparing for Beijing ' s statement for several days, and security measures involving police and barricades had been strengthened at the Government ' s headquarters on Sunday.
The riot is based on the feeling in many Hong Kong that they are slowly losing control of their own city.
Inflows from the mainland have increased competition in goods and services.
There is also a growing fear that Hong Kong's values, such as democracy and freedom of expression, are beginning to weaken under increasing pressure from Beijing.
Some criticize the Occupy Central movement, saying that its demonstrations put Hong Kong's life-force source at risk.
"The challenge they're talking about can lead to great economic damage, depending on how many people are involved and how long," said Regina Ip, who has long criticized the movement.
We don't want to spread the concern that Hong Kong is getting out of control.
It's a perception that's bad for investment.
Chinese state-owned media also reported in recent days, in which Hong Kong's democratic activists were exposed by saboteurs sent by Western Powers.
This summer, activists organized an informal referendum on electoral law, which attracted 780,000 participants, more than one fifth of Hong Kong ' s voters.
And in July, tens of thousands went to one of the largest pro-democratic demonstrations in the history of the region.

Feminists raise the issue of race and police behaviour after Ferguson
An unarmed youth was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri, earlier this month.
Those who come raise their hands, chanting, "Hands up, don't shoot," while they wait in line before the funeral.
After two weeks of protests in Ferguson, Missouri, about the murder of an unarmed teenager, Michael Brown, blogger Miriam Zoila Peres noticed a shift in the online conversation among white feminists.
In her experience, white feminists who left the commentary had placed the gender above race when it came to promoting reproductive rights and income inequality.
However, as tensions increased in the Middle West and attracted national attention, Peres saw the answers of white women, who concentrated 100 per cent on race.

Compared to the reaction of black women shortly after the murder of August 9, personal essays with headlines such as "the thoughts of Ferguson on behalf of a white woman" and "Feminism is not just about the oppression of women" appeared relatively late.
But for Peres, they showed a significant shift.
"In feminism, I don't think there are many people who talk about white skin and privileges at such a high level," she said.
People felt the need to say something about what happened.
It's very symbolic of the crisis we've been facing, and because (the Ferguson situation) is so race-related, they felt that it needed to be pointed out.
For a professor of English at Ohio Corita, Mitchell Ferguson exposed the problems black Americans face every day but are not perceived as "women's problems" in the cultural sphere.
"I can write something funny on Facebook about what's going on with me and my partner, and I'll get 150 likes from everywhere," Mitchell says.
When I write something about how coloured people are being attacked in their own country, silence is deafening.
"Why are women safe to speak publicly about relationships, but not about public security?" she asked.
For black women like Mitchell, who studied race, gender, and sexuality in U.S. history, there is no bias between race and gender.
In her view, black women were in a position to clearly share those problems; they faced a complex reality every day.

While white women now combine race and gender issues in the feminist mainstream, Angela Hattery, a professor of women ' s and gender studies at George Mason University, says that their predecessors were doing the opposite.
" Between 1865 and 1890, at least 10,000 black men were lynched, almost always based on the rape of a white woman," Hattery said.
I needed a white woman to confirm the story to justify the lynching.

From Hattery's point of view, the gap between white and black women occurred when white souffragists, such as Susan B. Anthony, studied the situation in the late 1800s and saw that the struggle for electoral rights would be effective only for one group, women or blacks.
"They decided to put all the eggs in a basket of women's voting rights, and the voting rights for blacks were to come later," Hattery said.
Looking back at things like this gives us a clear idea of why coloured women don't trust white women.
We didn't do anything good.
We never helped black women protect their husbands and sons.
Even after women achieved their right to vote in 1920, it took ten years for white women to unite against lynching in the South Women's Association for the Prevention of Lynchings.
This group appeared almost 40 years after black women first asked for help, Mitchell said.

From Mitchell's point of view, the rise of white feminist reactions to the problems raised by the Ferguson situation - police behaviour, racial discrimination - reflects a time when white feminists had to "take hold" the problems that black women have been dealing with in generations.
"Really, it would be great if activists who have such [traditional feminist] ideologies were as serious about the right to raise a child as they are about the right to contraception?" Mitchell asked.
The second-wave feminists who have made careers in the struggle for reproductive rights and access to contraceptives are now beginning to understand what that means.

A prominent white feminist activist, Gloria Steinem, two weeks after the murder of Michael Brown, used Facebook and published a sharp article by Guardian Rebecca Carroll, who demanded that white Americans take more part in protests about racism.

"I hope that women who have a different but similar reason to understand the dangers of the body - and the perspectives on racial issues that differ significantly in public polls - will be at the heart of change," wrote Steinem.
Although Steinham is vouchsafed for a more intersecting feminism that includes both race and gender issues, her comments on race in America still surprise some.

A researcher at the American Business Institute, Christine Sommers, author of "Who Stolen Feminism?," said She The People that young men in the United States, especially coloured young people, were "more vulnerable than their sisters," but Steinem's remarks about Ferguson ran counter to the criticism she had made earlier.
We now have hundreds of special programmes for girls and young women, but almost nothing for boys.

However, when the White House recently initiated a small program, "Standing My Brother" to help vulnerable black and Spanish-speaking youths, there was an angry reaction from many feminists, including Gloria Steinem.
Police relations with the black community are not the only problem in advancing the mainstream of traditional feminism.

After the U.S. Border Service arrested some 63,000 unaccompanied minors on the south-west border of the country this year, immigration reform came back to the surface - this time as a problem for women.

Andrea Mercado, co-chairman We Belong Together, an organization that mobilizes women in support of immigration reform, said that in order to make the issue important to women, she just had to share the stories of immigrant women.
"They speak for themselves," said Mercado.
When the vast majority of workers ' visas are issued to [male immigrants], women who come with them find themselves vulnerable to domestic violence and exploitation.
"These stories resonate with women's organizations," she said.

MINE wants to accelerate the growth of the electric car market.

This week, the Ministry of Economic Development will submit to the Government a comprehensive plan for the development of environmentally friendly transport in Russia, described the deputy director of the Ministry's department, Oleg Plurikov, on a round table that held "Vedomis" on the Moscow Motor Show 2014.
The plan was prepared on behalf of the Government and one of the main objectives was to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The document is expected to be adopted at the end of September to early October, says Pluričnik, the proposed measures relate to electric vehicles and hybrids - there is already a plan for the development of gas-fuelled vehicles in Russia.
The plan (a copy of which is available to the Reporters) is for 2014-2017.
There is a need to develop criteria for the evaluation of electric and hybrid transport and to decide how to promote the use and production of environmentally friendly vehicles.

A report to the Government describing tax and customs measures to support electric transport will be available by December 2014; a concessional credit and lease scheme will be available by April 2015; and proposals to reduce the price of machines, promote localization and establish service infrastructure will be developed by October 2015.
In 2014-2015, it is planned to amend the regulations to facilitate the construction of charging infrastructure (parks, petrol stations, etc.).

In addition, federal officials intend to propose to the regional authorities during 2015 that they also encourage the use of environmentally friendly transport, in the form of advantages in traffic and parking, for example; and by February 2016, proposals for the expansion of public procurement of such transport.

Finally, by October 2014, the Ministry of Economic Development will have included in the list of indicators for assessing the performance of regional authorities criteria that reflect the effectiveness of support for cleaner transport production and the development of charging infrastructure.
The market for electric vehicles in Russia is just emerging, with about 100 electric vehicles sold throughout the country in 2013.
In early 2014, the import tax on electric vehicles was over, so sales would be about 500 grand, predicted by the CEO of Mitsubishi Motors in Russia, Andrei Pankov.
But five-fold growth does not make the electric vehicles any more visible: in 2013, according to the European Business Association, 2.78 million cars and light commercial cars were sold in Russia.
So far, only Mitsubishi Motors have imported electric vehicles into Russia.
Renault is preparing to start imports, a company that focuses on corporate customers, says the Director of Strategic Planning and Partnerships of Renault in Russia, Nikola Remiz.
Most other electric transport producers have taken a wait-and-see position against Russia.
The development of electric vehicles also has Russian manufacturers - "", GAZA, "", but the output is tiny.
For example, between January and July 2014, according to ASM Holding, AvtoVAZ released 30 electric vehicles.

The demand is low because of the high cost of electric vehicles, says the director of Autowaza for the engineering of Sergei Amanov, without the help of God, there will be no breakthrough in this segment...

The development of the Russian market for electric vehicles, in addition to the high cost of machines (the electric vehicles that are sold in Russia, on average twice as much as those with internal combustion engines), is inhibited by the poor state of the charging infrastructure (fuels - units), and the Director General of Autostat, Sergei Celikov, sighs.

Owing to the high cost and low rate of reduction in the cost of electric vehicles, the Russian market will remain a niche for the next three to four years, and the editor-in-chief of the "Authorevu" Michael Podozozhanskii predicts that he will accept it.
By contrast, car manufacturers say that some models of electric vehicles are already close to the cost of conventional vehicles.

The Russian market for electric vehicles has good prospects, most importantly to build consumer confidence that "electric mobility" is real; this will be facilitated in particular by the emergence of new charging stations, as highlighted by the president of the BMW group in Russia, Wolfgang Schlimme.
Such infrastructure projects are being implemented, for example, by Rosseti State Company: several stations have been built in Moscow, and some 80 more will be available soon.
Negotiations on the construction of a refuelling network are ongoing with other regions.

According to the director of the Rosset Department, Vladimir Sofiin, the company believes in the electricity market and is ready to build gas stations across the country, but there are also problems: a small number of electric vehicles in the country and the lack of a single standard for charging electric vehicles with different brands.
In addition, Rosseti, as a network company, does not have the right to sell electricity, and is being explored for charging electric vehicles.
Pankov considers the most effective measure of support for the formation of an electric car market in Russia to be customs duty-free.
The zero rate will remain in effect until the end of 2014, and the possibility of extending it and extending the concessional list is being explored.
The replacement of the transport tax on the environment (the idea is discussed and applies to all machines) will also support the market, but not as tangible as the customs preferences Pankov thinks.
Transport tax is small in Russia, says Pankov, unlike Norway, for example, where tax cuts led to a sharp increase in the sales of electric vehicles - they now account for 12% of the market.

In Russia, incentives are also needed for car owners, such as free parking in the centre of the city (as already done in Moscow), confident Pankov, or the possibility of electric vehicles moving along the designated lanes, which is not yet available in Russia.

Twitter tried to become more interesting to new users.
Twitter Microblog Service has changed the user registration process to involve new players more quickly in active interaction with the platform.
This measure should reduce the number of people who have abandoned their microblogs.
New Twitter users will now view a large number of service-recommended accounts at the time of registration in order to form their own reading circle.
The recommendations are prepared on the basis of the interests indicated upon registration.
Twitter automatically ticks all automatically selected accounts.
Because of this, the user will have to take his own checkers off so as not to read anyone he's not interested in.
While users of the microblog service have previously seen only the avatars of recommended users, Twitter is now producing a sample of one of the blogger's popular tweets to help impress the person.
This is the biggest change on Twitter's Twitter page in the last three years.
Twitter has recently been actively working to modernize the service.
This activity is primarily related to the service ' s continuing efforts to achieve unprofitability.
In 2014, the microblog service experienced a slowdown in the growth of the user base and a decline in readers ' activity.
The company is now desperately in need of more loyal consumers who would have stayed for a long time once.
This is the only way to ensure a stable flow of advertising funds.

Motor vehicle disposal programme resumed on 1 September
Since 1 September, the Russian Federation has resumed its car recycling programme.
By 31 December 2014, 10 billion roubles will be allocated for this purpose.

As the head of the Russian Ministry of Industry, Denis Manturov, explained, the money is allocated from the limits that have already been brought to the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Russian Federation through redeployment from other areas of support.
The programme will cover all vehicles over six years of age.
The amount of compensation would range from 40,000 per car to 350,000 roubles per truck.
Previously, Russia had a similar car recycling programme.

The main difference in the current project, the Minister explained, is that it is now not only intended to dispose of the machines to obtain a subsequent discount, but also that if the car has reached the age of six, it is possible to purchase a new one at a discount when the old one is sold at the dealer's place of business, Interfax.
The previous federal recycling programme, which was in operation from 1 January 2010 until 31 December 2011, spent more than 16 billion rubles.
As a result, the car production rate in 2010 was about 1.2 million (plus 101.4 per cent in relation to 2009).
The Creator Coming Out Simulator will release a game about contemporary journalism.
The game designer Nikki Case, known as Coming Out Simulator, decided to release a game on contemporary journalism.

Case started working on the game a few weeks ago, but this fact is only now widely known.
The inspiration for the game came from events in Ferguson, where protests are now taking place after a police officer killed an unarmed black teenager.
The focus of the project, which does not yet have a title, will be how information coverage of stories affects their effects.

If he shoots the scene so that the cops look like heroes and the protesters are bandits, the police will start treating him better and letting him go where a normal person can't go.
If he were to cover events differently, his photos could turn peaceful protests into a massive riot.
The points in the game will need to be picked up by a Twitter hero in which new subscribers will appear if the photos there appear to be popular.

Bulgarian prison officers held a national protest
Hundreds of prison officials from all over Bulgaria held a national protest before the Ministry of Justice in the capital of Sofia.
During the peaceful demonstration, they reiterated their demands for the return of previous working conditions, which had recently been changed.
The salary increase is also part of the list of claims to be discussed with the Acting Minister of Justice, Christo Ivanov.
During the month, officers protested symbolically against the new schedule, demanding the return of the previous 24-hour shifts.
Although the Prison Service Union has met several times with representatives of the Ministry of Justice, no agreement has been reached, the Bulgarian National Radio (BNR) reports.
Negotiations are ongoing, as reported to the BNR by Rosen Jeliazkov, head of the Directorate-General for the Execution of Sentences.
Members of the Federation of Workers ' Trade Unions of the Ministry of the Interior are expected to join the protest of the Prison Workers ' Union.
The army controls the new Thai government
General Praith (right) appointed Rheit Wongsuwan (left) to the post of Minister of Defence

The Thai military ruler and Prime Minister, General Pratyt Chan-Ocha, announced the composition of the new Cabinet of Ministers, in which more than one third of the posts were filled by retired generals or generals.
The army has won key positions: the Ministers of Defence, Finance, Foreign Affairs and Trade.

On Monday, Praute Chan-Ocha was officially appointed Prime Minister following the official approval by the King of Thailand of the appointment of the head of the Interim Military Government to the post.
A 60-year-old military officer who took power in the country as a result of a bloodless coup on 22 May was the only candidate for the premiere.
He was elected Prime Minister at a parliamentary meeting.
The army had previously appointed members of Parliament.
According to Praitha Chan-Ocha, the coup was the only way to maintain stability.
It was preceded by six months of demonstrations, during which protesters demanded the resignation of Prime Minister Yinglak Chinawat.
Officially, Praute Chan-Ocha will be a temporary premiere, as the military plans to hold general elections at the end of 2015.
There are concerns, however, that the military is trying to strengthen its authority in the country.
The military came to power on 22 May
Against the backdrop of total paralysis of civil power.
The leaders of the main political parties were temporarily arrested.
Immediately after the military took power, they temporarily arrested leading politicians in the country, including Prime Minister Yinglyk Chinawat.
Some journalists and public figures were also detained.
The current political crisis dates back to 2006, when the army removed Brother Yinglyk Chinawat Thaksin as Prime Minister.
Both were popular among the rural population, especially in the northern part of the country, which had ensured their success in the elections.
However, many members of the middle class and the capital elite have joined the anti-government movement, which has virtually paralysed the country since November 2013.

Genetic disorder is often misdiagnosed
Brittany reported that she had spent many years thinking she was gonna die after the wrong diagnosis.
Karen Rogers spent most of her teenage years thinking that she had only a few years to live after she was diagnosed with another disease.
In fact, she had Charco-Marie-Touta (SMT) disease, a group of genetic disorders that caused nerve damage outside her brain and spine.
The charity CMT UK reported that the wrong diagnosis was a frequent problem among people with SMTs because so little was known about this condition.
Some 23,000 people in Britain are believed to have SMTs that can cause motor symptoms, such as muscle weakness, insecure walking, and flexed toes.
The sick may feel numbness or pain, and the condition does not heal and progress, which means that symptoms increase over time.
When Rogers was 13, she thought she was suffering from Friedreich's (AF) attack, a condition for which the prognosis was very bad.
Rogers thought she'd be chained to a wheelchair by the time she was 18, and die before she turned 30.
The mother of two children, now 51, said, "As a child, I knew I couldn't do what the others did.
I fell every day, and it took me more time.
I've never been able to skate or skateboard with other kids, and I've been bullied a lot at school because I've been walking and running.

Rogers said that when she was 13, after several surgeries to release the achille tendon and straighten her feet, she looked into the medical records when her doctor left the room, and it said she had an AF.
"I felt guilty because I snuck my nose where I shouldn't, and so I didn't tell anyone, but I came home, found information about it in the library, and wrote to the AF Association," she said.
When I got the information back, I was shocked and faced the worst panic possible.
I thought I'd be in a wheelchair at 18 and die before I turned 25, and that I'd gradually lose all my abilities in this period.
I went through this alone, and I planned my own funeral.
She said that by the time she was 17, she had realized that her ability to walk had not deteriorated as much as she thought and had asked her doctor about it.
He just stood up and hugged me and said, "My dear, I don't think you have this disease because you'd already be in a wheelchair."
I think you have something that poses a much smaller threat to life.
After several genetic tests, she was found to have SMTs.
"When he explained what SMT was, I thought I pulled a lucky ticket," she said.
The British SMT charity has announced a month of information about SMT to try to draw attention to this disease.
The tax burden on Washington area entrepreneurs increases as the economy recovers
A recovering economy means more customers, more sales, and new jobs.
It also means higher taxes.

State and local tax bills for companies across the country increased moderately last year, when economic recovery accelerated, according to a new study published last week, and companies in the Washington Zone were no exception.

Companies in the county, Maryland and Virginia together paid $27.6 billion to the state treasury and at the local level in fiscal year 2013, an increase of 3.8 per cent over the $26.6 billion raised in 2012.

The tax burden on state and local business increased by 4.3 per cent last year, to $671 billion, compared with 3.9 per cent a year earlier, the third consecutive year of growth after successive years of account decline in 2009 and 2010.
State taxes increased faster, 4.3 per cent than local taxes, 3.9 per cent, according to a study conducted by a professional service firm, Ernst & Young and the State Tax Centre, the Tax Policy Group.
More than half of the district ' s tax revenues, 56 per cent, are from business taxes, while 36 per cent of Maryland ' s tax revenues are from firms.
Virginia, with 28 per cent, generates the lowest tax revenue, proportionally, from entrepreneurs.

To a large extent, the increase in tax revenues is due to the return to the previous level of real estate value of companies, according to researchers, which raised real estate taxes by 3.7 per cent this year after three consecutive years of growth of less than 1 per cent.
While large states such as California, New York and Texas account for a large share of these revenues, the same seems to be happening in the Washington Zone.

Companies in the county, Maryland and Virginia together paid $10 billion in state and local real estate taxes last year, $9.6 billion more than in 2012, an increase of 4.2 per cent over the previous year.
However, the observed return on real estate has no similar effect on State and local tax revenues in Maryland, where real estate taxes are barely more than one fifth of company tax accounts.
Virginia and the District of Colombia pay about half of state and local tax accounts in the form of real estate taxes.

"What happens in Maryland is that so much of their real estate, especially the tax base around the District of Columbia, belongs either to the government or to a non-profit organization that does not pay real estate taxes," said Douglas Lindholm, Executive Director of the State Tax Center.
So Maryland has to rely much more on income taxes to pay for the same services that exist in other states.
The recent increase in tax revenues from entrepreneurs cannot be fully attributed to the re-establishment of the real estate market.
The income of entrepreneurs also seems to be being adjusted, according to these figures.
Companies in the region declared a state corporate income tax of $2.3 billion, $2.1 billion more than in 2012.
Maryland raised $1 billion of corporate income tax revenue, most of all in the region.
While trends are in the same direction, the tax burden of entrepreneurs at the local level is not increasing at the same rate in all three locations.
Colombia ' s growth rate was at the same level as the country ' s average of 4.3 per cent, while Maryland ' s growth was much faster, 4.9 per cent.
Only Virginia experienced a rise in tax revenues below the average of 4.1 per cent.
Virginia had the lowest corporate income tax in three jurisdictions (each with the same corporate rate) of 6 per cent.
Maryland has a corporate rate of 8.25 per cent, while the district has a relatively high rate of 9.975 per cent.

A similar study by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce earlier this year found that Virginia has lower taxes for state and local entrepreneurs and a generally more favourable climate for business taxes than Maryland.
The county was not assessed in this study.
Despite its advantage, Virginia is under competitive pressure from its neighbour from the south.
North Carolina recently signed a law reducing the corporate rate from 6.9 per cent to 6 per cent this year, as in Virginia, and the rate falls to 5 per cent next year.
If the state continues to meet tax revenue targets next year, the law could raise the income tax rate for entrepreneurs to even 3 per cent by 2017.
Meanwhile, small businesses in the Washington Zone seem to feel better and thus pay more state and local taxes, according to a recent study.

Business taxes paid in the form of individual income tax by small business owners - the transition structure used by most small firms - in Columbia, Maryland and Virginia increased by 20 per cent last year to $2.4 billion, at a much faster rate of growth than taxes for entrepreneurs as a whole.

Researchers say that the trend and increase in business tax revenues across the country is likely to continue this year, with turnover tax revenues from state and local governments rising by 6.2 per cent in the first three quarters of 2014 compared to the same period last year.
However, the Washington Zone may lag behind, as the decline in federal spending affects the labour market in the region.

Amazon buys Twitch for $1,04 billion.

AMAZON has just confirmed what Information reported on Friday morning: an online shop - and a video producer, and a hundred other things - buys a streaming video production service called Twitch for $1,04 billion (US$970 million).
This news turned out to be a surprise not because nobody expected Twitch to be sold, but because many expected YouTube to be a buyer.
Three months ago, selling Twitch video service to Google for a good billion looked completely ready, and that combination seemed natural.
==History==Twitch, based only three years ago as Justin.tv, set the goal of being a stream service of a general nature, a real-time YouTube version.
Instead, it quickly evolved into a platform where gamers broadcast their intragame moments; "YouTube for real-time games", according to Business Insider.
Interface Twitch.
And "let's play", a video genre in which all-knowing people process (mainly old) games, like in "The Mystery Theatre", is already popular on YouTube.

The fact is that YouTube is often mentioned when Twitch is described, so the news that YouTube is buying Twitch has been met with little interest, a classic example of a well-established technology company that buys a potential rival.
It's a secret why the YouTube deal failed, given that it was reported that he was willing to pay no less than Amazon.

All we have so far is a statement from Executive Director Twitch Emmett Shire: "We chose Amazon because they believe in our community, they share our values and long-term goals, and they want to help us achieve them faster."
Another secret, frankly, is the incredible success of Twitch.
Snobs like me, who claim to be better at sports than watching it, find it hard to understand the appeal of watching games instead of taking the joystick into their own hands.
It's one thing to look over a friend's shoulder at 3:00 a.m. when she crawls through Resident Evil, and quite another to watch some stranger get 20 shots in the head in a row at Call of Duty.
All the games you could watch right now.

Another problem is that many of today's most popular games are designed for one person, so watching them without controlling the angle of vision alone can be a recipe for a headache worthy of Do It Right.
I agree that the speed passes in which the Rogers of the Bannisters of our e-century complete their entire games on record dates are entertaining.
But if it's not a game virtuse or humour, it's unlikely that his Twitch channel will be interesting at all.
But what do skeptics like me know?
Twitch has 55 million unique visitors a month, and it's the fourth largest source of peak Internet traffic.
How exactly does Amazon work on this?
It's hard to imagine that Twitch will fold into Amazon Instant Video as gracefully as YouTube could just swallow Twitch.
However, Twitch has something that any company would love to have: a crowd of young men who are dreamed of by advertisers.
As Twitch Shire, Amazon and Twitch said, "Both believe in the future of games," and this channel does not show signs of wilt, even - ooh - as a spectacular sport.

The deputies proposed to expedite the entry into force of the Personal Data Act
If the initiative succeeds, Russian data cannot be stored on servers abroad as of 1 January 2015
A draft law has been submitted to the State for the postponement of the date of entry into force of the already adopted Russian Personal Data Act from 1 September 2016 to 1 January 2015.
The initiative is part of the legislative framework of the lower house.
It was sponsored by the deputies of the State Duma, Vadim Dengin, Jaroslav Nelov (LDDP), Evgeny Fedorov (the only Russia), Vladimir Parahin (the just Russia) and Alexander Yushchenko (KPRF).

Such a change, in the view of the authors of the initiative, would help to ensure more quickly and effectively the rights of citizens of the Russian Federation to preserve personal data and to respect the confidentiality of communications in information and telecommunications networks.

The Act, the entry into force of which is the responsibility of parliamentarians, requires that Russians ' personal data, which are processed on the Internet, be kept in the territory of the Russian Federation.

It also requires the recording, systematization, stockpiling, storage, clarification and extraction of personal data of citizens of the Russian Federation in databases located on Russian territory, as well as the indication of the location of such databases.
In addition, the law gives Roscomnadzor the right, on the basis of a court decision, to restrict access to information processed in violation of Russian legislation in the field of personal data.
The Act also proposes the creation of so-called "blacklists" of offending sites, an automated information system called "Registration of violators of the rights of personal data subjects".
This law was passed by the State Duma in the summer.
The draft law was sponsored by Andrei Lugova and Vadim Dengin of LDPR and Alexander Yushchenko of CLCF.
Dengin and Yushchenko are also among the sponsors of the current bill to postpone the date of entry into force of the already adopted law.
Those who don't have a date center in the Russian Federation will have to pay rent.

Commenting on the bill submitted to the State today, Leonid Levine, the first deputy head of the Duma Committee on Information Policy, stated that he saw no problem in postponing the date of entry into force of the Personal Data Protection Act.

According to him, those companies that would not have their own Russian personal data warehouses on Russian territory by 1 January 2015 would be able to rent them, such as "Rostelcoma," which repeatedly said that they were willing to lease their servers and were already providing their servers, from Mail Group, Western companies that were now providing their servers."
"There are also several independent data centres ready to cooperate in this area," he added.

"If companies decide to comply with the law and continue to work in the territory of the Russian Federation, I see no problem - they will have technological accommodation opportunities", Levin summarized.
Dispute Bill

Immediately after the publication of the draft law, the Russian Electronic Communications Association expressed concern that many global Internet services would no longer be available to Russians if the draft law were adopted.
These include online booking services for airline tickets and hotels.

According to the association, "the draft law deprives the subjects of personal data - citizens of the Russian Federation - of the right to dispose of their own data by making it mandatory that their recording, systematization, etc. be ensured only in databases located on the territory of the Russian Federation".
RAEC ' s statement emphasizes that a more effective measure would be to establish a mechanism to inform the user of where the recording takes place by systematizing his personal data.
In such a case, it will be possible to choose in which territory the activities will take place.
The adoption of similar personal data "localization" bills in other countries has led to the abandonment of global services and significant economic losses.

The militia handed over more than 400 prisoners to the Ukrainian military
In Novoroscia's Army, they claim to have hit Ukrainian Su-27 and accuse the enemy of violating the cease-fire agreement.

Russia reserves the right to take countermeasures aimed at protecting its legitimate interests in the event of the imposition of new anti-Russian sanctions, and informs the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation.

Sneaky ways to save money on university textbooks.
While the cost of university textbooks for many students exceeds $1,000 a year, Matt Schroeder, who is about to graduate, has come up with a clever way to cut costs.
He developed a system for renting books from seniors, offering them nominal compensation to postpone their sale.

"My textbook on mathematical analysis, which usually costs $180, I got a semester for $10 and a cookie called "Chick-fil-A", says Schroeder, 19 years old, who goes to the Covenant of College in Georgia.
The literature needed last semester would have cost $430, he says.
He spent $120.
According to the College Council, an average student spends more than $1,200 a year on textbooks and educational supplies, but students have a variety of options to reduce these costs.
Students are increasingly choosing Internet shops and creative ideas like Schroeder's system.
Book rentals are becoming more popular, allowing students to use the book for a semester, and often cost much less than buying it.
Nibo Incorporate, which owns more than 250 university bookstores, reports that book rentals have doubled since 2011.
Studies in the industry show that about a quarter of the books in university bookstores were rented during the last spring semester, says Vice-President "Nibo" Trevor Meyer.
Fewer than half of all books are purchased from university bookstores, according to the professional association National Association of University Shops.
Here's an introductory course on how best to make a good deal.
Buying from an Internet store
Sometimes, if you go online, the price of a new book can be one third of what you see in a university bookshop.

The ninth edition of "Mathematic Analysis" by Ron Larson, Bruce Edwards and Robert Hostettler costs about $290 on the list, but a new copy can be purchased for $239.99 on Chegg.com, which specializes in the sale of textbooks.
Purchase of used
If you don't mind other people's markings or damage, used textbooks are a good option.
Mathematical analysis is sold for $93.49 in used form on Chegg.com.

Matt Kasaday, 25, a fourth-year student from Brigham Young University, says he paid Amazon.com 42 cents for a second-hand copy of a textbook entitled Strategic Solutions in Media: Understanding the Business side of the advertising business.
The book was sold for $48 new.

Teachers, such as Ingrid Bracy, director of the College without Walls at the University of Massachusetts in Emherst, invite students to check with their professors whether previous publications can be used.
Sometimes updates aren't important for class.
In such cases, old publications can often be found for a very small share of the cost of the latest edition.
In addition to Chegg and Amazon, Half.com, owned by eBay Inc., is a popular alternative to buying used books.
Hire
The idea of renting textbooks is to think, if you're good enough to handle them, remember to return them, and don't want to keep them after you've finished the course.
You can save more than 80% of the cost of a new book.
For example, one student was able to rent Mathematical Analysis for a semester for about $20.
Find out the rules of the store where you take books, including any fines that you may receive for marking, underscoring, and damage.
If you rent a book, remember: If you do not return the book, the fines may even exceed the cost of the new copy.
Electronic books
Electronic books instead of traditional textbooks are another option.
Sometimes such books are actually rented by acquiring an electronic license for a certain period from distributors such as Amazon.com, Chegg and Barnes & Noble Inc.
"Mathematic Analysis" on Chegg.com will cost approximately $61 for six months.

Bracey says that students studying literature can often find the best prices, as many classical works can now be downloaded free of charge, while literature in natural and engineering sciences can be very expensive.
No matter what, take a look around.

Joe Golt, 29 years old, who is going to begin his studies at Pepperdin Law School, recommends using the ISBN number to determine the price of a book, as this guarantees that you are looking for the exact text you need.
Before you order on the Internet, Holt says, make sure there's a book in the warehouse.
This lesson has not been easy for him.
The delivery of the book he purchased was postponed for four weeks, and eventually he paid the full price at the university bookstore.

Statistics show that more than 4 million tons of fish were caught in Russia in 2013, and that much of the fish goes to Japan, Korea, and even the United States.
Fish imports in 2013 are about 800,000 tons.
The "Our People" shop has been operating since 2012, selling fish through an online store, serving a dozen more restaurants, such as "Simple Things" before sanctions were imposed.
There are now 15 other restaurants that have applied for Galkin.
We can make the same sushi out of our fish, and it's hot.
We've had a bit of trouble, we've tried different recipes.
We're selling sushi through an Internet store for a million rubles a month.
Our fish is a few times cheaper, and our delivery is a maximum of 15 rubles per kilo.
I'm getting a lot of Philadelphia with a keta to confirm at Galkin's tent.
Unlike the seed rolls, it takes longer to chew, but the realization that this fish, our home-grown fish, is giving us strength.
There are even halibut rolls and sea bastards on the website of The People.
In sushi bars, it is true that Chileans prefer to replace Norwegian salmon.
Galkin explains it because cooks are lazy to come up with new recipes with long-east fish.
"Rossian fish suppliers have not yet offered us," explains the owner of the Killfish Bar, Dmitri Euseev.
The situation with other products is similar: Russian producers could take the newly released niche, but this is not the case.
According to the founder and co-owner of the LavkaLavka project Boris Akimov, imports from China, Israel and Latin America are now more likely to be replaced by imports from Europe and America.
There are large multinational corporations that have powerful logistics and large volumes.
They can quickly replace prohibited imports, unlike our farmers.
That is to say, the main beneficiaries of the ban are the major producers of other countries," said Akimov.
In the last month, however, the restaurant industry received a more alarming message than food sanctions.
As a result of mass unannounced inspections, three McDonald's enterprises in Moscow and two regional enterprises in Stavropol and Yekaterinburg were temporarily suspended.
"We are studying the nature of the claims in order to determine the actions required to open restaurants for visitors as soon as possible," said Moneygam at McDonald's Press Service.
No one really knows what's going to happen.
If everything is limited to food sanctions, it's one option that can survive, says the employee of the restaurant consulting company anonymously.
If McDonald's all over the country starts shutting down, it's gonna be a whole different scenario.
Europrotocol instead of HBBD's certificate
The Casco payment can be received without a certificate from the HYDDA, so the BC intends to encourage the introduction of "europrotocol" in Russia.
The Bank of Russia has drawn up draft guidelines according to which, as of 1 September this year, the insured motorist will be able to obtain payment for the Casco payment without a GIDB certificate.
It is true that it is only in cases where the accident was "europrotocol" without the involvement of the traffic police.

In other words, if only two vehicles were involved in the accident, there were no physically injured persons, the damage did not exceed the limit and both drivers agreed on who was responsible for the accident.
From 2 August, the payment limit for Europrotocol is 50,000 roubles, and from 1 October it will be raised to 400,000 roubles in Moscow, St. Petersburg, as well as in the Moscow and Leningrad regions.
The point is that, often even with minor injuries, in a situation where an accident can be described as a "europrotocol", drivers who have been involved in an accident call a DPS.
After all, if there was a Casco policy, it was not possible to recover it without a GIBDD certificate.
The parameters described in the draft directive are intended to remove this obstacle to the introduction of "europrotocol" in Russia.
According to them, the maximum payment for Casco in the event of an accident without GIDD personnel should not be lower than the "europrotocol" limit.
At the same time, however, it cannot be above the limit defined in the Casco insurance policy.
The idea is certainly useful and theoretically able to unload both DPS and road staff.
But it's probably not gonna please the motorists or the insurers.
The latter are already pointing to the serious threat posed by the increase in fraud, which could be caused by the introduction of new regulations on the payment of Cascos.
As far as drivers are concerned, it is difficult to imagine what work it will take to overcome Russian traditional conservatism.
The driver will in most cases wait hours for the inspector to sign up for a minor accident because it's more reliable.
And there's no way that it's gonna be easier to defeat fraudsters or convince drivers of the reliability of Europrotocol.
The savings certificate will make it nameless.
Minfin wants to ban the bearer's savings certificates, but he's gonna let the banks give them an analog of unrevocable contributions.
The Ministry of Finance is preparing a bill that will ban the bearer ' s savings certificates.
Recently, this instrument has gained popularity, as the stakes are higher than on bank deposits.

The fact is that the bearer ' s savings certificates do not enter the deposit insurance system, and the bank is cheaper to pay because it does not have to contribute to the Deposit Insurance Agency ' s (AV) fund.

The risk is that small and medium-sized banks distributing such certificates are planning to take this step and that Sberbank and the Bank of Moscow will suffer from it, which AV estimates are responsible for 98 per cent of the relevant market.
The Bank of Moscow, according to the Agency, accounts for about 3.5 per cent.
The problem, explained in the AV, is that the customers of a small bank that purchased such a certificate seek to obtain money from the AV if the licence is revoked.
Some depositors may assume that their investments are insured if they do not have sufficient financial literacy and purchase the bearer ' s savings certificates.
The justified absence of insurance payments on these certificates in the event of the withdrawal of the bank ' s licence could lead to misunderstanding and social tension.
In the practice of the agency, there have been cases where bearers of bearer certificates have attempted to recover insurance compensation through a court of law," stated to the AVA.
The problem, of course, is concocted.
After all, no one will pay certificates to buyers, since they have no legal right to compensation from the State.

If it had been that the instrument was not insured at the ASV, metal accounts would have been banned along with it, in which citizens ' funds were recorded in grams of one of the four metals - gold, silver, platinum and palladium.
These accounts, too, are not covered by deposit insurance, but they have not yet been compromised.
It is likely that bearer certificates are a very convenient security document that can actually act as a quasi-denegium.
However, their movement is largely uncontrollable: any bank customer can buy a certificate, hand it over to any citizen, and before cashing it can be replaced by many owners.
It is not by accident that the bill stipulates that the savings certificate must be the specific security that must be kept in the depositary.
And in order to sweeten the pill, banks are allowed to issue such certificates without early repayment.
That is, an analogy is being introduced to the irrevocable contribution that bankers have long dreamed of.
